Reluctant Rebels: The Confederates Who Joined the Army after 1861
Noe
column2: Kenneth W.			"<h3>Interview with Dr. Kenneth W. Noe
column3: Professor of History at Auburn University

column1: Interviewed by Nathan Buman
Click here for the review
Civil War Book Review (CWBR): I'm here today with Kenneth Noe
column2: author of Reluctant Rebels: The Confederates Who Joined the Army after 1861. Professor Noe
column3: thank you for joining me.

column1: Kenneth Noe (KN): I’m happy to be here Nathan.
CWBR: You suggest
column2: in your introduction
column3: that Confederate soldiers who joined the army after the initial enlistment wave in 1861
column4: including later enlisters
column5: substitutes
column6: and conscripts
column7: remain an understudied group in Civil War scholarship. How did you choose to focus your study on the later enlisters instead of the substitutes or conscripted soldiers?

column1: KN: Well
column2: that’s a long story and probably has two parts.  In terms of studying later enlisters in general
column3: it really goes back to 2002 when I was a commentator for a session on the Civil War at the Library of Congress.  At that time Joe Glatthaar had given a paper on why soldiers fought and really summed up very nicely the literature that was out there on the whole question of soldier motivation as we have come to call it.  And I was actually in a bit of a pickle for a while because Joe’s paper was so good that I wasn’t sure exactly what I was going to be able to say as commentary.  But it did strike me as I read the paper again that there was an interesting problem in the literature that we had overlooked
column4: that most of the research that had been done on Civil War soldiers on why they fought and why they stayed really focused on those who had enlisted early in the war and who had remained with the regiments for as long as possible and generally they were in the so-called fighting regiments that we talk about.  I suggested that day in Washington that
column5: if we wanted a fuller picture of the Civil War soldier experience
column6: we really to look at the conscripts and substitutes but also the men who enlisted later in the war.  Almost a quarter of the men who fought in the Confederate Army did not enlist in 1861; they enlisted later.  And while some of them certainly were young in 1861
column7: although enough men lied about their age and enlisted anyway
column8: most of the three-quarters were not
column9: they could have enlisted right after Fort Sumter and I was really curious as to why they did not.  In terms of why the book ended up focusing on later enlisters more than conscripts and substitutes
column10: that’s actually more of a research question more than anything else.  I really wanted to get into their thoughts and that meant reading letters and diaries rather than looking at other source of material that could help us to get to people who did not leave those written records.  I also wanted to focus on material that was written during the war; I was a little suspicious of things that would have been written in Reconstruction or Redemption or thereafter.  And what that left me with was a research base with quite a few later enlisters
column11: although not as many as I had expected to find
column12: but very few conscripts and substitutes.  I think one of the issues we’ll have to deal with as we move forward and try to understand conscription and substitution more is that we just don’t seem to have many written records
column13: letters and diaries in which these men express their thoughts so we’re going to have to approach them through means other than the ones I used.

column1: CWBR: You mention your methodology; you state your desire to use letters written by soldiers during the war instead of those post-1865 Reconstruction or Redemption accounts. How does this choice shape your study and how might the later
column2: more traditional sources have altered your study.

column1: KN: Well I’ve worked with those later sources throughout my career and they’re certainly useful for many things. In terms of trying to understand how people thought at a given moment I tend to be suspicious of materials that appear 20
column3: 40 years after the war.  I’ll give you an example actually from a different book that I’ve done.  Years ago I edited the Civil War memoirs of a Union soldier from middle Tennessee.  His name was Marcus Woodcock; he fought in the 9th Kentucky Infantry.  And really before the war was over
column4: in 1865 after his regiment was mustered out
column5: he came home and started writing his memoir
column6: and got all the way up to the Atlanta campaign before he stopped
column7: and part of that memoir includes a discussion of his first battle.  That was at Stone’s River.  He describes at one point the death of his best friend a man named James Tooley and he’s very insistent in this 1865 document that Tooley never saw it coming.  There was no discussion of “what would happen if I die
column8: ” certainly Tooley never came out and said “I’ve had this premonition that I will not survive the battle.”  Woodcock was very insistent that that did not happen.  Years later
column9: towards the end of his life
column10: I want to say 1911 (I should have gone back and checked the date but I think 1911) he started to rewrite that memoir again.  And when he got to the Stone’s River portion he was very insistent that James Tooley had foreseen his own death and had discussed it the night before the battle.  Well this was something that he absolutely denied right after the war.  Now why did Marcus Woodcock in 1911 believe that his friend had had this premonition?  I don’t think he was a liar; this was a man who spent most of his adult life after the war working for the Baptist Church in Tennessee.  But I think after reading all of his accounts of soldier premonitions over the years
column11: Woodcock had come to convince himself that his friend Tooley had had one.  If I relied on that 1911 document instead of the 1865 document I would have a very different view of the death of James Tooley and that’s why in this book
column12: in Reluctant Rebels
column13: because I was really interested in trying to understand how they felt at the moment of enlistment
column14: when they first got in the camp
column15: when they first went into battle
column16: I was suspicious of those later recounts simply because I wondered how many of them would have the equivalence of the premonition of the death of James Tooley as part of a narrative.

column1: CWBR: On page 7
column2: you quote James McPherson who said that the “prototypical unwilling soldier…was a nonslaveholding Southern married farmer with small children who was drafted in 1862 or enlisted to avoid being drafted.” How would you change this statement or how would you summarize your findings based on the sampling of 320 soldiers. Is it possible to describe the prototypical unwilling soldier in the Confederate Army?

column1: KN: Statistically half of them were not married. Statistically many of them were not farmers. I was surprised to find the numbers of not farmers in the sample. I did not find a great deal of evidence that they enlisted because of the bounty. Now some men did clearly enlist because of the bounty (I would say roughly around 11 percent) but most of them offered no evidence of that’s why they had enlisted in 1862 or 1863. There’s not a lot of evidence of men who enlisted because they thought they were about to get drafted so they did so; you could count them on one hand in my sample. What I discovered were men who enlisted for a variety of other reasons: ideology to a certain extent but
column2: again
column3: not as much as I anticipated; men who enlisted more
column4: I think
column5: because they had by 1862 come to see the Union Army as a threat to their livelihood
column6: a threat to their homes
column7: literally a threat to their farms
column8: their livestock
column9: their slaves if they were slave owners
column10: a threat to their family.  Once they had come to the conclusion that the Union Army was coming to their state
column11: perhaps coming to their county
column12: prepared to deprive them of everything they had worked for in their adult life
column13: that’s when they start to enlist.  So on that point
column14: I do disagree with Dr. McPherson
column15: although I think he’s right about men who enlisted earlier in the war in terms of importance of ideology and comradeship and so forth. I just don’t think that description carries over when we start talking about these later enlisters as a separate cohort.

column1: CWBR: You mention these people who enlist when the northern army arrives in their area and you mention the ideology and sort of the different things that encouraged them to enlist. It seems to me that it is very difficult to pin down a broad description of these later enlisters. Could you maybe argue that these later enlisters were representative of a cross-section of southern society as a whole?
KN: Well I think if we compare them to those that we have been reading about
column2: if we compare them to earlier enlisters
column3: I think it’s safer to say that they were less ideological
column4: they were less motivated by the spread eagle speeches that were going around in 1860 and 1861.  They were certainly locally oriented.  Now that’s true of southern society in general; it’s a very localist society in 1860 but their localism
column5: their attachment to kin and neighborhood strikes me as particularly strong.  In terms of being a cross-section and certainly in terms of age they run across the spectrum.  I discovered many more slaveholders in this cohort than I expected.  In fact
column6: the number of slaveholders in my samples is almost exactly the same figure as slave holding families would have been in the Confederacy as a whole.  So
column7: to that extent
column8: they do reflect the region as a whole but I find them to be
column9: in comparison to those who went before them
column10: less ideological and more local. They have less of a sense of country or nationhood than those men who enlisted in the summer of 1861.

column1: CWBR: How difficult was it
column2: then
column3: to designate or pin down a specific reason for any one soldier’s enlistment.  Were there any common themes throughout or was it just simply certain soldiers mentioning over and over the reasons for their enlistment?  And
column4: broadly then
column5: do you see general themes coming out in these letters across the 320 when they are talking about family or war experience?  What sort of things
column6: outside of reasons for enlistment were they concerned with in their letters?

column1: KN: It was difficult; in fact it sort of became an issue at my house. We'd have guests over and people would ask me what I was writing about and I would tell them I was writing about Confederate soldiers and they always wanted to know more and I found it was really difficult to explain the book. It seemed to take me several minutes to go through all the permeations of what it was and what it wasn’t and what I was trying to do. So
column2: in that sense
column3: I think it was difficult when it came down to actually trying to identify a thesis that I could explain easily.  One thing I did
column4: in terms of trying to come to grips with these men
column5: is that I wanted to count.  I think it’s easy to go through sources from this period or any period and find the things that we are looking for and emphasize those and perhaps de-emphasize others.  We’ve had historians
column6: John Lynn comes to mind
column7: Joe Glatthaar again comes to mind
column8: who suggest that we need to be fairly rigorous with our research
column9: that we need to actually count and compare.  So what I did was come up with a rubric of various things that I might expect to find
column10: I added and subtracted as I went along
column11: and I started counting in terms of how many men mention any sort of political ideology; how many men write about their country; how many men compare the Confederate Revolution to the American Revolution; how many men talk about religion; how many men talk about slavery; how many men complain that they don’t get their bounty.  And when I had those figures and started to compare within the work certain patterns really started to develop.  I found that well over a third of these men were writing about religion.  I found that a little less than 20% ever mentioned political ideology and for most of them it was one mention
column12: here I followed Gary Gallagher’s rule that one mention is enough
column13: and I think that’s probably a fair argument.  We don’t know what they said in camp
column14: we don’t know how many letters were lost
column15: but they’re writing more about religion than ideology.  They’re writing more about home than anything else.  They’re writing home and they’re concerned about how their wives and other family members are keeping the farms going.  They’re concerned about what might happen if the Union Army shows up.  They’re writing about their hatred of the enemy; there are almost as many who write about how much they hate the Yankees as who write about any sort of political ideology but when you look at that hatred even more what bothers them isn’t northern politics as much as this notion of Union soldiers as vandals
column16: as property thieves; they’re going to come and take my slaves and my livestock and my land and my senses and leave me a poor man.  That’s the issue that really crops up.  So
column17: in terms of doing these comparisons
column18: I really did start to see patterns and more and more it struck me that these patterns were pointing back toward home even in areas that I did not expect.  In looking at religion
column19: for example
column20: how many men did not participate in those great revivals that we are always reading about in the winters of 1862-1863 and 1863-1864.  For so many of them their religious experience was taking place among their comrades in their messes or in their letters as they were writing back home still trying to maintain that position as head of family worship.  Comradeship was certainly important but it was a comradeship that was with men from home
column21: relatives
column22: and kin and I was surprised to find that they seemed to have trouble making new bonds with men that they had met in the army.  So again and again the numbers and the words as well were pointing me back toward home and away from what I think is the dominant interpretation right now of soldiers in general
column23: which is that they were fighting for ideas.

column1: CWBR: Let’s talk about these ideas and the political ideology. What do your findings contribute to the long-time historical debate about Confederate nationalism? And I wonder how you might account for
column2: it seems to me you suggest a stronger
column3: more committed nationalism among the early enlisters in 1861 than we see later; you suggest that that nationalism did not wane and other scholars have suggested so. Why couldn’t this Confederate nationalism build within these later enlisters as they spent more time in the army and among the veteran soldiers?

column1: KN: Well it’s an interesting question. It doesn’t seem to. I think
column2: like the soldiers that Jerry Prokopowicz talks about
column3: their loyalty was more to company and to a certain extent regiment than it was to army or much less nation.  They just don’t write about nationalism that much; 61 out of my 320 mentioned any sort of political ideology but of those if you break it down
column4: and bear in mind some men are in several categories because they are writing about 3 or 4 different things
column5: I have about 10% who write about their country and as I said a few minutes ago most of them mention it once.  I have 5 or 6 fervent nationalists who write a lot about their country but for most of them it’s a passing phrase that pops up in a passage about something else.  We’ve read that the American Revolution was tremendously important to the Civil War generation.  Reid Mitchell was the first person who wrote about that and yet
column6: out of my 320
column7: only 9 of the men in my sample ever mentioned the American Revolution.  Nine percent
column8: 29 out of 320
column9: mentioned independence as a goal
column10: as a fact in some manner
column11: and most of them mentioned it once.  Subjugation is a word that James McPherson pointed us to
column12: this notion of being forced to knuckle under to the Lincoln administration and its political ideas including abolition.  They don’t write much about subjugation; I think I have 17 of them that mention the word once.  And finally states rights
column13: I mean growing up in Virginia I was taught year after year that Confederate soldiers had fought for states rights
column14: not for other issues
column15: and certainly not for slavery.  But in fact out of my 320
column16: I only had a dozen who ever mentioned anything that looked like states rights.  These men were not nationalists; they weren’t ideologists.  I suspect (I can’t prove it; I don’t have enough men who write about why they did not enlist in 1861 to do more than suggest) but I think that it was that lack of political fervor
column17: that lack of interest in those sorts of ideas that may have kept most of them out of the army when the war began.  But as the war dragged on and as the Union Army became more of an immediate threat to their homes
column18: their neighborhood
column19: their livelihood
column20: they were spurred to enlist.

column1: CWBR: You spend a great deal of time talking about the later enlisters and how they viewed their comrades and how they viewed the veteran soldiers who had joined in 1861. I wonder if the early enlisters write about their opinions of later-enlisting comrades. Were they considered equal on the battlefield and in camp or were they something of a newcomer
column2: not as dedicated to the cause.

column1: KN: Well I tended to look at these issues from the later enlisters point of view. I really didn’t spend a lot of time reading primary material from the earlier enlisters as they wrote about the new ones. I have looked at those sources for other projects from time to time and yeah I think there was a sense
column2: in many cases
column3: that these were men who were not as good as us
column4: not as fervent as us.  You know a lot of them are here for the bounty.  These are expressions that I have seen in both in Union sources and in Confederate sources.  The way the later enlisters saw it though
column5: when they arrive in regiments they are arriving in most cases as men who know where they are going.  They’re coming to particular companies and regiments when they can and various legislation makes that possible for them where they know people.  They are coming to this company and this regiment because their brother is there
column6: or their neighbor is there
column7: or somebody is there.  And I suspect that these transitions into those units
column8: to an extent that men going to brand-new regiments are certainly conscripts would not find when they came to the army.  As far as the later enlisters saw
column9: it they were just as good of soldiers as anyone else once they got there and they don’t really write about being shunned or unwelcome.

column1: CWBR: During your discussion of the widespread shift later in the book
column2: the shift away from card playing and rabble rousing in the southern armies
column3: these sorts of sinful acts as those morally-concerned soldiers call it.  On page 133
column4: you state that “what later enlisters now added to the mix was a pronounced family orientation that kept them mentally and spiritually connected to home.”  Is this shift away from these licentious acts
column5: is that simply due to an increasing likelihood of older
column6: married enlisters and the maturing of the veterans or is it just a general shift as the soldiers realized that war was not a party?

column1: KN: Well in a way I think it’s both. Yes in a way you are dealing with an older cohort; my men are a few years older than that average we always hear of 21 or 22 but I think that it’s important to look at when they come to the army. When we read these accounts of how wild and crazy camp was
column2: Steve Woodworth has done this beautifully
column3: we’re really looking at 1861 and 1862; we’re looking at men coming to the war without really knowing what the battle is going to look like.  My argument is that
column4: by the time later enlisters start showing up in Confederate ranks in February-March of 1862
column5: they’re joining a veteran army that has already by itself
column6: to an extent
column7: gone through that transition.  I mean yes there are some pious later enlisters who write about all the sinful acts they find in camp but I found a lot less of that than I expected and my sense is that the army itself
column8: that army of earlier enlisters
column9: had already made that transition because of the combat experience that had sobered them up.  So later enlisters
column10: yes they’re older men
column11: but they’re also arriving in
column12: to an extent
column13: more sober camps than those that had been in existence a year earlier. So to that extent the army was never as wild for them as I might have been for people who joined up.

column1: CWBR: In part of the larger discussion of maturing of the forces
column2: what caused the widespread shift toward religion that began in Stonewall Jackson’s Corps in the Army of Northern Virginia and its subsequent spread westward?  Was it
column3: as some scholars have suggested a conscious desire for southerners to legitimize their cause and give it a moral foundation?

column1: KN: Well I think there probably was some of that. For later enlisters
column2: in particular
column3: because they’re the ones I know the best it was a lot more personal.  I think it really was
column4: these are men who had a hard time leaving home.  By and large they did not want to be in the army.  They did enlist
column5: they were willing to fight
column6: they were certainly literally willing to fight but they wanted the war to end.  They loved to use that phrase “this cruel war.”  This was not a marvelous moment in their life
column7: for most of them it was a terrible thing that happened; they wanted to go home.  When they got to the army they were faced with the reality of death: death in camp
column8: death as a result of battle
column9: they saw men dying
column10: they saw their friend dying
column11: they knew that they might not get home.  And I think that shaped their religious response.  If you go back to the time of the American Revolution
column12: Americans (westerners in general) have a sort of vague sense of the afterlife.  They’re not really sure what heaven is going to look like.  It’s going to be good but there’s no real sense of well it’s going to be just like life on earth.  For a lot of reasons during the Jacksonian period
column13: by the time we get to 1860
column14: there is a sense among American Protestants
column15: North and South
column16: that heaven is going to look a whole lot like home
column17: that when a Christian dies and goes to heaven that man is going to live in a small nuclear household with his wife and with his kids if they too were saved and if they too were able to get to heaven and that life was going to go on pretty much as it had before only better.  So what happens with a lot of these men is that they start using the same phrase over and over.  They start writing their wives and their children to an extent and they say “let us meet in heaven
column18: if we do not again meet on this earth
column19: let us meet in heaven” and they spend a lot of time trying to convince their wives and their children to live good Christian lives.  I think it was the ultimate way of getting home for men who weren’t sure that they were going to get back to their earthly home in North Carolina or Alabama or wherever
column20: there was still that hope that belief that their families would be reunited in a home in the afterlife.  And so again for them religion tends to be very
column21: very personal.  They don’t write very much at all about the Confederacy as a Christian nation
column22: that they are Christian soldiers that they are fighting against godless abolition; I mean there are a very small number of them that do.  Their religion for them I think it was for antebellum southerners as a whole was very personal and very
column23: very family oriented and
column24: to an extent
column25: individual and that’s really what drives their religious expression through the war.

column1: CWBR: In summary then
column2: do we have some sense of what happened to these 320 soldiers from your sample that you built your study around?  Do you know how many died during the war?  And I wonder how
column3: I know you wanted to focus on their writings during the war
column4: but I wonder how their post-war memories or reflections might have differed from their feelings during the war?

column1: KN: It’s a wonderful question. Those who survived
column2: and some of them did
column3: I mean how did they look back on the war 30 and 40 years later and that’s probably another good study to be written but that’s not something that I looked at.  I wasn’t interested in their memories so much as I was interested in their experience so I would certainly encourage anybody who wanted to take my sample and track these men down in the published literature of the 1870s and 80s and 90s to see how they regarded the war experience.  I think that would be interesting; it’s not something that I did.  A lot of my men died in the hospital.  I was shocked at how many of them actually spent time in the hospital and
column4: as I think is the case for every Civil War historian and as I think you are working through the collections of letters and diaries
column5: there’s always that moment when the collection ends and you know that the soldier has died and that happened a lot
column6: you know they are writing these letters from hospitals “I think I’m getting better” when in fact they weren’t. The memory question is an interesting one and it certainly memory is certainly something I’ve been interested in over the years but it’s not something that I did with this project. What I really wanted to do was make a contribution to the soldier motivation literature that we have out there and in the same way that say McPherson did not look at their memories 30 or 40 years later or Chandra Manning didn’t look at those I didn’t either what I was really trying to do was fit my work into that literature.

column1: CWBR: Professor Noe
column2: thank you for joining me and discussing your most recent book
column3: Reluctant Rebels: The Confederates Who Joined the Army after 1861.

column1:
KN: Thank you; I enjoyed it.

God's Almost Chosen Peoples: A Religious History of the American Civil War
Rable
column2: George C.			"<h3>Interview with George C. Rable
column3: Professor and holder of the Summersell Chair in Southern History at the University of Alabama

column1: Interviewed by Nathan A. Buman
Click here for the review
Civil War Book Review (CWBR): I’m here today with George Rable
column2: author of God’s Almost Chosen Peoples: A Religious History of the American Civil War. Professor Rable
column3: thank you so much for joining me.

column1: George Rable (GR): My pleasure.
CWBR: You seem to give a very even-handed treatment of as many religions as possible in addition to looking at soldiers and the homefront
column2: men and women
column3: and white and black. How important was it for you to include this balance throughout your religious history of the Civil War?

column1: GR: Well my purpose was to write a comprehensive religious history of the war and I must admit
column2: as the project proceeded
column3: I was approached by a number of people asking me: “is my group going to be included” or “is my group going to be included
column4: ” so I was under a little bit of pressure even as I was working on the project but I thought if it was going to be a religious history of the war it should include as many groups as possible including non-believers.

column1: CWBR: So often we focus on what made the North and South dissimilar. Does a recognition of an “American” understanding of the war through religious avenues bring northerners and southerners together in this narrative; at the end of the day were they really very different religiously?
GR: I think religiously
column2: in some ways
column3: they were not very different.  They both used similar religious frameworks to interpret the causes
column4: course
column5: and consequences of the war. They both put a great deal of emphasis on providence and judgment to explain what was happening to them and what was happening to their enemies as far as that goes. So I think studying religion actually does somewhat narrow the differences between the two sides though obviously I think they would disagree with that.

column1: CWBR: I was especially struck by your discussion of some of the Mormons in the West too who wondered about the South believing that God fought on their side and
column2: at the same time the North did
column3: and if both sides were correct that would lead to total annihilation. How did they reconcile that fact?

column1: GR: well I’m not sure they saw that particular contradiction or at least most people didn't see it. Occasionally you'll get comments from people saying “well you know the other side is praying just as hard as we are
column2: that may present a problem.”  More commonly
column3: the assumption was that the Lord could not possibly allow their enemies to win
column4: or could not possibly allow their country to fall
column5: could not allow the Union to be destroyed
column6: could not allow the Confederacy to be subjugated.

column1: CWBR: You seem to suggest a new point of contention
column2: the split of northern Methodists and southern Methodists
column3: and the Baptists as well in leading to secession.  How did these splits help to affect the coming of the Civil War
column4: and looking forward then
column5: how did the North-South split of these denominations influence post-war churches? Was it a legitimate and long-lasting influence for them?

column1: GR: Well both Henry Clay and John C. Calhoun thought that the divisions of the churches were quite ominous in the 1840s leading up to the heighted sectional conflict of the Civil War itself and I think that they were right. Now I’m not sure one would argue that the split in the churches was a cause of the war; it was more a symptom of sectional tensions over slavery than anything else. And of course the Presbyterians had split earlier and they did not split primarily over slavery. But the fact that the churches are divided at the beginning of the war certainly does not lend any encouragement to sectional compromise. In fact
column2: one of the more interesting things I discovered in the research were the comments of Catholic editors who pointed out that “well this is what you get when you have a Protestant nation
column3: when you have schism and division.”  If you had had a Catholic nation there would have been no sectional conflict and Civil War; the church universal would have been able to take care of that particular problem.  Now in terms of long-lasting impact
column4: obviously these religious divisions persisted a long time among the Methodists
column5: the Presbyterians
column6: and of course the Baptists are still divided to this day.

column1: CWBR: For a nation that was so seemingly well-churched in the antebellum period
column2: why do we see the debauchery and casting away of church services in camp during the early months of the war?

column1: GR: Well they're heavily churched but also remember that probably only a minority of Americans were actually members of churches in part because the bar of church membership was pretty high at that time especially in some of the evangelical denominations. On a typical Sunday you might have many more people in attendance than actual members of the congregation so I think that’s a factor. Plus you’re talking about young men and these are not the most religious segment of the population
column2: usually in that time or in our own
column3: and plus these are young men removed from the influences of home and family and so it’s not surprising that under the stresses of camp life and battle and war in general you would find a great deal of what the people of the time would certainly describe as absolute debauchery. Although I suspect they exaggerated the degree of that from time to time so it’s interesting. I think many of the more devout soldiers are absolutely convinced that a lot of their comrades are heathenish and I sort of take them at their word.

column1: CWBR: As January of 1863 rolls around
column2: President Lincoln officially calls into order the Emancipation Proclamation.  I wonder how this altered the message delivered by the southern clergy and
column3: in turn
column4: the message being given by the northern clergy to northerners on the homefront?

column1: GR: Well let’s start with the northern clergy first. Many of the northern clergy had been pushing for such a measure all along. The northern clergy of course had been divided
column2: some of the more conservative denominations like the old school Presbyterians had not been especially eager to embrace abolition or emancipation
column3: but once Lincoln issues that final proclamation even the more conservative churches come around.  They naturally interpret the war itself and the fact that war has continued
column4: a lot of them interpreted
column5: as God’s judgment on slavery and once you cast off
column6: what one minister called the Jonah of slavery
column7: maybe the Lord would bless the nation with victory.  So again it’s interpreted as this sort of cycle of sin and judgment and then redemption.  The southern clergy continually embraced the institution of slavery during the war as the biblically sanctioned institution.  What changes for the southern clergy during the war is that the southern clergy become increasingly critical of the behavior of slaveholders.  In other words
column8: slavery is not sinful in and of itself
column9: in the fact that they scripturally sanctioned institution
column10: but they become increasingly critical of the behavior of slaveholders for breaking up slave families through sale
column11: for neglecting the religious instruction of the slaves
column12: for not teaching slaves to read so that they were unable to read the scriptures.  So there’s a kind of reform movement that takes place during the war; the southern clergy advocate reform of the institution of slavery.  I don’t think they see this reform as leading to abolition and it’s interesting
column13: however
column14: that this reform gets absolutely nowhere.  Not a single one of these measures even reaches the floor of the state legislature or the Confederate congress; there’s some consideration committee
column15: but that’s it.</p.

column1: CWBR: As the war progresses
column2: you speak increasingly of the revivalism that takes place throughout some of the southern armies but you suggest that it’s less common among the western armies in the Confederacy and I wonder is it too much of an oversimplification to wonder if this fact helps explain the consistency of the Army of Northern Virginia and the canonization of the Army of Northern Virginia in Civil War memory?

column1: GR: I think it certainly helps explain part of the canonization of the Army of Northern Virginia in the Civil War memory. Now if we could ask Stonewall Jackson that question
column2: I think he would certainly say the revivals would mark a blessing of God
column3: not only on the soldiers
column4: but on the army itself. And I think you could certainly argue that religion is quite important in sustaining the morale of armies but also keep in mind that there were revivals in the western armies as well they just came a little bit later and perhaps with less intensity and I think less organization.

column1: CWBR: What does the study of religion say about Confederate nationalism and also war support or war weariness in the North?
GR: Well I think religion is important part of Confederate nationalism. In fact
column2: you see such intense civil religion on both sides; you have presidents proclaiming days of fasting
column3: humiliation
column4: and prayer; presidents declaring official days of thanksgiving after victories; you have countless sermons preached and published on both sides on these special occasions as well as other occasions.  And I think religion is an important component of Confederate nationalism and it’s also an important component of American nationalism in general.  I don’t think the old thesis that somehow southerners were guilt-ridden and lost the will to fight and thought that God had turned against them really holds a great deal of water.  I think that there’s this persistent belief that God will somehow save them
column5: even at the last moment.</p.

column1: CWBR: Spending so much time with this topic
column2: would you maybe suggest that the war changed America’s outlook on religion or did their religious beliefs and spiritual outlook change their interpretation of the war as they were fighting it?

column1: GR: Well I think religious interpretation shaped their interpretation of the war
column2: there’s no question about that.  When you interpret battles in terms of divine favor and divine chastisement I don’t think there’s much doubt about that.  How much the war actually itself changed religious beliefs
column3: of course
column4: is a very difficult and complex question and I think a very debatable one.  Historians over the years have tended to emphasize a kind of disillusionment in the aftermath of war
column5: a disillusionment in civil religion
column6: though they focus most of their attention on intellectuals.  It seems to me that most Americans
column7: northerners and southerners in the aftermath of this war
column8: sought to rebuild their lives obviously in every way you can conceive and sought to rebuild their spiritual life as well and rebuild their church lives
column9: and were not so much interested any more in looking back at the issues of the war but they were simply interested in rebuilding their religious lives. And I must say I do not see the same amount of religious disillusionment in the aftermath of this war that some other historians have argued for.

column1: CWBR: Would you maybe suggest that the religious fervor and the rate at which Americans used religion to cope with the conflict
column2: is that unique to the American Civil War or might this simply be a traditional wartime response for any people?

column1: GR: I think the way religion was used during the Civil War
column2: if not unique
column3: was certainly more intense than any other war.  I know
column4: at one point in the book
column5: I do say that the American Civil War was the holiest war in American history and I certainly can’t think of any other war in which religion played such a large role.  Now obviously religion came into play in the American Revolution; religion comes into play in the War of 1812
column6: the Mexican War
column7: World War I
column8: World War II
column9: etc. but not nearly in the pervasive and all-encompassing sort of way as it did during the American Civil War.  I think it was a confluence of a lot of things
column10: first of all
column11: the Civil War itself was unique in the annals of American war and
column12: secondly
column13: it comes at a time of great religious expansion and fervor in America in general.

column1: CWBR: Lastly
column2: and we touched on some of this earlier
column3: I’ve always been struck by the influence of Lee and Jackson’s piety on post-Civil War memory. How did their religious beliefs influence their role in the Lost Cause mentality and why don’t we find more of a sense of the Union generals’ piety in post-Civil War memory?

column1: GR: Well I think their religion was very important in Lost Cause memory because Lee and Jackson become kind of the ultimate Christian martyrs. In fact Jackson’s death leads to all kinds of soul-searching about why the Lord had taken Jackson away from the Confederacy just when they needed him most. And many pious Confederates simply concluded that
column2: first of all
column3: they might not be able to understand why God had done that and
column4: secondly
column5: perhaps they had put too much faith in Jackson or
column6: as they put
column7: it “too much faith in an arm of flesh” and God was punishing them for that reason.  Now I suppose the flip answer to why religion has not been as important in the memory of northern soldiers is
column8: perhaps
column9: that the more pious northern soldiers were not nearly as successful in the battlefield as Lee and Jackson.  O. O. Howard who probably
column10: in some ways
column11: is the ultimate Christian soldier in the North had a very rocky career in the eastern theater and a somewhat more successful career in the western theater.  George McClellan
column12: I must say somewhat to my surprise
column13: was remarkably religious as well and wrote things that could have easily been written by Robert E. Lee.  General Rosecrans was a very devout Catholic who loved to stay up late into the night discussing theology with various people including James Garfield
column14: the future president of the United States.  So I think there are certainly Christian generals on the northern side as well
column15: but they just weren’t as successful as lee and Jackson were.

column1: CWBR: Professor Rable
column2: thank you so much for joining me and taking the time to discuss your recent book
column3: God’s Almost Chosen Peoples: A Religious History of the American Civil War.

column1:
GR: It’s been my pleasure.

" Buman
column2: Nathan Winter 2011 2011-02-01 Interview University of North Carolina Press "" ""

column1:
4827 978-0-8078-3436-7 $35.00 CWBR AUTHOR INTERVEW:
Creating a Confederate Kentucky: the Lost Cause and Civil War Memory in a Border State Marshall
column2: Anne			"<h3>Interview with Anne Marshall
column3: Assistant Professor of History at Mississippi State University

column1: Interviewed by Nathan Buman
Click here for the review
Civil War Book Review (CWBR): Today
column2: Civil War Book Review is pleased to talk with Anne Marshall
column3: author of a brand-new work
column4: Creating a Confederate Kentucky: The Lost Cause and Civil War Memory in a Border State. Professor Marshall
column5: thank you for joining me this afternoon.

column1: Anne Marshall (AM): Well thank you so much for having me.
CWBR: What inspired you to look at the Civil War and Civil War memory and how did you come to choose Kentucky as the focus for your study?

AM: Well I really chose Kentucky because it sort of chose me I guess. I grew up in Kentucky; I had always sort of noticed as I was growing up that there was some real sort of dissonance between the sort of standard history of the state and its Civil War experience that I learned in fourth grade Kentucky history. And then the sort of public commemoration that I saw all around me
column2: whether in historical markers or monuments or sort of the public dialog about the war and so when I got to graduate school this is right around the time when there was just a lot of great work about historical memory and the Civil War coming out and this was right when David Blight’s book came out and I just thought
column3: you know
column4: this would be a really great angle at which to study the question of why Kentucky supposedly succeeded after the Civil War and that's really how I came to the topic.

column1: CWBR: James McPherson has written on the motivations of soldiers and
column2: more recently
column3: in light of important books by Chandra Manning and Gary Gallagher
column4: what can your analysis of wartime Kentucky say about why soldiers fought? Did the Emancipation Proclamation shift the ways in which Confederate and Unionist soldiers and residents in Kentucky viewed the conflict?

column1: AM: Yes
column2: it definitely did and I think in a way different from that which these scholars sort of point to
column3: I think that the general consensus (at least the question that they sort of hold up) is whether or not
column4: and to what extent
column5: the Emancipation Proclamation served as a real motivation for northern troops who had been fighting to preserve the union.  And for Kentuckians who were (white Kentuckians at least) who were fighting to preserve the union the Emancipation Proclamation really had a negative effect.  This was certainly not what some Union troops that were from Kentucky were fighting for and
column6: in fact
column7: many of them became incredibly disenchanted with the war effort; they had sort of seen the writing on the wall
column8: of course
column9: as Lincoln had been offering compensated emancipation to Kentucky before he issued the Emancipation Proclamation.  So they sort of understood what was happening and then
column10: of course
column11: Kentucky was exempt from that proclamation but they were very dismayed because for them turning the war for union into a war to end slavery was antithetical to the entire reason they had decided to fight for the union to begin with
column12: and I do think that another important difference between Kentucky (white Kentucky) and its rational for fighting
column13: in terms of nationalism
column14: I think it’s important to consider how many Kentuckians didn’t fight.  About 71% of white Kentuckians decided not to fight.  Many
column15: many Kentuckians evaded Lincoln’s draft so really it’s not so much in many ways a question of I think Kentucky’s experience shows that for many loyal citizens that loyalty didn’t necessarily translate into a commitment to actually don a uniform and go off and fight.

column1: CWBR: That's interesting and I wonder shifting towards the years after the civil war. I wonder if the violence and lawlessness during 1865-1885 if that makes Kentucky unique or were these problems and challenge did they present a problem for residents in federally-reconstructed states as well? What might Kentucky’s experience say about the effectiveness of Federal forces in southern states?
AM: I think that’s a great question because I think that as we know the South was a very violent place after the Civil War
column2: but I think with states like Kentucky
column3: and also Missouri to even greater extent
column4: tell us is that the border states were particularly violent and I think that this was an effect of the kind of fighting that had been so prevalent: the kind of guerrilla conflict
column5: if you will
column6: that had been so prevalent in the state during the Civil War.  And also the fact that they weren’t federally constructed
column7: as you say. They really didn’t have any
column8: there wasn’t this official military occupation in most places. There was really no apparatus outside of the state government to quell the violence in these states and so I think that it does point to the fact that in other southern states certainly federal forces had an effect in terms of quelling violence.

column1: CWBR: well you mentioned earlier the unionists that were able to keep their state out of the confederacy and who fought for the union army in times. I wonder why did former Unionists
column2: who successfully kept the state out of the Confederacy during the war
column3: why did they fail to garner enough support to combat the conservative violent factions that you spoke about just a second ago in the post-bellum period?

column1: AM: Yeah well that’s another great question and what happened was a lot of these former Unionists were the conservatives. They weren’t necessarily these leaders
column2: former Unionist leaders who were able to use their pulls to keep Kentucky out of the Confederacy in the Union
column3: weren’t necessarily the ones condoning the violence.  And in many cases they deplored the violence; they were also conservative and I think that after the war
column4: and certainly the fact that the war had turned from a war of union into a war of emancipation
column5: affected their conservative terms after the war and there’s no question that
column6: in spite of the fact that many of them did deplore the means (the violent means) that the violence was an effective way of bringing about political ends that really suited them.  And on the ground the violence really sort of served their interest of their constituency
column7: at least as far as their constituencies saw this
column8: and that this violence against African Americans was used by lower-class whites to maintain their ideas about white supremacy.  And also their access to labor
column9: they were using violence to keep African Americans away from the polls but also away from jobs
column10: so really these conservatives
column11: it’s not that they condoned the violence
column12: but they certainly were aware of the fact that
column13: in some ways
column14: the violence served their interests and I think that that made them sort of politically ineffectual to some extent when it came to quelling the violence.  Although
column15: there were certainly calls from
column16: not only former Unionists
column17: but former Confederates
column18: especially people like Henry Watterson who was the editor of the Louisville Courier
column19: journalists at that time to crack down on the violence.

column1: CWBR: Shifting to one of the key phrases in the title of the book the lost cause. Some scholars have looked at this stating that perhaps the strength of the Lost Cause in New Orleans resulted from their relatively early and easy falling to Federal forces and inherit guilt in the city that helped them to embrace Confederate celebrations after the war. How does the experience in Kentucky compare to a place like New Orleans or perhaps other areas that failed to become Confederate strongholds during the war like Unionist Tennessee?
AM: Yes
column2: well I think that it’s
column3: rather than focusing on the experiences of those places during the war
column4: it’s interesting to sort of see an effect that historians cite the guilt factor in New Orleans is a little bit like the fact that they tend to focus on the political crack-down under martial law and the federal forces in Kentucky late in the war as sort of a factor of turning Kentuckians against the Union once and for all in the end.  And this
column5: according to a lot of scholars of Kentucky
column6: was the spring board for the Lost Cause
column7: but I think what’s interesting in all of these case whether we look at postwar Kentucky
column8: postwar New Orleans
column9: postwar East Tennessee
column10: is the fact that no matter what the particular situation during the war
column11: that southerners of all political stripes could really find a lot in the Lost Cause that suited their modern (their contemporary) political imperative during the postwar era.  I really think that there really probably is some truth to the idea of guilt or the idea of (in Kentucky) of the poor treatment at the hands of the federal officials during the war.  But what really makes the Lost Cause resonate for so long in these places is that it really carries with it a set of values in the postwar era that suits people all over the South and in the North in some places as well.  So I think that that’s really where I would place the power of the Lost Cause and reason that southerners
column12: no matter what their wartime experience was or their sentiments were
column13: can really sort of grab on to it in the postwar era.

column1: CWBR: earlier you mentioned the importance of David Blight in sort of setting the foundation in the way you looked at the post bellum period when you began your studies. Thinking about the recent scholarship of David Blight and Heather Cox Richardson and the ways in which they examine how whites reconciled nationally by pushing blacks to the margins
column2: might Kentucky be indicative of a broader trend and how does your study illustrate reconciliation in a national context?

column1: AM: Yes
column2: I think that one of the points that I
column3: from the beginning of this project
column4: saw as a both being and engaging with those notions that David Blight and Heather Cox Richardson put out there that are very important in telling the story in terms of narrative and reconciliation and having to push.  In the case of David Blight
column5: he argues that essentially northern whites relegated this
column6: sort of emancipation narrative as he calls it
column7: to the dust bin in order to reconcile with southern whites.  And I think that this is a really resonant argument but one thing that I found in Kentucky is that
column8: if you look at it and you look at what the Civil War soldiers were saying the during the war and you look at what the Civil War meant for all of these pro-slavery Unionists
column9: what becomes apparent is that this emancipationist narrative was really never viable to begin with.  So in essence
column10: I guess
column11: that means that what Kentucky can show us is that some Unionists never pushed African Americans to the margin after the war because they had always pushed them to the margin; they were never part of that vision of what the Civil War meant except for the fact that that meant the end of slavery and that was a bad thing.  So I think that that really crippled white unionist memory in Kentucky for a long time and so I do think that that this really does illustrate
column12: in terms of reconciliation
column13: because I think that it shows that there are lots of narratives out there and that in many ways white Kentuckians show this reconciliation happening much more quickly than it does nationally
column14: which we tend to focus on national reconciliation happening in the 1890s
column15: but I think in Kentucky's case whites reconciled in Kentucky much
column16: much earlier over these questions of race.

column1: CWBR: That’s really interesting and in terms of reconciliation it’s my understanding from reading your book that GAR reunions play a large role in the reconciliation and I wonder
column2: do you have any sense if African Americans had been incorporated into northern Grand Army of the Republic reunions and encampments before the Louisville meeting in 1895 or were the challenges that organizers faced to incorporate African-American veterans more commonplace?

column1: AM: Yes
column2: actually African Americans had been regular part of GAR meetings in may northern chapters.  They were integrated so African Americans and whites joined alike
column3: they met alike
column4: they remembered the war in some common ways and actually there’s a great book out about this
column5: Barbara Gannon’s
column6: The Won Cause where she actually refutes some of what David Blight argues as well in terms of war memories and she uses the GAR membership and the integrated GAR membership to really show this. And so I think
column7: in that sense
column8: Louisville was presented a sort of new challenge: how were these northern
column9: integrated chapters going to come in as equals; they come to the South and suddenly African Americans and white members were supposed to be segregated and have different accommodations and sit in separate places and really
column10: in that sense
column11: the Louisville experience was different.

column1: CWBR: What did the southern literature during the period
column2: specifically Annie Fellows Johnston who sold millions of copies of The Little Colonel (later becoming a movie)
column3: what did that do for the image of the South in a national context
column4: as we are looking at southern literature and sort of the popularity of things like gone with the wind and what not in popular culture in giving an impression of southern culture?

column1: AM: Yes
column2: well I would say that the Little Colonel series had a similar effect to the works of Joel Chandler Harris or Thomas Nelson Page in that it really sort of spun these tales even though the Little Colonel was set in the New South
column3: it was actually set at the turn of the century
column4: which is when Annie Fellows Johnston was writing.  It really evoked a sort of Old South gentility; it gave northerners a way to sort of look at the South and the post-Civil War South which carried according to Annie Fellows Johnston a lot of the same conventions in terms of that the Old South had carried
column5: for example
column6: the African-American characters were not slaves but they were devoted servants
column7: still
column8: who had chosen to remain with their former owners because they were well-treated and happy.  And there was a lot this air of the Old South
column9: that was sort of positioned in the New South and that gave northerners (people all over the world as a matter of fact) a way to look at the South with this sort of sense of nostalgia
column10: a sense that sort of gave it a comforting elegant gentile setting and a world that was increasingly tumultuous. This was a time of increasing industrialization and increasing immigration and a lot of white Americans all over the nation were really sort of unsure about what was happening to their increasingly urbanized world. And so being able to go and read these books that evoked this sense of Old South/New South gentility was sort of a form of escapism that was really very appealing to many Americans.

column1: CWBR: I wonder
column2: how does looking at the ways in which Kentucky emerged from the war inform or shape our understanding of current events in a state like Kentucky versus other states like South Carolina
column3: Alabama
column4: or Pennsylvania?

column1: AM: Yes
column2: well I’m not sure that we can sort of trace a direct lineage in terms of a sort of causes and effects of Kentucky’s war experiences and its sort of contemporary realities of Kentucky.  But I certainly think if we're thinking about identity which is something I wrote a lot about in this book
column3: not only just looking at the Civil War narrative that that came out of Kentucky's Civil War experience in the aftermath
column4: but I was also looking at
column5: in a general the way
column6: that these Civil War narratives sort of created an identity for the state as a whole.  And I certainly think that the way that Kentucky's identity developed after the war
column7: the things that made it seem like a former Confederate state have stuck with it in a lot of different ways
column8: it still has this reputation for being sort of simultaneously poor but also having a sort of patina of wealth to it which we can associate with the Old South.  Some of what Annie Fellows Johnston was trying to create in her books
column9: for example
column10: and it still has a reputation for being a sort of violent state
column11: so I think that there are still some elements there that are.  Certainly the racism that existed in postwar Kentucky that informed a lot of this identity is still there; I’m not sure that it’s any greater of an extent in Kentucky than it is in certainly in other southern places
column12: and perhaps even in northern places today
column13: but there’s still elements of that there so I think
column14: in those ways
column15: some of this identity is still sticking with Kentucky.

column1: CWBR: Well it’s interesting you mention identity and I have to ask why has it taken so long to incorporate African Americans and even Abraham Lincoln into the historical analysis of the Civil War in Kentucky and turning to the future and the present as well how has the Civil War Sesquicentennial celebration encouraged engaging and incorporating groups like these groups?

AM: Well I think in terms of African Americans I think Kentucky is sort of where a lot of other southern and formerly Confederate states are on this sort of public acknowledgement of African-American history in general. But also the history of slavery
column2: the history of slavery’s influence on Kentucky's Civil War experience
column3: and also the impact that African Americans have had on Kentucky's Civil War experience in that its sort of come in the aftermath of the Civil Rights Movement where people were connecting present fights for African-American rights in the 1960s and on into the 1970s with the deprivation of those rights that had come out of the aftermath of slavery.  And then had the promise of those rights had not been fulfilled in the Reconstruction era
column4: I think that in this sense it’s sort of similar to the national narrative and it’s just really been in the last 20 or 25 years or so that really African-American groups have really been at the forefront of trying to gain recognition for their role in the state’s history and to insert their experiences into the Civil War narrative of the state’s history.  And the Lincoln question is really interesting because he was of course a Kentuckian and was hated in his home state for so long
column5: getting less than 2% of the popular vote in 1860
column6: and then he really didn’t gain any popularity among the states whites after the war
column7: so what’s really been interesting of course that the Lincoln bicentennial
column8: which those events were carried out mostly in 2009
column9: and the state sort of did a whole 180 on this one and embraced Abraham Lincoln and had a couple of years of celebrations really where they focused on every aspect no matter how small every connection that Lincoln had in the state.  And I think that that’s really also a realization of Lincoln’s legacy and buying into this finally saying Kentucky is buying into this David Blight emancipationist narrative 150 years later to I think that the sesquicentennial was sort of
column10: in essence
column11: took off the tone for the sesquicentennial remembrance have come out of the Lincoln bicentennial in the sense that
column12: with the sort of events the state is highlighting this year
column13: they are trying to sell a broader story of the Civil War that incorporates Confederates
column14: white Unionists
column15: African Americans so I think that this sort of evolution of historical memory and public history as well.

column1: CWBR: Professor Marshall
column2: thank you so much for joining us this afternoon and discussing your new book
column3: Creating a Confederate Kentucky: The Lost Cause and Civil War Memory in a Border State.

column1:
AM: Well thank you so much for having me.

" Buman
column2: Nathan Spring 2011 2011-05-01 Interview University of North Carolina Press "" ""

column1:
4900 978-0-674-04562-0 $27.95 CWBR AUTHOR INTERVIEW:
The Union War Gallagher
column2: Gary			"<h3>Interview with Dr. Gary Gallagher
column3: John L. Nau III Professor of History at the University of Virginia

column1: Interviewed by Nathan Buman
Click here for the review
Civil War Book Review (CWBR): Today
column2: I’m delighted to be joined by Gary Gallagher who is John L. Nau III Professor of History at the University of Virginia to discuss his most recent book The Union War. Professor Gallagher
column3: thank you for talking with us today.

column1: Gary Gallagher (GG): Thanks for inviting me.

CWBR: You mention in the acknowledgements that you came up with the idea for this book ten years ago; how did you decide to approach this question and look at a study of the Civil War through the concept of Union?
GG: I began talking about the book ten years ago with Joyce Seltzer
column2: who is the editor I worked with at Harvard on an earlier book
column3: The Confederate War. But I’ve really been thinking about this for much longer than that. I’ve been thinking about it because I’ve found over the years perhaps the most difficult thing to explain to students
column4: or groups of adults to whom I speak about the war
column5: is why the loyal citizenry thought Union was worth fighting for.  It’s a very hard concept for many modern Americans to come to terms with: why would someone from Vermont who is under no direct threat
column6: either their property or their system of local government
column7: from the Confederates
column8: why would they think it was worthwhile to put on a uniform and risk their lives to save the Union?  Union just doesn’t mean anything to us now
column9: and it’s very hard to explain that to modern audiences.

column1: CWBR: I was especially intrigued by your discussion of language and vocabulary
column2: particularly when you discuss how the word “Union” has essentially dropped from our current vocabulary but that it dominated the Civil War and antebellum period. Why do you suppose that is the case? What did Union truly mean to the wartime generation of soldiers and civilians?

column1: GG: I do think Union has gone out of our vocabulary
column2: literally gone out of our vocabulary in terms of its mid-nineteenth-century meaning.  Union has a labor connation now; it has no tie to the way that it was used in the mid-nineteenth century.  In the mid-nineteenth century
column3: Union and nation and country and United States were deployed as synonyms frequently; they’re interchangeable in a lot of the writings that you see in the mid-nineteenth century.  I think that part of the problem now is that Union
column4: among that cluster of words
column5: simply has dropped out. Now we think of nation
column6: or we think of country.  And we take the nation for granted; we take all of the things for granted that were much more fraught in the mid-nineteenth century. We can’t imagine an internal threat to the United States of the sort that galvanized the loyal citizenry between 1861 and 1865.  Union is just a word that no longer has any meaning in that regard
column7: and if we don’t have a sense of what that word means . . . I think Elizabeth Varon’s book from a couple of years ago
column8: Disunion
column9: helps get at the meaning of the word.  She talks about how important the word “disunion” was and
column10: of course
column11: disunion can only be an important word if Union is an even more important one.  Why was the idea of disunion so troubling to so many people?  Well
column12: it’s because Union meant so much
column13: and I think it meant a cluster of things.  It meant the legacy of the founding generation
column14: the handiwork of the Philadelphia Convention
column15: the small “R” republican form of government
column16: the small “D” form of democracy; it meant a nation where common people had a voice in their own government--of course
column17: we’re talking in a mid-nineteenth-century context
column18: so that is to say white men had a voice in their government--and also had the ability to rise economically.  Lincoln spoke to this beautifully
column19: in many ways during the war
column20: but the really interesting and important thing to me is Lincoln is simply saying the same kinds of things--he says them better--but he is saying the same kinds of things that untold people are saying.  This place is unique in the Western World
column21: the rest of the Western World is going in the wrong direction
column22: advocates of Union believe.  They believe the failed revolutions of the 1840s show that the European nations were falling even more into the embrace of oligarchy and aristocracy and monarchy. In an American context
column23: the slaveholding southerners represented oligarchs and aristocrats; unionists in the free states deploy those words constantly in referring to those who led the secession movement.  Everything they stood for
column24: slaveholding oligarchs
column25: was inimical to the work and promise of what the Founding Fathers had done from the perspective of those who really took Union seriously.  They also believed that Union had meaning beyond the United States.  It’s important for all of those reasons within the United States but beyond that
column26: it’s important because
column27: they would argue
column28: that democracy had not at all been established in the Western World and if it fails here
column29: it might be snuffed out entirely.  When Lincoln talks about the last
column31: that’s what he is talking about
column32: but lots of other people used language very similar to that. So it has a Trans-Atlantic meaning
column33: and it also has a meaning for those who lived in the United States: a profound meaning
column34: something that would cause people to risk their lives.

column1: CWBR: You admit
column2: up front
column3: the challenges that any scholar must overcome when looking at the motivations of the common soldier and/or the common population during wartime
column4: especially given the tremendous amount of letters written during the American Civil War.  What sorts of obstacles did you face in trying to provide a broad enough scope to achieve a representation of the ways in which soldiers and civilians
column5: alike looked at Union and the Civil War?

column1: GG: The key is
column2: there’s so much evidence from the Civil War that you can argue anything.  You can take almost any position and argue it
column3: and you can find evidence that supports what you want to argue.  I don’t just look at soldiers in this book
column4: but common soldier testimony is so voluminous that I think the only way to come at it is to read as much as you can with the understanding that no scholar can read anything but the tiniest percentage. We’re talking about millions and millions of letters that the soldiers wrote
column5: any scholar who reads 20 or 25
column6: 000 of them has done heroic labor in research.  But those 25
column7: 000 letters are statistically insignificant
column8: and they cannot
column9: in any way
column10: be considered a real representative sample of soldiers’ sentiments.  So I think it’s important to place different kinds of evidence in conversation with one another.  Read as much as you can
column11: pick out the themes in the letters that you’ve read
column12: and then compare those to what you find elsewhere. There are other types of evidence you can use. In The Union War
column13: I used patriotic covers
column14: newspapers
column15: song lyrics
column16: and other things. I believe historians should use as many different kinds of evidence as possible--and when you have the array of different kinds of evidence
column17: see if themes cross over from one kind to another.  That’s the way I think we have to come at this. Everything we do is imperfect; there’s just no way to get a perfect reading of what was going on.  But when I think that you look at an array of evidence
column18: Union stands out. This includes the writings of Abraham Lincoln
column19: who had as good a sense of what motivated the loyal population as anyone. He was an incredibly perceptive politician
column20: and his public statements and statements designed to be leaked to the public
column21: so to speak
column22: first and last
column23: spoke of a war for Union.  He says it in the beginning; he says it in his message to Congress after the 1864 Presidential Election. In the latter
column24: he says
column25: in every great war--I’m paraphrasing him--a people have to have one overriding goal and in this great war of ours
column26: its Union.  Much of what he is talking about in that statement is a plea to pass the Thirteenth Amendment.  But in calling for that
column27: he specifically says the Thirteenth Amendment—emancipation
column28: killing slavery--will be one of the tools to help achieve the overriding goal of Union.  Even at that late stage of the war
column30: for most of the loyal citizenry
column31: it’s still about Union.    Most of them had embraced emancipation by that time
column32: not for the reasons we would want them to
column33: not as a great moral crusade
column34: but because they knew that emancipation would help to beat the Rebels
column35: would punish the slaveholding oligarchs who caused all of the problems in the first place
column36: and would create a better Union
column38: a Union that didn’t have the poisonous issue of slavery sort of lurking in the national political scene to rise up and cause a problem such as that in the Secession Winter of 1860-61.

column1: CWBR: If northerners were fighting for Union
column2: does that mean southerners were fighting primarily for disunion and not states’ rights or slavery?

column1: GG: I think it’s very important to separate the issues that brought secession and what motivated people in the Confederacy during the war. Those are two related issues
column2: but they’re not the same thing.  Secession came because the cotton South believed that Abraham Lincoln’s election
column3: the election of a Republican
column4: posed a sufficient threat to the long-term stability of slavery to make secession a smart choice.  It’s all about slavery (secession is)
column5: absolutely
column6: it’s all about slavery.  You take slavery out of the picture in 1860
column7: and you don’t get secession. I see no way for secession without slavery.  I don’t think there can be any question about that
column8: and I don’t think that any serious scholar does question that.  The fact that the Republicans had a plank in their platform that said they would leave slavery alone wherever it existed struck slaveholders as dishonest.  They knew that both Lincoln and Seward
column9: the two most famous Republicans at that stage
column10: had said
column11: in very well-known speeches from 1858
column12: that the nation couldn’t exist half-slave and half-free.  Slaveholders knew that both Lincoln and Seward wanted the nation to be all-free
column13: and therefore they just didn’t trust this idea that Republicans wouldn’t strike at slavery wherever it was
column14: never mind that they were going to block it in the territories.  So secession is all about slavery.  Once you get secession
column15: once you get the cascading crises in the wake of that first round of seceding states
column16: then other factors do come into play.  And I think motivations for actually supporting the Confederacy and going into the Confederate army were various
column17: just as they were with the United States soldiers.  But I think protecting home ground
column18: not being dictated to by the United States
column19: those are very important. But Confederates talked
column20: all the time
column21: about preserving their way of life
column22: preserving their country
column23: preserving their homes
column24: and all of those things are tied
column25: inextricably
column26: to the fact that they lived in a slaveholding society
column27: in a society that gave them racial control over 3.5 million black people.  Slavery is important any way you look at this
column28: but I think different kinds of motivations come into play in terms of what why soldiers went into the army for the Confederacy
column29: for example.  But we have to take as a base line that the vast majority--you can’t say everybody because with millions of people there are always outliers--the vast majority of the white south
column30: whether or not they owned slaves
column31: had a profound interest in slavery as a means of race control
column32: in addition to slavery as a means of economic control in some ways.

column1: CWBR: During Grant’s campaign
column2: how did many northerners justify going through the trial of so many casualties? It seems almost as if Grant gets a pass for the tremendous casualties. Was it the promise of a stronger Union?

column1: GG: He didn’t get a pass from all citizens in the North. A lot of the Democratic newspapers
column2: especially the Copperhead kind of newspapers such as The Old Guard
column3: were very hard on Grant. Some of them began to call him a butcher; that’s mainly an epithet that was leveled against him by Confederate newspapers but some of the newspapers in the United States did so as well. I think it was a measure of the devotion to Union that the citizenry was willing to put up with that level of loss in the spring and summer of 1864
column4: although it was a close thing in the summer.  We always need to remind ourselves that United States victory was not pre-ordained.  The United States could have lost the war.  I think that more than once the Confederacy came close to meeting the test it needed to meet for success. The Confederacy had an easier test than the United States did.  All the Confederacy had to do—and Lee understood this very well--was persuade the civilian population of the United States that it wasn’t worth the cost. I think Overland Campaign pushed a significant part of the civilian population close to that point in the summer of 1864
column5: from late June and through July and into August.  I think it was--of course this isn’t new with me--Sherman in Atlanta and Sheridan in the Shenandoah Valley that turned things around and re-elected Lincoln and the Republicans who
column6: of course
column7: had not run as Republicans in 1864.  They ran as the Union Party
column8: which is another very clear indication of how important that concept was.  Let’s don’t even call ourselves Republicans
column9: they said
column10: we’ll bring in the greatest possible support if we call ourselves the Union Party.  It was close in the summer of 1864.  Grant did get some criticism; the person who was largely immune from criticism and a person who was a much bloodier general than Grant
column11: first to last
column12: was Lee.  That’s one of the interesting topics of the war.  We’re off-subject a bit
column13: but Lee essentially was given a pass by the people of the Confederacy. That’s always fascinated me.

column1: CWBR: You seem to be arguing for a middle ground when you discuss the role that the Union Army played in emancipation
column2: a coming together of opposing traditions (military and social). How important is an understanding of both perspectives in the process of emancipation and the execution of the war?

column1: GG: There are several factors that have to be in any consideration of the process of emancipation
column2: and it was a process.  Lincoln has to be in it; Lincoln’s absolutely one of the crucial factors.  Congress is very important
column3: beginning with the first Confiscation Act in the summer of 1861 and moving through all of that legislation in the spring and summer of 1862.  And
column4: of course
column5: the actions of hundreds of thousands of enslaved people in the Confederacy are very important
column6: the notion of self-emancipation that W.E.B. Dubois advanced in the mid-1930s and which has been picked up by any number of historians beginning in the late 1960s and coming down
column7: most recently
column8: through Steven Hahn and others now.  All of those are very important elements of the process
column9: but my argument is the one that gets left out is the role of the United States Army.  If you take the United States Army out of the equation
column10: you don’t get emancipation no matter what any of those other people want; it doesn’t matter.  If the United States Army doesn’t go somewhere
