column11: emancipation doesn’t go there either. It’s fascinating to look at the geography of emancipation in the Confederacy during the war.  Where are the roughly half-million enslaved people who actually achieved freedom during the war?  And I take this number from Ira Berlin’s project at Maryland
column12: which I think is the gold standard in that regard; it’s about a half a million
column13: about one in seven.  One in seven
column14: where are they?  They’re where the United States Army went and stayed for a significant period of time: up and down the Mississippi River
column15: the Lower Peninsula in Virginia
column16: in significant parts of Tennessee
column17: that’s where emancipation comes.  It comes where the army goes.  What is the degree of emancipation in Texas?  Virtually zero; the United States Army doesn’t get there
column18: so it doesn’t matter how much an enslaved person wants to be free.  In Texas
column19: there’s no chance because the army doesn’t come.  So I just think it’s very important to put the army
column20: not only in the picture
column21: but put the army very prominently in the picture.  And also
column22: to make the point that it doesn’t even matter whether the soldiers in the army want emancipation to come or not.  A lot of them do; by the end of the war
column23: I think most of them did
column24: though again
column25: not for the reasons we would want but they still did.  But even somebody who isn’t really for emancipation
column26: an army commander who’s not really for emancipation--Sherman would be a good example of that--still acts as a destructive agent regarding slavery as he moves his army through central Georgia or wherever he’s going. The army is absolutely critical to the process of emancipation.

column1: CWBR: Stephanie McCurry’s most recent book suggests taking the slaves seriously in the ways in which they negotiated freedom
column2: that they had to navigate a difficult environment when the Union army came marching through the Confederate countryside. How might your findings complement or contradict the concept of the slave as an active player in emancipation?

column1: GG: I don’t contradict it at all. I think that enslaved people did play an active role when they were in a situation where they could. I’ll just come back to my earlier point; the situation has to be one where there is the possibility of freedom
column2: and that possibility of freedom lies in the presence of a United States military force near enough at hand to make the decision for freedom one that was attainable.  It might still be very difficult to get to Union lines
column3: it often was
column4: but they had to be close enough to get there.  So I see no inherent contradiction at all between the idea of an enslaved people working hard to achieve their own emancipation and the fact that the United States Army was crucial in allowing them to do so.  I see no contradiction there; it’s just that I would argue that it doesn’t matter how much an enslaved person wants to be free
column5: they cannot be free within the context of the Civil War unless the conditions are appropriate and the crucial factor is: has the United States Army come close enough to make it possible?

column1: CWBR: David Blight has become the staple for looking at postbellum reconciliation. Does recognition of slavery and its abolition as major war motivations or war goals hold northern and southern whites accountable for rebuilding their postbellum society?
GG: Well
column2: I think reconciliation has been exaggerated; I don’t think most people were reconciled after the Civil War.  I think there’s a difference between reconciliation and reunion
column3: and there’s an interesting study that will be coming out soon by Caroline Janney. She’s writing a book on the memory of the war that is going to deal with these themes
column4: and distinguishing between reunion and reconciliation is one of her points.  I think she’s exactly right. Of course reunion began at Appomattox; the two sections are put back together into the nation. But true reconciliation--the kind of reconciliation where the opposing parties would say it doesn’t really matter who was right or wrong
column5: let’s just talk about how brave we all were together
column6: and let’s airbrush black people out of the picture
column7: and just have a white drama of triumph--I don’t think that ever really happened.  I think it happened in key places
column8: sort of showcase places
column9: but reconciliation for Union veterans was--and Grant is a perfect example of this--their version of reconciliation was: we were right
column10: you were wrong
column11: and now we welcome you back on those terms.  That’s not really reconciliation of the sort that’s often put forward.  I think the animosities were profound
column12: and I don’t think they ever went away for the wartime generation.  And the mass of white veterans did not airbrush emancipation out of the picture. That doesn’t mean they held the kind of racial views we would want them to hold
column13: but they didn’t airbrush emancipation out.  There’s a wealth of evidence that supports this point.  In the speeches at Union monument dedications--the ones at Gettysburg are the easiest ones to get to—the speakers talk about Union the most but also talk a lot about emancipation.  Emancipation was a good thing; emancipation hurt the slaveholding class
column14: it removed this future threat to the republic
column15: it made a better republic possible.  I don’t subscribe to the idea that there’s this great collective amnesia that swept over white people North and South in terms of which side was right and which side was wrong.  I don’t think most Confederates would have ever said that they were wrong; they weren’t happy that they lost and they weren’t happy that slavery was gone but they accepted reality.  And the United States veterans who won the war would never have said that it didn’t matter whether you fought for Union or fought for the Confederacy.  For Union veterans
column16: they had been right and they were willing to reconcile on those terms: “You ex-Rebels were wrong and we defeated you
column17: now you can now come back into the Union.

column1: CWBR: During an 1889 battlefield dedication at Gettysburg
column2: Joshua Chamberlain says “our thoughts were not then of States as States
column3: but of the States united
column4: ---of that union and oneness in which the People of the United States lived and moved and had their being…[T]he cause for which we fought was higher; our thought was wider…What is lost is slavery of men and supremacy of States.” Was the Union the ultimate contribution of the wartime generation to the future of the United States?

column1: GG: I think the wartime generation would have absolutely said yes
column2: and they would have said that it was an improved Union because it no longer had slavery in it and therefore did not have a powerful oligarchic class of slaveholders.  I absolutely think they would have said that the primary outcome of this war was Union.  Emancipation is also extremely important
column3: they would have said
column4: for those reasons
column5: because it helps the Union.  It makes the Union stronger; it protects the Union going forward. I think that Chamberlain gets at that.  Chamberlain certainly mentions emancipation
column6: and he would have been much closer than most Union soldiers to the position that we
column7: in the twenty first century
column8: would want the Union soldiers to have regarding emancipation.  But it is about the Union; you have to save the Union first. To repeat myself
column9: they would have also said it’s a better Union.  War made a better Union.  It’s a better Union because that ticking time bomb of slavery has been excised.  So
column10: for most of the loyal citizenry
column11: they had taken care of all of the business at the end of the war.  They had saved the Union
column12: and with the Thirteenth Amendment they had gotten rid of slavery.  The only reason they went beyond those things was because in the war’s immediate aftermath former Confederates did not seem to understand they had been defeated. I don’t think there’s any great lost moment in Reconstruction
column13: I absolutely do not.  The Fourteenth Amendment was
column14: in the mid-nineteenth-century perspective
column15: mainly designed to punish slaveholders again; that’s what loyal citizens would have said.  Even the Fifteenth Amendment represented a way to punish the former slaveholding oligarchs.  The only reason we got to those two amendments was because the white South behaved so badly
column16: with a big assist from Andrew Johnson
column17: in the wake of Appomattox.  I think that many of the loyal citizens said: wait a minute; they’re not acting like they lost the war.  They’re acting like they didn’t lose the war!  They were offended by that
column18: and so they went beyond the Thirteenth Amendment.

column1: CWBR: Professor Gallagher
column2: thank you for taking the time to discuss The Union War with us.

column1:
GG: You’re certainly welcome.

" Summer 2011 2011-08-01 Interview Harvard University Press "" ""

5122 978-0-7006-1797-5 $39.95 CWBR AUTHOR INTERVIEW:
A Generation at War: The Civil War Era in a Northern Community Etcheson
column2: Nicole			"<h3>Interview with Nicole Etcheson
column3: Alexander M. Bracken Professor of History at Ball State University

column1: Civil War Book Review would like to congratulate Nicole Etcheson on winning the 2012 Avery O. Craven Award for this title
column2: given by The Organization of American Historians
column3: for most original book on the coming of the Civil War
column4: the Civil War years
column5: or the Era of Reconstruction
column6: with the exception of works of purely military history.

column1: Interviewed by Nathan Buman
Click here for the review
Civil War Book Review (CWBR): Today
column2: we are pleased to speak with Professor Nichole Etcheson
column3: the Alexander M. Bracken Professor of History at Ball State University and author of A Generation of War: The Civil War Era in a Northern Community. Professor Etcheson
column4: thank you so much for talking with us today.

column1: Nichole Etcheson (NE): Thank you for having me.
CWBR: Historians have spent so much time looking at the factory owners and the laborers in the Northeast and slaveholders and non-slaveholders in the South
column2: but you show us the farmers and the wider agricultural community of the Midwest and the Old Northwest.  Of all the counties and all of the northern states
column3: why is Putnam County
column4: Indiana an excellent area to study in order to understand how the American Civil War altered an entire generation of people?

column1: NE: As I say in the introduction
column2: no county is going to be totally perfect and I did choose Putnam County
column3: in part
column4: because of a famous speech that was given there by a Copperhead politician
column5: Dan Voorhies
column6: right before the war began.  But
column7: it seems to me
column8: that Putnam County does a fairly good job of representing the North.  It’s a largely agricultural community
column9: it is divided between Whigs and Democrats (and later
column10: Republicans and Democrats)
column11: in an era
column12: and in a state (Indiana) where the inter-party competition was quite fierce
column13: and a lot of the home front studies of the North have looked at cities: Chicago
column14: Boston
column15: and Philadelphia.  And those are all wonderful additions to what we need to know about the northern home front but we have not had many studies that have looked at the northern home front and that have looked at rural areas
column16: small-town areas that were more typical of the North.  Putnam County comes closer
column17: I think
column18: to being what much of the North was like.

column1: CWBR: In terms of your methodology
column2: what is the value of a county study in our broader
column3: more complete understanding of the Civil War era?

column1: NE: I call this a micro-history
column2: meaning looking at a very tiny place
column3: although I do take a larger slice of time than many home front studies of the Civil War which will concentrate on 1861-1865.  I look from
column4: about
column5: the end of the war with Mexico through the end of Reconstruction so I think that swath of time is a contribution.  But
column6: in terms of micro-history
column7: I really wanted to get a sense of how the war impacted individuals: soldiers
column8: farmers
column9: women
column10: the black community in Putnam County because
column11: really
column12: this war swept up real people.  And it is hard to get a sense of that when you’re looking at the big political studies we have or the big military studies that we have.   The way that this impacted the lives of real human beings and I would suggest that
column13: even though we are looking at very particular human beings in a very particular place
column14: the kinds of things that happen to them-imprisonment
column15: widowhood
column16: gaining more rights-are taking place all over the country.

column1: CWBR: You very cleverly begin the book with an account of the murder of Martha Ann Sublett Mullinex by her husband Greebury. How does this incident illustrate the inter-party conflict
column2: that you mentioned earlier
column3: in the years leading up to the war?

column1: NE: Yes
column2: Martha was murdered by her husband; they had not been married very long and he may have been mentally disturbed.  That is a little hard to tell in the newspaper accounts; he comes across as not quite “all there
column3: ” and he murders her with an axe.  But what interests me about that
column4: it is a turning point in the county history-it is the last execution in the county-but the story is picked up by a young man
column5: Miles Fletcher
column6: who is a professor at the local university
column7: and Miles Fletcher comes from a very prominent Indianapolis family.  And Miles turns
column8: what might ordinarily be a very tragic story
column9: into a revelation about the problems of the Democratic Party because the Mullinexes are Democrats
column10: Fletcher is a rising Republican
column11: and Greenbury drank
column12: and his family manufactured liquor
column13: and they were not interested in education
column14: and the murderer’s uncle had ties to the governor of Indiana who was a Democrat
column15: who managed to get a temporary stay of the execution through his Democratic political connections.   So Fletcher turns this all into a parable about how terrible the Democrats are
column16: the way in which this is politicized
column17: to reveal the differences between the two parties
column18: I thought
column19: was very interesting in the period before the Civil War.  It seemed to me that one of the constants throughout the Civil War period
column20: issues about gender that were there in the marriage
column21: issues about alcohol
column22: all of these things continue through but Fletcher has no interest in
column23: and there is no role played by race in this tragedy
column24: but it will come to be the case over the years that race becomes a more and important of a factor to the life of the county.

column1: CWBR: I was struck by the degree to which Putnam County seems to provide a micro-history
column2: as you mention
column3: in the presidential election of 1860 in which we see residents positioning themselves in four different corners.  It’s not simply a Lincoln-Douglas debate and I wonder
column4: what made politics so complex as the county considered their choices in 1860?

column1: NE: Putnam County
column2: one of the reasons I chose it
column3: is that a state like Indiana
column4: and a county like Putnam
column5: had a substantial migration from the upper South.  So all through the 1850s you see these very strong
column6: loyalties to Kentucky
column7: to the South
column8: that people in Indiana and people in this county feel that the growing Republican Party is picking on the South
column9: that southern rights are under attack
column10: and there is not much sympathy for abolitionism or antislavery.  At the same time
column11: though
column12: you do have the Whigs moving towards the Republican Party
column13: not out of an antislavery sentiment
column14: but out of the sense that it is the North that is the aggrieved party
column15: that the North has been bullied constantly by the Slave Power of the South.  So when we get to 1860
column16: it is mostly Douglas men versus Lincoln me-northern Democrat versus Republicans-arguing about which one of them can best represent the South.  There is a tiny
column17: infinitesimal Constitutional Union
column18: Bell movement but
column19: what I found out and find quite interesting
column20: was that there is a small Breckinridge movement led by some prominent local county officials
column21: a Judge named Delana Eckels went about the county and about the state making speeches for the Southern Rights’ Democrats and John Breckinridge and that the margin that the Breckinridge voters polled in that county pushed the county to the Republicans.  It allowed the Republicans to win the county.  To my knowledge
column22: we have tended to dismiss the Breckinridge movement in the North
column23: but I wonder
column24: if we did these kinds of micro-histories and looked at these results county-by-county
column25: if we might find that some of the Republican margin of victory is owed more to the Southern Rights movement than we have heretofore known.

column1: CWBR: Looking at the war
column2: it seems to me that many of Putnam’s residents opposed Republicans’ use of emancipation as a war aim.  If that is the case
column3: what does that tell us about the long-standing slavery v. union debate? Did Putnam County residents fight a different civil war?

column1: NE: They fought an internal civil war as well as a national civil war. And certainly many
column2: many hundreds of young men from Putnam County went off and they fought with Sherman and they fought with McClellan
column3: and they fought under Grant
column4: and they are owed a great deal for the victory that the Union eventually won.  But the county was very deeply divided and there was a very strong Copperhead
column5: anti-war
column6: Peace Democrat movement within the county.  And it mainly played out over issues of the draft and of emancipation
column7: which is to say that the violent incidents that occurred in the county-draft officers being mobbed and draft officers being shot at-were about the draft.  People were organizing; the Copperheads of Putnam County were organizing.  They were forming mobs
column8: if you want to call them that
column9: that had a consistent pattern of intimidating the draft officials and trying to prevent the carrying out of the draft.  With emancipation
column10: it was much more on the level of rhetoric of party resolutions that this was barbaric of the Lincoln administration to do this
column11: that it confirmed what the Southern Democrats had been saying all along: that the Republicans were really an abolitionist movement.  So
column12: I think there was war at both levels
column13: on the local level and then on the national level.

column1: CWBR: In that tone
column2: you seem to show that statewide
column3: Indiana experiences a great deal of debate over the Thirteenth Amendment
column4: and the state is the only one that chooses not to repeal its black laws. Why does Indiana seem so racially conservative?

column1: NE: I think it was that southern migration; that was one of the major divisions for people. I would go back even further to the origin of the black laws
column2: as I talk in the book
column3: to the Constitution of 1851
column4: where Indiana instituted Article 13 of the Constitution which prohibited African Americans from coming into the state.  So
column5: as you say
column6: Indiana was a black law state; it had various prohibitions against equal rights for African Americans and that Article 13 had been ratified by an even bigger margin-it was ratified separately from the Constitution-and it got a bigger margin of victory than the Constitution itself.  So
column7: I think that was due to the strong southern-roots population of Indiana.  And then what you’re referring to is that the state had a lot of difficulty shedding those attitudes and didn’t even get around
column8: until constitutional revision until the 1880s
column9: to repealing these black laws that had been nullified by the Civil War.  But I would also like to point out that
column10: despite those attitudes
column11: amazing things happened in Putnam County with race.  Republicans who
column12: before they were Republicans
column13: back when they were Whigs in the county in the 1850s
column14: did nothing for black rights-actually were opposed to black rights-through the Civil War period and
column15: perhaps for self-interested motives
column16: they actually come
column17: by the 1870s
column18: to be recruiting African Americans to moving into the county.  So there is this legacy of racism but the Civil War era brings
column19: I think
column20: enormous strides.

column1: CWBR: You see
column2: immediately after the war as you reference
column3: Putnam residents seem as if they want to disassociate themselves from the discussion of race entirely and they focus
column4: instead on economics or their support of or opposition to the war.  I wonder if I’m reading that correctly and
column5: if that’s the case
column6: why do politicians
column7: locally
column8: often push race to the periphery?

column1: NE: Well
column2: there are still these long-standing issues.  One of the things I found was that temperance is always there; it is kind of pushed to the background during the Civil War but
column3: after the Civil War
column4: it emerges and it is just an incredibly big deal.  And women are very involved with the temperance movement so
column5: although I don’t see women seizing upon the Civil War to get their rights-the kind of narrative that we have had
column6: someone like Elizabeth Cady Stanton
column7: who looked at the Civil War as an opportunity to seize political rights for women-Putnam County women don’t want that.  Most of them just want the men to come home and then
column8: sometimes when the men don’t come home
column9: they have to cope with the realities of getting on with life.  A lot of things that had been there before the war
column10: the concern with economic development
column11: the concern about temperance emerge again after the war
column12: but the reality is that the war has changed the status of African Americans.  One of the families that I talk about in the book
column13: the Townsends
column14: are the long-resident free blacks
column15: and for much of the period
column16: the only free blacks in the county
column17: their son serves in the 28th United States Colored Troops; he has a very tragic experience: he never sees combat
column18: he becomes ill
column19: he dies.  But nonetheless
column20: there are people coming into the county
column21: like the Townsends
column22: who have served in the military.  Now that blacks are mobile
column23: people are coming up from Kentucky and from other southern states and some of them have military service and they have the Fourteenth Amendment and the Fifteenth Amendment and they have a status that now has to be recognized.  People in the county have to come to terms with that.  So I think
column24: yes
column25: white people in the county would like to go back to the set of issues that had always preoccupied them but they have had a new set of issues has emerged. And they have increasing numbers of people in the county who are going to push for those rights.

column1: CWBR: I was struck
column2: particularly
column3: by how the Civil War changed gender roles.  Women had to work when men went to the war and when the men returned they
column4: often
column5: could not work.  How did pensions serve to maintain veterans’ manhood by enabling them the hope of providing for their family with their service during the crisis.  And
column6: at the same time
column7: how did pensions
column8: on the other hand
column9: alter the gender roles or the traditional role of a dependent woman?  I’m thinking specifically about Jennie Fletcher
column10: whose husband and father-in-law failed to enable her to be an independent woman.

column1: NE: The Fletchers were very wealthy so ultimately Jennie Fletcher
column2: when Miles dies
column3: inherits enough money
column4: and then when her father-in-law dies
column5: she inherits enough from that estate that she is seemingly independent.  On the issue of pensions
column6: pensions had different ramifications
column7: I think
column8: for different groups of people by race and class.  Some of what is interesting is that men who apply for these pensions don’t see it as a hand-out from the government.  One of the things that is interesting about these pension rolls is that
column9: as these men age
column10: they have more and more problems which
column11: I think it would be fair to say
column12: is probably related to the fact that they are getting old; they can’t hear.  Lucius Chapin’s pension rolls
column13: his teeth are falling out
column14: he is getting into his seventies
column15: he is having trouble hearing
column16: he is having some mobility issues
column17: and yet his pension applications take these all back to when he was in the army in Tennessee and Georgia and he had heat stroke
column18: and that is why his teeth are falling out or he had a malarial fever back during the war. So this is the cause of losing teeth and bad hearing. We would probably say
column19: well you’re aging; that’s why these things are happening to you.  The veterans want to see this
column20: not as I’m getting older and I’m asking the government for money
column21: as no
column22: the government owes me this because this is happening to me because of what I did for the country thirty or forty years ago.  The pension file of one of the black veterans
column23: Wyatt James
column24: who was related to the Townsend family
column25: who suffered some terrible-looking wounds in the Petersburg Campaign in 1864 and
column26: on the one hand
column27: historians have pointed out how black veterans can apply for these pensions and they can get remuneration just the way that white veterans do
column28: so it makes white and black manhood equivalent.  On the other hand
column29: Wyatt James is a laborer and the requirement is that he has to be disabled from laboring in order to qualify for the pension.  So
column30: it seems to be a little bit harder for him to be getting a pension than for Lucius Chapin
column31: who is a lawyer and doesn’t
column33: need to work as physically hard to make this case as he is getting older for increased pensions.  The women who get pensions
column35: who is the mother of the black soldier
column37: it is kind of hard to find out what happened.  She apparently filed for a pension and didn’t get anything for a long time and then got a good pension agent who got her back payments-a couple thousand dollars-an extraordinary sum for a poor black woman in that period.  I think that testifies
column39: to the government’s emphasis on equal rights: she is the mother of a soldier who died
column40: she apparently had some difficulty navigating the pension application process at first but
column42: she gets the back payment of a substantial amount.  And then
column47: is the case where the pension allows her to be fairly independent.  Her husband had been a prisoner at Andersonville
column49: he died shortly after the war
column50: and she views this pension as her money and
column52: it becomes divorced from this idea that it is her husband providing for her in perpetuity; she never remarries
column53: she lives largely off of the pension
column56: that is not ever what she wanted; she wanted John to come back from the war and provide for her as a man is supposed to do. So it is an unintended consequence of the pension that she becomes a very independent-minded widow.

column1: CWBR: You mention some of the strides that African Americans are able to make in the years after the war in the way that Putnam County alters the way that its viewpoint on race. I wonder
column2: generally speaking
column3: does post-war Putnam County’s experience help explain African-Americans’ struggle to make social headway nationally leading into the Jim Crow period?  It seems to me that
column4: while they are making strides
column5: many white residents are simply apathetic about race in this period in Putnam County.

column1: NE: Yes
column2: some are.  There are two things going on.  One
column3: of course
column4: is that African Americans during the Civil War and during Reconstruction are seeking to better their condition.  So
column5: by the 1870s
column6: in particular
column7: there builds up
column8: in some areas of North Carolina dissatisfaction with the end of Reconstruction
column9: with the re-imposition of discriminatory measures by the state of North Carolina
column10: and so African Americans there start thinking about leaving.  But then there is also a coordinate movement in Indiana
column11: and ultimately in Putnam County
column12: to recruit blacks to come to the county.  And the white Republicans who do this-some of them are self-interested- want cheap labor
column13: so they think former slaves from the South may work for less than white laborers in the county.  Some of it is
column14: this is a very closely divided county
column15: and local Republicans are looking to bring in Republican voters; everyone denies that this is going on.  That doesn’t seem to be how it started.  Local Democrats will say that they went out looking for voters; they’re importing voters.  It does not seem to have
column16: then
column17: the genesis of the movement but it certainly was a nice added side effect.  And so you get these white Republicans who were bringing in
column18: or hoping to bring in
column19: these North Carolina African Americans.  And local Democrats are certainly not indifferent about it; they are mad as hell and we talk about the Exoduster movement to Kansas and there was a national
column20: congressional committee to investigate what was happening with the movement of blacks out of the South.  Because our focus has largely been on the movement from the Deep South to Kansas
column21: we have tended to miss the fact that the whole reason to call this congressional committee into session was that they were worried (Democrats in Congress were worried) about black movement into Indiana.  That was really the origin of the congressional concern and a lot of the testimony was about Kansas but a lot of it was about Indiana as well
column22: and in that local testimony you see local Democrats organizing to drive African Americans out.  Now
column23: ultimately what happens is
column24: a lot of these Exodusters who come to Putnam County
column25: they end up leaving.  Many of them go to Indianapolis
column26: some of it because racial prejudice was stronger in the countryside than they had been led to believe.  I think a lot of it has to do with there being less economic opportunity than they had been led to believe so they go to Indianapolis which is a larger
column27: growing metropolis and there are more jobs there.  But some of these Exodusters stay in the county
column28: some of them marry into the Townsend and form the real beginnings of the black community in the county.

column1: CWBR: Professor Etcheson
column2: I want to thank once again for taking the time to discuss your book today
column3: A Generation at War: The Civil War Era in a Northern Community.

column1: NE: Well
column2:
thank you very much for having me.

column1:
5207 9787-0-8078-3542-5 $40.00 CWBR AUTHOR INTERVIEW:
The Civil War in the West: Victory and Defeat from the Appalachians to the Mississippi Hess
column2: Earl J.			"<h3>Interview with Earl J. Hess
column3: the Stewart W. McClelland Chair in history at Lincoln Memorial University

column1: Interviewed by Nathan Buman
Click here for the review
Civil War Book Review (CWBR): Today
column2: Professor Earl J. Hess
column3: the Stewart W. McClelland Chair in History at Lincoln Memorial University
column4: joins me to discuss his most recent work
column5: The Civil War in the West: Victory and Defeat from the Appalachians to the Mississippi. Professor Hess
column6: thank you for joining me today.

column1: Earl Hess (EH): You’re welcome and good morning. I’m happy to be here.
CWBR:You focus your study on the western armies and the activity in the western theater. What are some of the strengths and limitations of a geographic study of the Civil War?
EH: That’s an interesting question. I think some of the strengths are that we have a tendency
column2: maybe
column3: to under-appreciate the strength of regional identity in the 1860s in America.  Even though
column4: I think a lot of people are aware of that
column5: but still it is good to understand why we should think about that and have some deep awareness about what were the different characteristics of the regions of the United States and how they conducted the war.  I think there were some real differences between the West and the East and that is why
column6: in the book
column7: I often refer to the “western way” of conducting the Civil War on the part of the Federals.  There are four to five themes that could be discussed in that regard.  One of them was an almost overwhelming self-confidence that the western Federals developed in their ability to handle their Confederate enemy.  That
column8: as many of the readers of Civil War military history know did not exist very well in the East for various reasons.  You have Robert E. Lee in the East
column9: of course
column10: and in the West you had different Confederate commanders and you had a lot of Confederate problems in the West versus the Confederate strengths in the East and a lot of Union strengths in the West that countered-balanced all that sort of thing.  In terms of limitations
column11: of doing something like this
column12: I guess maybe you can lose a sense of cooperation and I try to compensate for that by pointing out the numerous ways in which the East and the West cooperated with each other
column13: not only the Union side but the Confederate side as well.  People know about the 11th and 12th Corps coming to Chattanooga after the Union defeat at Chickamauga in ’63 but
column14: you know
column15: the 23rd Corps went to the East and an awful lot of black regiments that were raised in Kentucky in 1862
column16: most of them were shipped to the East and served in the Army of the James which
column17: I think
column18: is kind of interesting and not very well known. There was an awful lot of regional cooperation. Most of the troops down in the Department of the Gulf were northeastern troops instead of western troops. There were very few troops from the western states down there in the New Orleans area.

column1: CWBR: I wonder how is the focus on the western soldier beneficial? Did he have a unique perspective on the war and the way that he looked at the big picture?
EH: I think there is an argument to be made about that. I think the western soldier
column2: because of Shiloh
column3: tended to feel like they were surprised at Shiloh and in April of ’62 they came close to losing but they persisted; they fought very hard
column4: they defeated the Confederates in battle
column5: at least in their view.  And beginning with that and successive victories after that they developed a really
column6: really striking self-confidence that
column7: I think
column8: historians and readers ought to pay a little more attention to as a major emotional factor in the winning of the war in the West.  Western soldiers
column9: as they continued to be successful also were quite aware that their compatriots in the East (I am talking about Union soldiers) were not being successful.  They read in the newspapers about defeats at Second Bull Run and then Fredericksburg and Chancellorsville and they tended to be kind of disgusted by that and they felt like their counterparts in blue in Virginia were not pulling their weight in terms of winning the Civil War.  And so you can see some very striking commentary in their letters and diaries about that issue.  It is not just the rank and file as Grant and Sherman also paid keen attention to all of that and I think they were getting kind of disgusted by the fact that the eastern Federals were not doing all they could do to keep Lee occupied.  I think that the dispatch of Longstreet and two divisions from the Army of Northern Virginia to help win the Confederate victory at Chickamauga was something of a turning point in the mindset of Grant and Sherman
column10: feeling that after they got the situation righted at Chattanooga in November of ’63 that something really needed to be done to better coordinate efforts East and West.  And when Grant was given a chance to command all Union forces
column11: he really implanted that concept.  If there really was a western way of war in the Civil War
column12: I think Grant brought it with him in March of ’64 to Virginia and
column13: to a large degree
column14: was successful in planting that concept over the whole Union war effort.

column1: CWBR: You mentioned cooperation between East and West and I wonder what challenges did Union officers in the West have to overcome considering their distance from Washington and how did they get the administration invested in a war so far away when they are so concerned with defending the city itself?
EH: If anything
column2: I think the western commanders were better off because of the distance from Washington because they had less interference from the politicians and I think they had a bit more freedom to develop a war effort as they wanted to in the West.  Obviously
column3: they needed financial support; they needed other things too
column4: that were basic to conducting the war effort.  It seems like there is a lot less political interference in the Union war effort in the western states than there is in Virginia.  And that may well be a factor in helping to develop this successful western way of war as opposed to the (in a degree in a way) the unsuccessful way of conducting the war in the Virginia theater
column5: at least before Grant got there and kind of changed things around a little bit in the spring of ’64.  I also make the point in the book that I really think that Lincoln
column6: who
column7: of course
column8: was Kentucky-born and lived in Indiana and in Illinois
column9: he was a westerner
column10: through and through.  He seems to have paid a lot more attention to the western theater and was pretty keen about doing
column11: I think
column12: the right thing to support there.  Jefferson Davis was
column13: of course
column14: also western-born in Kentucky too and he lived in Mississippi in the 1850s and et cetera
column15: but he seemed to have paid less attention
column16: or at least-maybe it is not fair to say he paid less attention-but his handling of western generals was less astute than his handling of Lee. And there is an interesting dichotomy there between Richmond and Washington in terms of how they viewed the West and how they handled-and the success with which they handled-the western forces.

column1: CWBR: You speak a great deal about the ways that occupation challenged the western armies. How did this influence their course of war and what did the occupation period indicate about both Confederate morale and the ability of Reconstruction after the war?
EH: There are some big questions here. It is a developing argument in the literature over the past few years. A lot more interest is being drawn to occupation problems in the Civil War
column2: especially guerrilla activity.  I did not have room in my book to get into a really big
column3: detailed discussion of all this but I do not really see guerrilla activity or necessarily civilian problems
column4: in general
column5: as necessarily guiding
column6: in important ways
column7: the general course of the way the North fought the Civil War.  That is an arguable point
column8: of course.  I really focus in my book on things that were integral to the movement of troops across deep
column9: large
column10: expansive enemy territory.  How do you do that?  You utilize effectively available technology like steamboats on the river system or railroad equipment where the rivers do not offer you the same opportunity as steamboats.  And
column11: obviously
column12: commanders have an awful lot of problems to deal with in terms of dealing with
column13: sometimes troublesome civilians or with civilians who take guns and take to the woods and start taking pot shots at Union soldiers.  If you read through the dispatches of Union generals in the West
column14: three-fourths
column15: eighty percent of what they are discussing are issues like this.  And maybe only twenty to twenty-five percent of the time they are discussing how to move troops and how to deal with organized Confederate troops on the frontier between Union-controlled territory and Confederate-controlled territory.  But at the same time
column16: I do not see any clear links between anger over guerrilla attacks translating itself into a greater desire to burn more territory or burn more resources to punish the South.  That effort to try to burn resources
column17: to consume Confederate food yourself
column18: that kind of stuff
column19: all of that is hard war policy and has a half a dozen major origins.  It can range all the way from a simple desire by young Union soldiers who are hungry and they are not getting enough food from their commissary so they want more food so they just naturally go out on their own to take food from civilians.  That is the most fundamental reason why you have this developing and there are other reasons.  There are real limitations to the Union supply system.  The Union resources were not inexhaustible and the ability to transport supplies was not unlimited so a lot of times Union soldiers did go hungry because their commissaries could not provide them with
column20: even their regular
column21: rations.  It is true that some people did get angry at guerrilla attacks and think that they should burn in retaliation; that
column22: of course
column23: did happen too.  But there are many
column24: many different streams of meeting that hard war policy.  I disagree
column25: for example
column26: with Daniel Sutherland argument in his recently-published award-winning book on the guerrilla war in the Civil War that it was a major factor in leading to the hard war policy and in altering the northern war effort.  I am not sure that that is a supportable argument.  But I think that there were two things going on here; I do not think that they necessarily relate to each other.  It is the organization and transportation and fighting of organized forces
column27: won by the Union against the Confederates
column28: but then there is a plethora of problems that commanders had to deal with in terms of occupying the ever-growing area of the South that Union soldiers no controlled.  I think that the Union side of the Civil War did a wonderful job winning that first problem and never really came up with truly effective (consistently effective) policies of dealing with the second problem.  I think they experimented a lot in dealing with occupation issues.  Sometimes it worked
column29: oftentimes it did not.  In the end
column30: it was the ending of the organized war that finally brought peace to the occupied areas and finally that is when guerrilla fighting completely evaporated everywhere by 1865.

column1: CWBR: On the flip side to guerrilla warfare
column2: you do mention
column3: on several occasions
column4: where white southerners throughout the war welcome the invading northern troops. What accounts for this and how common was that occurrence during the war?

column1: EH: The North would have liked to believe that there was a huge reservoir of Loyalists in the Confederacy and
column2: of course
column3: in some pockets there were
column4: especially in East Tennessee.  That
column5: of course
column6: the biggest example.  The overwhelming majority of southerners in the mountainous counties in eastern Tennessee were Loyalist and vigorously Loyalist
column7: willing to die for their beliefs.  You have a lot of Loyalists in northern Alabama  and western North Carolina
column8: here and there.  Even in some of the areas of the South that are overwhelmingly pro-Confederate
column9: you find a few Loyalists here and there.  And
column10: you know
column11: the same was true in the American Revolution where you found Loyalists to the Crown
column12: especially in the southern colonies in the 1770s.  How do you account for it?  I am not sure that historians have answered that question; I do not think that necessarily I have either.  I actually live here in East Tennessee and so the idea of mountain Loyalism is very keen here and people know about it and they are interested it.  I do not think that any historian has yes really dug deep enough to try to deeply understand why that was so and they have a tendency to just
column13: kind of
column14: say that it was so and look at the effects of it in the 1860s.  There are a number of different reasons.  There can be some sort of anti-slave attitude and certainly it is true that the mountain Loyalists detested slavery
column15: not because they were abolitionists but because they hated the fact that the ownership of slaves created an elite caste in southern society and so
column16: to a degree it is a sort of class consciousness going on there.  The East Tennessee Loyalists tended to be very racist on top of that but that does not mean that their loyalism to the flag and the hatred of the planter aristocracy was any less.  And
column17: to a large degree
column18: the Union troops were keen to seek these people out and utilize them and
column19: of course
column20: as everyone knows
column21: an awful lot of southerners served in blue.  Every seceded state contributed troops to the Union army
column22: some of them more than others.  And that did weaken the strength of the Confederacy and its ability to opt for independence.  I do not know that it necessarily was the fatal weakness but it certainly was one of the many weaknesses to CSA defeat
column23: especially in the West.  One point I make in the book is that the key difference in the West is geography; it is a huge
column24: expansive area in the western Confederacy compared to the eastern Confederacy and so it has a lot more different problems
column25: a lot more different aspects to it than the war in the East tended to.

column1: CWBR: It seems to me that
column2: for every stalemate that we have in the eastern theater there is a victory and some headway made in the West by Union forces.  In terms of morale and maintaining foreign neutrality
column3: was the West the Union lifeline to victory overall?

column1: EH: That is a nice way to put it. I agree with you. That is a good way to express it. I am not sure that contemporaries
column2: or certainly contemporaries in the West
column3: were keenly aware that they were winning the war.  I am talking about contemporaries so northern civilians in Illinois
column4: Wisconsin
column5: etc.  The press in the East tended
column6: of course
column7: to be focused on their region so they tended to be focused on the stalemate and etc.  And for some reason
column8: an awful lot of foreign governments like the many people in the British government and the French government tended to focus on what was going in Virginia and probably did not pay as much attention as they should have to what was taking place in the West.  So you often have scares in Washington
column9: D.C. about British recognition and all that sort of stuff.  Henry Halleck wrote a letter to William Rosecrans in December of ’62 when Rosecrans was preparing to lead the Union army out of Nashville against Bragg’s army at Murfreesboro that resulted in the battle of Stone’s River and Halleck informed Rosecrans that Lincoln is very
column10: very concerned that when the British Parliament meets in January that it might recognize the CSA based on the horrible defeats at Fredericksburg and that sort of stuff.  And so they really kind of painted a picture to Rosecrans as if his campaign in December of ’62 that resulted in the battle of Stone’s River might be the turning point in the Civil War.  That is recognition that if the East is doing badly the West has an opportunity to try to take up the slack and
column11: I think that
column12: in the long run
column13: that is exactly what did happen.  To me
column14: that is one more way of seeing the West as the decisive theater of the Civil War.  And certainly it is true that
column15: by early ‘65
column16: the western war is basically won and the eastern war is not yet finished.  That is
column17: of course
column18: a big reason that Sherman decides to lead 60
column19: 000 tough
column20: western Union soldiers
column21: veterans of many successful campaigns and battles
column22: to Virginia to give the final blow to Lee’s hopes of holding onto Petersburg and Richmond.  It is interesting to imagine Sherman and
column23: by that time
column25: 000 (Schofield’s 23rd Corps was added to it)
column26: what would have happened if Lee had stayed at Petersburg and allowed Sherman to join with Grant with those 80
column27: 000 troops.  You would have had an interesting development
column28: an interesting campaign and set of battles to end the Petersburg campaign at that stage.  To me
column29: it is a telling commentary of how successful the West was
column30: that Sherman was able to take such a huge army and march it hundreds of miles to help end the war in Virginia.

column1: CWBR: Taking a step back then
column2: how did black enlistment change the war for both northern and southern in the western theater?

column1: EH: Well
column2: that is an interesting point.  In a very superficial way
column3: you could say that it adds 180
column4: 000 troops to the Union army; that is a very; that is a gigantic contribution and even though most of those 180
column5: 000 black troops did not participate heavily in combat
column6: they performed essential roles.  The vast majority of garrisons that were necessary to protect the Mississippi River after the fall of Vicksburg consisted of black troops.  Something like forty percent
column7: I believe
column8: of all black troops raised by the Union army over all in the Civil War were raised along the banks of the Mississippi River and those troops served almost their entire service guarding the Mississippi for northern commerce and Union military logistical support from July 4
column10: until the end of the war.  That is the kind of service that does not get much publicity or credit because people tend to focus on the battlefield instead of this sort of thing but it is fundamentally important.  In less obvious ways
column11: in other words and maybe in ways that are difficult to appreciate
column12: in a kind of fundamental
column13: underlying way
column14: the recruitment of 180
column15: 000 blacks into the Union army
column16: in a practical military sense that had a big import.  You could look at it another way.  Lincoln’s Emancipation Proclamation
column17: which was the precedent for recruiting troops was arguably unconstitutional
column18: certainly on shaky grounds.  But once you go putting 180
column19: 000 black men into blue uniforms and give them a rifle and train them how to shoot it
column20: that confirms that there is not going to be any backsliding in American history to try to resurrect some form of legal slavery or anything like that.  It was
column21: I think
column22: a necessary important political and morale step intermediate between the Emancipation Proclamation and the Thirteenth Amendment which was passed by Congress in
column23: I believe
column24: late 1864 or early1865 perhaps.  On the Confederate side
column25: the Confederates
column26: as everyone knows
column27: toyed with the idea of possibly raising black troops
column28: finally did so very late.  Whether they would have had success if they had the chance
column30: to put it more fully into effect no one can tell.  And
column33: the deployment of black Union troops on the battlefield tended to infuriate Confederate troops who oppose them
column34: resulting in infamous massacres of black troops at Fort Pillow
column35: for example which I briefly discuss in the book and in the eastern theater too.  And also maltreatment
column36: even if they are not being massacred
column37: often when black Union soldiers were captured by Confederate soldiers they were mistreated or they were sold back into slavery or they were used as labor instead of being treated as POWs as well.

column1: CWBR: A simple question
column2: perhaps with broader ramifications: At what point was the war in the West officially settled in your eyes?

column1: EH: Goodness
column2: in terms of major activity by mainline forces
column3: with Hood’s defeat at Nashville in mid-December of ’64
column4: coupled with the decision to transfer what was left of the Army of Tennessee to North Carolina.  Conceivably
column5: if Hood’s force had remained in Mississippi after December of ’64 it might have done some more work too but after it was decided to shift Hood’s forces
column6: now under Johnston
column7: over to North Carolina that kind of ended it.  There was the matter of mopping up after that and there are some campaigns.  Of course
column8: there is Wilson’s big cavalry raid going through Alabama and into western Central Georgia by the end of the war and there is Canby’s long
column9: long-deferred major operation to capture Mobile in March and April of ’65.  But in hindsight
column10: you can see that both operations could easily have not happened and the war would have come to an end when it did anyway but nobody could have foreseen that then. But those kinds of mopping up operations are natural in such a huge expanse of theater of operations like the West where there are lots and lots of targets. And you have significant numbers of Union troops around so you might as well use them and wind up the war because you do not know when it is going to end until it does end.

column1: CWBR: You have spent a great deal of time
column2: in general
column3: in studying both eastern and western theaters.  In your mind
column4: was the United States Army of the Tennessee the most effective fighting force ever assembled?

column1: EH: Yes
column2: I would tend to say that.  Given the comparatively modest size of that field force
column3: barely going above 30
column4: 000 men at any time period
column5: and given its limited resources in terms of well-trained staff officers
column6: in terms of well-trained engineers
column7: it improvised an awful lot.  It had a lot of tough fighting ability and a lot of stamina
column8: high morale and tremendous faith in their leaders
column9: especially Grant and Sherman and McPherson.  I think they probably liked Howard maybe a little bit less but I would
column10: in fact
column11: argue that Oliver Otis Howard was a better commander of the army than McPherson was.  McPherson made some real mistakes in the Atlanta campaign even though he was a bright guy and a good guy.  So
column12: yes
column13: I would say so and
column14: on the other end of the spectrum
column15: the Confederate Army of Tennessee
column16: Bragg’s force and Johnston’s force
column17: of course
column18: put in the least impressive record
column19: I guess you could say of combat effectiveness and successful campaigns
column20: not necessarily because of any faults that rest on the shoulders of the rank and file but for a variety of other reasons too
column21: I suppose.  And the Army of the Cumberland
column22: I would argue
column23: is one of the more impressive field forces in terms of high levels of professionalism and innovative administrative efforts and all sorts of other things going on there too.  So
column24: I think the western theater really provided some interesting stories and histories of different units from the field armies on down to regiments that are unique in American military history.

column1: CWBR: Professor Hess
column2: thank you for taking the time today to discuss The Civil War in the West: Victory and Defeat from the Appalachians to the Mississippi.

column1: EH: Sure
column2:
I enjoyed it. Thank you.

column1:
5362 978-0-393-06531-2 $29.95 CWBR AUTHOR INTERVIEW:
Freedom National: The Destruction of Slavery in the United States
column3: James			"<h3>Interview with James Oakes
column4: Distinguished Professor of History and Graduate School Humanities Professor at the City University of New York Graduate Center

column1: Interviewed by Michael Frawley
Click here for the review
Civil War Book Review (CWBR): Today
column2: I’m discussing with Professor James Oakes his new published <i>Freedom National: The Destruction of slavery in the United States
column4: which was recently awarded the 2013 Gilder Lehrman Lincoln Prize. Congratulations Dr. Oakes and thank you for joining us today.

column1: James Oakes (JO): Thank you very much. It's a pleasure to be here.

CWBR: You review in your book the drive of Republicans to make freedom national since the 1830s. How did the Republican Party find such a level of freedom in the Constitution when the Democrats did not?
JO: Well
column2: that's a long and complicated question.  They went back to the records of the Constitutional Convention and to the records of the founding era and discovered to their own satisfaction.  They were satisfied to discover that the founders had left an anti-slavery legacy that was more powerful than most contemporary historians actually believe was there and also that one wing of the anti-slavery movement
column3: the Garisonian wing
column4: belief was there specifically they saw in the language of the Constitution the repeated reference to slaves as persons rather than property and from that they deduced that the Constitution did not recognize slaves as property from the anti-slavery rulings of English courts that were extremely influential in revolutionary America.  They deduced that slavery could only be created by statutory or positive laws they called it and that in the absence of such statutory the universal presumption of the natural law was freedom since slavery was strictly a state institution.  It could not exist anywhere outside the boundaries of a state that had slave codes on its books and created slavery by positive law this would have been true in all of the northern states.  But
column5: it was also true in all of the western territories and any areas where the Constitution itself was sovereign. There was positive law recognizing the existence of slavery again that meant not only the northern states that had abolished slavery but also the high seas
column6: Washington D.C.
column7: the western territories.  And
column8: if properly followed that constitutional logic would lead to a series of policies that would as you put it and I put it in my book make freedom national and slavery merely local
column9: a state institution
column10: on the assumption that slavery was a weak and inefficient and backwards institution.  The republicans
column11: or antislavery people
column12: assumed that once these policies were implemented the slave South was surrounded
column13: not allowed to expand
column14: no more new slave states
column15: abolished in Washington D.C.
column16: suppressed on the high seas.  All those things
column17: once you do that
column18: you surround the South with what they called according to freedom. Slavery would die of its own accord a natural death so the logical outcome of the policies associated with the doctrine of freedom national was that slavery would ultimately be extinguished. That’s the language Lincoln used all the time. We wanted to put slavery on a course of ultimate extinction.

column1: CWBR: Based on this plan do you believe that slavery could have ended as many Republicans seemed to hope
column2: without war?

column1: JO: I don't know. That's a hypothetical question and I've gone back and forth with it. I guess if I had to come down again
column2: it's a hypothetical question
column3: it’s a counterfactual.  I don’t know
column4: and nobody really knows
column5: but I’ve gone back and forth about this with some friends who disagree.  If pushed I would say I don't think it would work.  I think they underestimated slavery's strength.  I think they underestimated slavery’s economic vitality and
column6: also I’m not sure that how long it would have taken for the Republicans anti-slavery party to gain enough congressional strength to be able to implement that kind of policy to its fullest.  So
column7: it requires too many assumptions about the potential power of the Republicans in the national power of the anti-slavery northern party and of slavery’s intrinsic weakness and its likelihood that it would die.  But
column8: that said
column9: it’s almost impossible to find a Republican who doesn’t believe that slavery will be put to death if these policies are implemented you get different estimates.  Thaddeus Stevens said do this
column10: implement these policies
column11: and it will be gone in 25 years.  Secessionist during the secession crisis said if we let the Republicans implement these policies slavery will be dead in 10 years.  When Lincoln proposed these policies for the Border States
column12: the policies of gradual abolition
column13: his preferred time table was 10 years.  But
column14: Owen Lovejoy the anti-slavery Congressman
column15: the abolitionist Congressman
column16: from Illinois
column17: said at one point during a speech in the 1850s
column18: look we’ll give you 25 years if you do this
column19: just start it now and if it takes 25 years that’s fine.  In fact if it takes 50 years that’s fine.  So Republicans did uniformly believe that if you implemented these policies slavery would eventually die. But
column20: I don’t know if I really can say that I doubt that that would have happened
column21: and I doubt that that would have happened based on not so much on my ability to see the counterfactual but because of what I saw happen in the Civil War.  That is slavery did not die even under 4 years of intense overwhelming military bombardment by the north
column22: and a concerted campaign of military emancipation alongside the policy of building according to freedom. Even with that I believe slavery would have survived the Civil War and I believe that’s the position most Republicans eventually came to by the end of the war.

column1: CWBR: During the war you show that Republicans still work within Constitutional limit when working to end slavery
column2: especially in the Border States
column3: how important was the reaction of slave holders in the Border States to Republican’s emancipation plans?

column1: JO: Well
column2: the Republicans had two distinct emancipation plans.  The Border State plan is often mistaken as the primary plan.  So
column3: that we get a certain positive trajectory that says the Republicans began by advocating gradual compensated emancipation and ended up by advocating universal uncompensated military emancipation.  In fact
column4: military emancipation was a distinct policy
column5: and it was applied to the disloyal seceded states almost as soon as the war began and the other policy of pressuring the loyal slave states to abolish slavery was applied subsequently because it was a peace time policy.  It couldn’t begin to be implemented until Congress came into session for the first time during the war
column6: full regular session
column7: beginning in December ’61.  So
column8: almost immediately at the moment Republicans hit the ground in December 1861
column9: they began noticing the Border States were resisting.  That there was a problem with the Border States and within a few months’ time they had comes to the conclusion that there was far less unionism in the Border States than they had believed.  There would be and that they were going to have to pursue a much more aggressive policy to force those states to abolish slavery on their own.  So
column10: the reaction of the Border States accentuated and accelerated the aggressiveness of the Republican policy with regard to the loyal slave states.  But
column11: it did not impede the development of the universal emancipation of military emancipation in the succeeded states.  What changed over time was the relationship that Republicans understood between those two policies
column12: that is going into the war
column13: Republicans
column14: all Republicans
column15: all antislavery people
column16: for decades had assumed that slavery was weak.  Weak everywhere.  Weakest in the Border States.  That the Border States would be the first to abolish slavery and once it was abolished there it would seep further and further into the South as the intrinsic weaknesses of the system became more and more evident.  The shrinking power of each new Free State
column17: Border State transformed into a free state
column18: further weakens the power of the slave states as a block
column19: and they believed that it would start in the upper South and then move to the lower South.  But
column20: by the spring of 1862
column21: they begin to reverse that premise.  Having implemented a policy of military emancipation in the seceded states they began to say to the Border States you know you better start abolishing slavery quickly.  Because if you don’t
column22: military emancipation will seep northward into the loyal Border States and slavery will be disintegrated by
column23: as Lincoln put
column24: it the mere friction and abrasion of war.  So
column25: I don’t accept the standard interpretation that says Lincoln’s concern for the Border States inhibited his acceptance of emancipation.  He
column26: in fact
column27: had accepted military emancipation long before
column28: months before
column29: he made his first proposal for gradual compensated abolition in the border states and
column31: the war accelerated and made more aggressive the approach to the Border States that would have been there in a naturally peace time situation.

column1: CWBR: You show a Republican Party bent on ending slavery
column2: but how widespread were these ideas among the general northern population? Does Lincoln’s re-election show that they understood and supported emancipation as much as Congressional Republicans did and did the average American understand the Constitutional issues involved?

column1: JO: I think more qualified historians than myself have amply demonstrated that in this period of American history all issues
column2: all major political issues
column3: all sources of political division whether it be the Bank of the United States
column4: the internal improvements
column5: or slavery were framed in constitutional terms.  It was simply normal for Northerners and Southerners alike to frame all their arguments about slavery in constitutional terms and
column6: it was universally insisted upon among republicans that they would never over step the bounds of the constitution by having the Federal government abolish slavery directly in the state where it was already legal.  That was simply understood across the board.  It’s almost impossible to find anyone in the United States in 1860 who believed that the Constitution allowed the Federal government to abolish slavery in a state where it already exists.  So that is simply the consensus of pro-slavery and anti-slavery people
column7: Democrats and Republicans.  So all debate over slavery takes place within that consensus about the Constitution.  So I would have to say after that long winded answer that the short answer to your question is yes
column8: Northerners did understand the constitutional limits within which the debate over slavery took place.

column1: CWBR: Can you explain how the impending end of the war impacted Republican plans
column2: were Republicans really as nervous about slavery returning in a post war United States that did not have a Constitutional amendment that ended the institution?

column1: JO: Yes
column2: this was a surprising discovery for me.  I actually began this book inspired by an event that was central to my last book which was the second meeting of Frederick Douglas and Abraham Lincoln that took place in August of 1864 when Lincoln looked he was going to lose his bid for reelection and he called Frederick Douglas to the White House for a second meeting and said to him looks like I’m going to lose and slavery is not yet dead.  We need your help to organize a cadre of blacks who can move unnoticed through the South to inform as many slaves as possible that they are freed because once I lose and go out of office the Emancipation Proclamation process will end and Douglas did not dispute that and I remember when I first started thinking about that discussion between the two of them I said well if that’s correct and Lincoln historians who say Lincoln freed all the slaves with a stroke of his pen by affixing his signature to the Emancipation Proclamation have got it wrong.  That Lincoln himself did not believe he had done that and that side who claim that the slaves freed themselves
column3: that slavery was deteriorating
column4: and that no force on earth could have stopped the revolution from completing itself
column5: they must have been wrong also if these two guys very smart guys meeting in August of 1864 in the closing year of the war are agreed that slavery wasn’t dead and would survive the war if Lincoln and the Republicans were not re-elected.  Then I was going to have to investigate that and see what was going on there and when I did I discovered that in the book I’ve just finished
column6: I discovered that this was actually a widespread assumption among Republicans.  That by late 1863 after the two anti-slavery policies had been implemented completely and fully the pressure on the Border States
column7: the loyal slave states
column8: to abolish slavery on their own.  All those policies had been implemented to put the pressure on them and not a single one of them had abolished slavery and military emancipation had been enforced at high tide beginning with the Emancipation Proclamation.  Universal emancipation had been decreed
column9: a whole cadre of emancipation agents had been sent through the South to entice slaves off their plantations.  Blacks had been admitted into the Union Army by the tens of thousands and yet it looked like the North
column10: the tide of the war
column11: had changed with Gettysburg and Vicksburg in the summer of 1863.  It looked like the tide had changed in favor of the North.  The North was going to win the war but it also looked like by the end of the year again when republicans came back to Congress it looked as though the war would end with a northern victory but without slavery having been abolished and over the course of the next several months from December of 1863 to about March of 1864 Republicans debated among themselves what was the best way to get slavery thoroughly abolished and since all the various legislative proposals looked as though they ran up against the Constitution the only solution they could agree on was to re-write the Constitution.  In March
column12: in the spring of 1864
column13: the Senate endorses the 13th Amendment.  In June
column14: the Republican Party endorses the 13th amendment in its platform and the House rejects it.  The Democratic minority defeats it in the House and the Republicans go into the 1864 elections committed to that 13th Amendment thoroughly abolishing slavery everywhere.  The other fear that I didn’t see in my last book but came pouring out of the sources when I went through them this time was not only that most of the slaves would not actually have been physically freed by the war.  The war would end with most of them still slaves but
column15: also
column16: the threat that once the war was over the Constitution would be restored
column17: slavery would once again revert to the control of the states and the states would be free not only to perpetuate slavery but to re-enslave those who had ostensibly been freed by the war.  This was a threat that was openly made by slave state representatives from the loyal slave states on the floor of Congress and virtually every speech made by every Republican in defense of the 13th Amendment said this will do two distinct things
column18: it will end slavery everywhere in the United States and it will make the possibility of it being revived impossible so the fear of re-enslavement
column19: the re-establishment of slavery after a northern victory was a crucial aspect of Republican motivations in pushing for the 13th Amendment.

column1: CWBR: Why do you believe that most people today do not seem much in the way of emancipation taking place before the Emancipation Proclamation
column2: is it they myths that have grown up around Lincoln or have historians not gotten the narrative correct?

column1: JO: That’s a tough question and the answer I give ultimately has to do with politics. That is
column2: we should probably explain that one of the things I try to demonstrate in my book is that in the very earliest months of the war when Congress came into a special session five months ahead of schedule
column3: in July of 1861
column4: Republicans began emancipating slaves and that there was an emancipation clause in the First Confiscation Act and the orders for implementing that law were issued by the War Department on August 8th
column5: 1861.  From that date on you see emancipation spreading with the Union Army as it moved down into occupied areas of the Confederacy along the southern Atlantic coast and then in 1862 up the Mississippi Valley in Louisiana and ultimately up all the way into Tennessee and the areas occupied by Sherman and Grant’s armies.  So that by the time the proclamation is issued
column6: tens of thousands if not hundreds of thousands have already been emancipated under the various policies implemented beginning in the summer of 1861 and yet even as even before the Emancipation Proclamation was issued all of that emancipating was obscured by the nature of the debate over slavery.  I think the best answer I can give to why people in this secession crisis were saying disunion means abolition
column7: and we are going to abolish slavery.  All republicans are saying this despite the fact that they have been in charge of the abolition process in the Sea Islands in the late 1861 and in Louisiana in 1862.  Despite that most republicans
column8: began to say it was inconceivable to me that we would ever reach the point where we would emancipate all the slaves with the Emancipation Proclamation.  I think the explanation for that has to do with the fact that in 1862 when they are implementing a universal policy of universal emancipation in the seceded states is an election year and the Democrats begin to say
column9: look we said all along that this was the goal of this party
column10: that this was an abolitionist party
column11: not a unionist party.  They don’t really care about establishing
column12: their primary goal is not restoring the union
column13: the primary goal is abolitionizing the whole United States.  Republicans respond by saying it was inconceivable to us that we would ever reach this point.  This is entirely the product of unforeseen circumstances in the war and exactly the same thing repeats itself in the 1864 presidential elections when right after the Republicans have committed themselves to a 13th Amendment and once again Democrats begin to say
column14: and say all through the election
column15: you see this is what we told you were going to have
column16: a war without end until the Republicans successfully destroy slavery.  This is what they wanted all along and once again Republicans start saying no this was inconceivable to us we never imagined.  That’s when you start hearing Lincoln say it was unimaginable to me that we would ever get to this point where we would be abolishing slavery.  Everybody knew the war was caused by slavery but nobody could have imagined that the results were so fundamental and astounding.  Well
column17: in fact
column18: everybody had imagined it but in the context of the political between northern Democrats and Republicans the Republicans are put in the position of having to deny the charge that they had been going after slavery all along. That was their primary motivation and in the process obscuring the fact that they have been going after slavery all along starting in the early years of the war. That’s the best explanation I can have for the peculiar disappearance of all those emancipations in the first years of the war from the historical memory. It would take someone who’s better equipped to study historical memory than I am to give a fuller answer.

column1: CWBR: Professor Oakes
column2: I appreciate you taking the time to sit and discuss your most recent work
column3: <i>Freedom National: The Destruction of slavery in the United States

column1:
JO: Thank you very much.

" Frawley
column2: Michael Winter 2013 2013-02-01 Interview W. W. Norton & Company "" ""

column1:
5512 978-1-59420-342-8 $36.00 CWBR Author Interview:
More than Freedom: Fighting for Black Citizenship in a White Republic 1829-1889 Kantrowitz
column2: Stephen			"<h3>Interview with Stephen Kantrowitz
column3: Professor of History and Director of Graduate Studies at the University of Wisconsin
column4: and recently named a finalist for the Gilder Lehrman Douglass Prize

column1: Interviewed by Michael Frawley
Click here for the review
Civil War Book Review (CWBR): Today the Civil War Book Review is proud to speak with Stephen Kantrowitz
column2: Professor of History and Director of Graduate Studies at the University of Wisconsin. We will be discussing his recent book More than Freedom: Fighting for Black Citizenship in a White Republic 1829-1889. Thank you for joining us today.

column1: Stephen Kantrowitz (SK): I am really happy to be with you.
CWBR: Based off the title of your book
column2: could you explain why you chose the dates that you did since most people see your subject as something intimately connected with the war years?

column1: SK: Yeah
column2: the reason behind the wider parameters there is that the black freedom struggle in the nineteenth century is closely
column3: intimately related to the Civil War era. Its normal dates and topics and events
column4: but it isn't totally identical to it. The black freedom struggle that I'm charting begins with the publication of David Walker's Appeal to the Colored Citizen's in 1829-1830. Which from my perspective establishes the idea that African-Americans are going to forcefully claim a place in the American nation. But not only that
