column5: it is possible for them to do so by making an alliance with whites and being their friends. I don't say that in a casual way
column6: Walker truly believes that it is possible for whites and blacks to share a country. That will mean changing the hearts of white people. It is that project
column7: as much as the project as ending slavery
column8: as much as the project of transforming the legal
column9: or constitutional status of African-Americans that he and his comrades are after during that entire period.  To 1889
column10: is a little less clear as a date. The reason I chose that date has a lot to do with the life of a person who is central to the arch of the book
column11: which is Lewis Hayden
column12: who was a fugitive slave who becomes one of the key activists in the black Boston community of the nineteenth century.   He dies in 1889.  That is the year before the lodge elections bill fails
column13: that is the year before the Mississippi disenfranchising constitution passes
column14: it really is the end of an era that something like David Walker and his friends would have imagined as possible earlier in the century.

column1: CWBR: You chose Boston as the focus of your work. Why did you choose this city over others with large free African American populations like New York or Philadelphia?
SK: Two reasons for that
column2: first it is personal. I am from suburban Boston
column3: I am from Brookline
column4: and in the course of exploring the history of the free black communities in the North
column5: I realized that I felt a very powerful personal connection to the place
column6: and found the strangeness and difference of the history that I was exploring relative to my own experience of the place
column7: really a powerful motivator that kept me going and connected to the project in many ways over the course of a decade. I think there is a much more important intellectual reason for doing this project and that is free black people are the freest and most equal in Massachusetts. There freer and more equal in Massachusetts than any other polity or context in North America
column8: or at least in the United States. Black men have the right to vote
column9: and have few formal restrictions on their lives. Therefore we get to see the limits of the possible. We also get to see a place where slavery has been extinguished since the 1780s
column10: and so there is a long
column11: long history of freedom. We also have a white climate that is more open to anti-slavery abolitionist ideas comparatively early. So
column12: Boston is a great place to test the limits of the possible. It is a great place to see how far things could go
column13: and it is wonderful for that reason too because it is in Boston that the first important interracial coalitions devoted to anti-slavery and equality emerge in the form of New England anti-slavery society and the Liberator and that world. This makes Boston a wonderful place to see how far it was possible to imagine how things would go.

column1: CWBR: African Americans in Boston identified themselves as ""colored citizens
column2: how important was this term to the fight for citizenship?

column1: SK: It is a surprisingly important term
column2: and one that kept coming up over the course of the research. Not because I think everybody in that world had read David Walker
column3: it is not clear to me that they had. The term itself survives and establishes a foothold in people's imaginations and it does so
column4: as something to aspire to. That is people say
column5: we the ""colored citizen's"" assemble to do this or that
column6: and you will find that language throughout the anti-slavery press
column7: you'll find it in petitions
column8: you'll find it throughout the Civil War and beyond. People use it to express their hope that they can be both ""colored"" and citizens. African Americans also use this term ironically
column9: they use it to suggest that many people think this term is an oxymoron in fact
column10: and that we are incapable of being citizens because we are ""colored."" African Americans understand that use a lot of other terms that signal the same things. Like
column11: ""Aliened-Americans
column12: or the term ""2/3 free
column13: that is one of David Walker's phrases
column14: or the ""nominally free."" There are a lot of other phrases like these that play upon this idea of skepticism. ""Colored Citizens"" is really critical
column15: and at one point
column16: was actually the title of the book.

column1: CWBR: Was the rhetoric and legacy of the American Revolution important to helping African Americans see a path to citizenship? Is following this ""American"" pattern helping African Americans to gain citizenship?
SK:Well to some degree. But I would phrase it a little differently. I would say African Americans are they themselves aware that they had participated in the Revolution. So say
column2: George Middleton
column3: a Revolutionary War veteran
column4: is one of the stalwarts of the community in the early nineteenth century on Beacon Hill. There are a large number of memories of the so called ""bucks"" of America
column5: a black unit that was presented a flag by John Hancock. So
column6: what I am suggesting is that the relationship to the Revolution is not one of the Revolution happened
column7: we can use this event and therefore analogize our freedom struggle to the American Revolution's freedom struggle. Instead
column8: we are going to seize that freedom struggle as though it were our own which it only was in part of course. The best example of this is the way that slavery comes to an end in Massachusetts. Which is
column9: well there are many slaves in Massachusetts in the 1780s. However
column10: in the middle of the decade
column11: a series of court cases brought by Massachusetts slaves in which they sue for their freedom based upon the first line of the Massachusetts constitution. Which is ""All men are born free and equal."" On the basis of that simple utterance
column12: they say how can slavery exist when all men are born free? The courts agree
column13: and the Supreme Court agrees that slavery is unenforceable. Slavery collapses. So
column14: the Revolution offers some of the tool kit for establishing freedom
column15: but it is black people seizing that opportunity and leveraging those universal principles into something that will work for them in their own lives. That is the importance of the American Revolution for them. You can see this in the way that William Cooper Nell approaches the Revolution when he writes Colored Patriots of the American Revolution in 1855. He is very carefully deploying a partial record of black military service and other achievements
column16: to make a case that African Americans had always been integral to the American national project. Now
column17: he leaves out the fact that many African Americans took up the British offer to serve with them in exchange for freedom. This had been the case in every war where they had been an opportunity to serve one side or another for freedom. So
column18: he writes a very selective account in order to make the case
column19: because
column20: well
column21: he is a propagandist as well as a historian. So
column22: it is a complex relationship
column23: but the Revolution is absolutely useful too and important too to the black freedom struggle in the nineteenth century.

column1: CWBR: How important was the relationship between black activists and white supporters
column2: why was this relationship needed in order to move citizenship forward?

column1: SK:So
column2: we think about the United States in 1850 or 1860
column3: there are about 250
column4: 000 free black Northerners
column5: there are somewhere around 20 million white Northerners.  There is no way that 250
column6: 000 people even if they were all enfranchised
column7: even if they were all activists
column8: which of course they are not. There is no way that this tiny group of people can assert itself politically and transform a white republic
column9: into a non-racial republic. What they can do is recruit white allies. That is the reason that 1829 is such an important date.  It is the first time we hear free blacks appeal to whites In David Walker's appeal when he says
column10: ""What a happy country this will be if the whites will listen."" William Lloyd Garrison and a handful of others do appear to listen to that
column11: and their willingness to extend themselves over the color line at great social cost
column12: and enormous lifetime that many of these individuals make to that struggle. That ability to do that and show that this is a cause worth doing is the turning point for African American participation and belonging in the American body politic
column13: and American social life
column14: and American cultural and political life. So
column15: I think it is absolutely critical and tough
column16: it is not easy
column17: and as with any struggles white people at any moment can decide to go home
column18: and retreat to a world of comfort. That doesn't involve constant struggle
column19: and their black counterparts do not have this option
column20: and so there is an inequality built into the struggle itself. On the other hand
column21: some of the white people last in the struggle for decades
column22: and some last for their entire lives. The book charts some of the ways in which some of the white allies disappoint and desert and betray their black coalition partners. On the other hand
column23: it shows people who had been bitter enemies like Benjamin Butler
column24: turn out to be for critical moments really important allies. So
column25: it's a mixed bag
column26: but it is a really important story because it is what makes that change possible for a specific group of people.

column1: CWBR: Why was the formation of organizations
column2: public and private
column3: from Masons to militias
column4: so central to your book?

column1: SK: There are central to the story of this because
column2: for the most part
column3: I said that black men were enfranchised in Massachusetts
column4: but they are excluded from virtually every white dominated institution
column5: organization
column6: political party
column7: and political club. So
column8: in order to learn the function as political beings
column9: to learn how institutions work
column10: to learn how constitutions are written
column11: to learn how meetings are run
column12: to learn all the basic elements of political life African Americans have to turn to one another to do it. And it is through these organizations that they do these things
column13: in much the same way that Europeans had turned to one another in the eighteenth century in the middle of the ""Enlightenment"" and begun to constitute themselves as independent societies
column14: which were not under the control of the state or the church. It is a much the same story as that
column15: except in the American context it is not threatening to a king or church and thus they can do. If they try to do it in Richmond or Charleston
column16: or in New Orleans
column17: it would have been construed as a precursor to a slave revolt. In this context they can do it and they learn to do. The second reason is less practical and more transcendent
column18: that is they are mostly poor people. These are mostly people who experience a lot of hostility and neglect in their daily lives
column19: as members of a very small stigmatized minority. So
column20: to have a place to go where they constitute themselves as whole
column21: special
column22: important that is really important to them and their understanding of themselves and one another
column23: and their ability to turn to the wider world with a sense of they are worthy of the things they imagine. This takes place in churches
column24: it takes place in schools
column25: it takes place in masonic and other kinds of fraternal organizations. Wherever it takes place I think it is part of a dialectic
column26: a necessary back and forth between the retreat to a place of security and comfort and the knowledge that one needs to move out from that world into the world where you might make some transformative change.

column1: CWBR: How does the 1850 Fugitive Slave Act change how African Americans work to preserve their freedom?
SK: Well the Fugitive Slave Law of 1850 upends their politics. There had been efforts to capture fugitives
column2: and rescue fugitives prior to that; examples include the Lattimore war in the 1840s. But at the same time they had not had the concerted weight of the federal government pursuing a pro-slavery political project in this way. The Fugitive Slave Law of 1850 signals to African Americans that the Federal Government has abandoned whatever ambivalence had characterized it at some point. And instead has decided to become active agents for slaveholders
column3: and that is really threatening. It warns a fair number of far-sighted African American intellectuals that the Dred Scott decision is coming. Martin Delany as early as 1854
column4: remarks
column5: ""forget these personal liberty laws
column6: our fate is in the hands of the federal government
column7: that is where the fate of our liberties will be decided."" That turns out to be true. So
column8: it is hard to overstate the importance of the Fugitive Slave law
column9: it causes some people to flee
column10: it forces others to become more militant. It ignites the political crisis of the 1850s
column11: and it accelerates the spiral from Kansas/Nebraska
column12: to Bleeding Kansas
column13: to John Brown
column14: to the beginning of the war itself.

column1: CWBR: Speaking of militant
column2: when the war finally does come we have this popular picture of free African Americans pushing to join the army
column3: and help fight for freedom. However
column4: is that the case 100%
column5: in at least the North or in Boston. What issues did the free African American community of Boston have with joining the army
column6: based on what their idea of citizenship was?

column1: SK: So
column2: when recruitment begins for the 54th and later the 55th and the 5th cavalry
column3: black Bostonians bring to that effort their own history with military recruitment. For them
column4: the last ten years have been crucial because for ten years black Bostonians have been trying to establish a black unit of the state militia
column5: with black officers accredited and admitted and enrolled in the militia in the same way as any other unit. That is
column6: enrolled on the terms of perfect equality with other units. That fits with their whole idea that engagement as citizens of the American nation requires a transformation of the American nation so that it abandons its commitment to whiteness. For example
column7: they are not only asking to be chartered as a unit of the state militia they want the want the state to remove the word white from its state militia law. That is a key feature here
column8: which the state won't do
column9: because that is part of federal law.  So
column10: they run up against this over and over again
column11: and in frustration their militia movement collapses and they never march and it is a kind of a fiasco. It is not a fiasco though at the end of the day
column12: because what it does is it sets the table for the conversation at the end of the day that happens in 1863
column13: and that conversation says: it is great that the Union has decided to honor our desire to serve against the slaveholders
column14: but it has to be on terms of equality. Initially they think they are going to be offered the same pay as white soldiers
column15: they are promised that in the recruiting for the 54th. People like Robert Morrison and John DeGrasse go to the governor and say: we need to have black officers appointed. Governor Andrew approaches the War Department
column16: and is told in no uncertain terms this will not happen. Faced with a situation where they are not going to treated as equals
column17: where they can't have black officers
column18: black units will be led by white officers
column19: Morrison and his friends say nope we are not going. The proof is in the pudding here
column20: the commitment of black Bostonians is not universal but it is strong enough when the 54th marches through Boston on its way to South Carolina in the spring of 1863
column21: there is nearly 1000 men marching through the streets but only about 40 of them declare Boston as their hometown. Compare that to the initial movement to form a home guard to defend Massachusetts at the moment of secession in 1861.  In one night they get 125 men to sign up
column22: here they had weeks
column23: and weeks to recruit and they only had about 40. That tells the story
column24: as for equality a lot of people simply aren't willing to serve
column25: and when it turns out they are going to be paid as military laborers
column26: and not private soldiers
column27: many of them think twice about what they have done. Some of them have to be sent home
column28: they strike for pay. When the state of Massachusetts offers to make up the difference in pay they say that won't do. The Federal Government has to recognize our equal service with equal pay
column29: if we take extra pay from Massachusetts it makes it look like the money is the point
column30: of course the money is not the point
column31: the principle is the point. By 1864
column32: Congress ends up passing the Equalization Act
column33: ultimately pay is pretty much equalized for everybody. They do win that fight
column34: but it really is a painful struggle though.

column1: CWBR: When the war ends slavery ends
column2: now the struggle for citizenship though has really just begun. What did the activists in Boston hope to accomplish in a world without slavery
column3: and how well were they able to reach out to their newly free southern brethren and help and tie together with them this push for Citizenship?

column1: SK: This is where the great disappointment of their story begins. Neither the effort to build on their wartime victory
column2: and on the early constitutional amendments
column3: or the outreach to the newly free people bears the kind of fruit that they thought it would. The 13th
column4: 14th
column5: and 15th Amendments are transcendentally important.  They understand how important these things are to ending slavery
column6: and national path to citizenship
column7: and there cannot be racial discrimination in obtaining the franchise. Few things can be as important as these
column8: they also see the limits of them.  Some of the people in this world oppose the ratification of the 14th Amendment because it doesn't go far enough. It does allow southern states to continue discrimination against the right to vote
column9: if they are willing to pay the penalty of a proportional reduction of representation in Congress. That seems like a total betrayal to people like Edwin Garrison Walker. The 15th Amendment likewise
column10: a lot of these folks believed that should have included women too. Many black activists in the Boston community
column11: men and women
column12: are some of the best women's rights advocates in the United States. They are very disappointed to see the 15th Amendment go forward
column13: for not speaking about sex as well as race. They are also disappointed that the right to vote might not be limited on the basis of race
column14: as opposed to an affirmative right to vote. What happens quickly thereafter
column15: black Northerners find themselves marginalized and treated as second class citizens
column16: in much the same way as black Southerners are experiencing. They are described as mob like and incapable
column17: as really not quite ready for the full exercises and privileges of citizenship. When it comes to the freed people
column18: I think black Northerners because of the power of their vision and the power of their literacy
column19: because of their institutions initially feel as though they are going to shape freedom. They are going to teach the free people how to live as citizens rather than slaves. But the free people have ideas of their own. They have not grown up in an institutional framework
column20: have not grown up under constitutions
column21: they live in a different cultural and political world. So
column22: it is very difficult for
column23: say
column24: ministers who have been trained in the North
column25: or for that matter Masonic organizers
column26: to use the same tools that they used in the North to build political or cultural institutions in the South. Although they often rise to prominence in southern Reconstruction politics
column27: they don't build the same world that they had lived in in the North. It is just not possible
column28: in terms of life
column29: in terms of labor. The violence of the labor struggle in the South are just too different from what they know. It is a story of surprises and disappointments.

column1: CWBR: Professor Kantrowitz
column2: I appreciate you taking the time to discuss your most recent work
column3: <i>More than Freedom: Fighting for Black Citizenship in a White Republic
column4: 1829-1889. Thank you for joining us today.

column1:
SK: It has been a great pleasure.

" Frawley
column2: Michael Summer 2013 2013-08-01 Interview Penguin Press "" ""

column1:
5668 9780199751716 $27.95 CWBR Author Interview:
Appomattox: Victory
column2: Defeat
column3: and Freedom at the End of the Civil War		Varon
column4: Elizabeth R.			"<h3>Interview with Elizabeth Varon
column5: the Langbourne M. Williams Professor of American History at the University of Virginia

column1: Interviewed by Michael Frawley
Click here for the review
Civil War Book Review (CWBR): Today the Civil War Book Review is proud to speak with Elizabeth Varon
column2: the Langbourne M. Williams Professor of American History at the University of Virginia
column3: and discuss her recent book <i>Appomattox: Victory
column4: Defeat
column5: and Freedom at the End of the Civil War. Thank you for joining us today.

column1: Elizabeth Varon (EV): It is a delight to do so
column2: thank you.

column1: CWBR: What drew you to this topic?
EV: Well
column2: some years ago
column3: I was asked by the Library Company of Philadelphia to give a talk about Juneteenth:  the moment of emancipation in Texas.  And in the course of researching Juneteenth
column4: I kept running across references in African-American discourse
column5: spanning the immediate post-war era right up through the early 20th Century
column6: to Appomattox as a “freedom day
column7: ” commemorated as sort of a hallmark in the process of emancipation. Those references alluded to an image of Appomattox as a day of liberation for slaves--the exact moment of emancipation
column8: for many…the day that fulfilled the promises of the earlier Emancipation Proclamation
column9: the day that some slaves knew for the first time that they were free
column10: or that others were able to truly experience freedom for the first time
column11: now that the principal institution of the Confederacy
column12: Lee's army
column13: had met its demise.  It was also a day
column14: in African American commemoration
column15: of black liberation at the hands of African American liberators.  This was a key element to the remembrance of the day:   seven regiments of the United States Colored Troops had participated in the final campaign that culminated in Lee's surrender.  They had been instrumental in blocking Lee's escape route
column16: setting the trap that Lee tried
column17: unsuccessfully
column18: to punch a hole through on the morning of April 9. This was understood to have an enormous symbolic importance in the eyes of commentators.  We can see this in African American sermons and speeches
column19: including the landmark studies of George Washington Williams
column20: the eminent historian who was a veteran of the Appomattox campaign:   the treatment of Appomattox as a freedom day
column21: and as a day that proved the fitness of the free people for citizenship.   In this post war discourse on Appomattox
column22: there was an effort to fuse the emancipationist and reconciliationist modes of Civil War remembrance
column23: to argue that the Union victory (and the centrality of African Americans to the Union's victory) were proof of the fitness for citizenship of the freedpeople
column24: and also a moment that heralded a promise of interracial reconciliation. For me
column25: this discovery drew me towards the surrender. And my preliminary research confirmed that our dominant view of the surrender as a “gentlemen's agreement” does not do justice to the complex meaning and legacy of this event.

column1: CWBR: Why was the campaign that led to Appomattox just as important as the surrender itself?
EV: That's right. There has been a tendency
column2: a temptation
column3: to think of that last campaign as a postscript to the great decisive “turning points” of the war. But that was not how the men who participated in the campaign saw it. They believed that the fate of the war effort still hung in the balance in those early days of April 1865. For men on the Union side
column4: it wasn't just the fact of their victory but the way they had won it that loomed large. They would emphasize
column5: in their accounts
column6: that it took enormous skill and courage and discipline to chase down Lee's army
column7: in those last days. For African Americans
column8: the campaign had an additional level of symbolic meaning. Confederates
column9: by contrast
column10: are grappling at the moment of defeat with two competing narratives of these final days of fighting. One of those narratives
column11: enshrined in Lee's Farwell Address
column12: stresses the steadfastness and blamelessness of Lee's men in this moment of defeat. The other narrative
column13: however
column14: is a far more troubling narrative for Confederates. It is a story
column15: perhaps
column16: of a failure of will
column17: and tactical and strategic mistakes
column18: of disillusionment and desertion and disintegration. This is a story that is unbearable for Confederates. It leaves them vulnerable to self-doubt and recrimination
column19: and so we see them push it to the side
column20: and to instead enshrine the story encapsulated in Lee's Farewell Address:  the story of the Confederates having been overwhelmed by the brutal Yankee war machine
column21: a story that fixates on the issue of odds. The Confederates will claim that they faced
column22: in the end
column23: during that last week and on the morning of April 9
column24: in particular
column25: worse odds than they had ever faced before in the war--odds of five to one or even worse--and that those terrible odds had necessitated Lee's surrender.

column1: CWBR: So the ratio of Union to Confederate soldiers at Appomattox was extremely important to how Reconstruction developed?

EV: A numbers game emerges and it has profound political implications. So--we can establish in hindsight that there were roughly thirty thousand Confederates and roughly sixty thousand Union troops in the vicinity of Appomattox Courthouse on that last day on April 9. The Confederates will claim
column2: following Lee's lead
column3: that they had faced much worse odds
column4: in the end:  again
column5: odds of five to one or worse
column6: rather than two to one. (Lee had often beaten odds two to one earlier in the war.) They will claim that
column7: in the end
column8: they had only the eight thousand effective infantrymen that were really ready to fight--and that they faced a Yankee army of one hundred to two hundred thousand
column9: and more
column10: and so on. My point in the book is that Lee's reference in his Farewell Address to the “overwhelming numbers and resources” of the Yankees was political
column11: and has to be put in the context of Confederate ideology:   that the numbers game had political implications. For Confederates
column12: “numbers”--the very phrase--conjured up images of the Yankee army's ruthless mercenaries and hirelings. “Resources” conjured up the dark satanic mills of northern capitalists. The numbers game
column13: in other words
column14: was part and parcel of an indictment of the North
column15: an indictment that had its roots in proslavery and secessionist ideology
column16: and that was translated during the war into the charge that the Yankees did not fight fair.  This was important politically because Lee knew
column17: as those who rallied around his “overwhelming numbers” interpretation of Confederate defeat knew
column18: that by denying the legitimacy of the North's military victory
column19: they could deny the North the right to impose its political will on the South after the war.

column1: CWBR: So
column2: as the importance of the surrender document
column3: Lee's Farewell Address
column4: the correspondence between Lee and Grant
column5: and other writings show
column6: during the Appomattox campaign itself the war shifted from one of bullets to one of words.

column1: EV: Yes and no. I do think the war effectively ends at Appomattox. We will sometimes use war as a metaphor to describe the political battles of the postwar period--and we should be careful not to push that too far. The surrender does end the massive bloodletting of these two giant armies; although there is fighting after Appomattox and the surrenders that follow in its wake
column2: the hopes for Confederate independence
column3: I think
column4: died at Appomattox. In some important sense
column5: the war ends. But a war of words does begin. You are right about that. A big argument of my book is that we tend to see the artifacts of the surrender--the letters Lee and Grant exchanged
column6: the terms themselves
column7: the parole passes that are issued to Confederates
column8: the Farewell Address of Lee--we tend to see these things as transparent in meaning. I am trying to make the case that these artifacts of the surrender as all sources of contention. The parole passes are sort of a perfect case in point
column9: speaking about this emerging war of words. So Lee and Grant meet a second time on April 10. Lee requests of Grant that each of Lee's men be issued a printed parole certificate confirming that that soldier came under the Appomattox terms. Grant accedes to this request.  Grant does so in part because he imagines that these certificates will remind the Confederates of the obligations attendant upon their status as paroled prisoners of war--that is what they are-- and remind them that their freedom was contingent on their good behavior. The parole passes contain a clause that ends up becoming quite a troublesome clause. In keeping with the language of the terms themselves
column10: the parole certificates vouch that if a soldier observes the law where he resides
column11: then that soldier was not to be “disturbed.” While Union men imagined that these parole certificates would be a reminder of their obligations
column12: the Confederates interpreted the parole certificates
column13: and the very language in them--the not to be disturbed clause in particular--as a kind of promise that honorable Confederate men would not be treated dishonorably but the Yankees. In other words
column14: the paroles
column15: in Confederate eyes
column16: imposed conditions on the North.

column1: CWBR: Lee has come down to us today as a person who stayed out of politics after the war
column2: clearly though this was not the case
column3: why is our perception so different from reality?

column1: EV: Our perception is grounded in two facts. First of all
column2: Lee did technically observe the terms of his parole.  And he did accept military defeat and reject the option of guerrilla warfare.  But we miss the subtlety and dissonance in Lee's post war comportment
column3: and I think generally it is underrated how political a man and how savvy a man Lee was. Lee was not a symbol of submission in the eyes of Confederates after the war. He was a symbol of defiance. In all of the artifacts to which I have alluded
column4: and also in a postwar interview that he does with the New York Herald
column5: and congressional testimony he gives in February of 1866
column6: Lee is pointing the way to the restoration of the South's power within the Union. Restoration is Lee's political keyword. For him it reflects the nostalgia
column7: not uncommon for the men of his background
column8: nostalgia for the days of the early republic
column9: which in his mind are halcyon days before the Union had fallen from grace
column10: before African Americans had been imbued with false hope--a time when the rest of the nation seemed to assume that Virginia would lead the nation. Lee was nostalgic for this kind of imaginary period of equilibrium. In his mind
column11: a just peace will undo the “grievous effects” of the war
column12: as he puts it
column13: and sort of restore the old virtues. Now
column14: in the service of this vision of restoration
column15: Lee behaves politically. He denies the existence of anti-black violence in the South. He makes this denial quite brazenly as he testifies before the congressional committee. In his interview with the New York Herald
column16: he essentially argues that if the North gives up the policy of magnanimity—if it turns to vengeance or to vindictive or arbitrary policies--Southerners would consider the surrender terms as breached.   Indeed there is this notion
column17: I think
column18: on the part of Confederates
column19: that Lee had drawn a line in the sand at Appomattox--that Lee's position was
column20: ""You can ask us to surrender our arms
column21: but you shouldn't ask anything more from us. We will yield
column22: but we will do nothing more."" This is a sort of defiance
column23: and again we can come back to the artifacts of the surrender. The parole passes
column24: that “not to be disturbed” clause
column25: will reverberate in political debates. As Republicans will try to give freedpeople a measure of civil rights and civil protections
column26: and begin discussing the possibility of African American suffrage
column27: Confederates will turn to them and say that this radical agenda is a contravention of the Appomattox covenant
column28: if you will--of the promise that white southern men will not be disturbed. They will literally say the prospect of black citizenship “disturbs” the South and therefore represents a betrayal of the Appomattox terms. There is a very complex political dynamic here. My point is that the terms and the artifacts of the surrender were a touchstone for these political debates during Reconstruction and that Lee is very much implicated in these debates.

column1: CWBR: Grant and Lee then were representative of their societies
column2: one looking to the future and the other to the past?

column1: EV: I think that that is right. Grant has an entirely different interpretation of the surrender than Lee does. In Lee's mind
column2: the surrender was a negotiation in which he secures honorable terms for his blameless men. In Grant's eyes
column3: the surrender is a vindication of the cause of Union
column4: of the ability of citizen-soldiers to out fight the conscripts and dupes of an autocratic society. It is a vindication of freedom:  and it will clear and open the way for the Union's ethos of moral and material progress to enter the South. Grant's terms are very much intended to effect a sort of mass conversion on the part of Southerners. He believes that the terms should foster a spirit of repentance and atonement. Again
column5: Lee's position was that the Southerners had nothing to atone for. Grant's position was that the Union's magnanimity and its mercy were emblems of its moral authority
column6: its moral superiority even
column7: and that mercy should effect atonement and repentance. These are fundamentally different views
column8: but in the book I stress that these debates over the terms don’t simply pit Union against Confederacy or North versus South. They pit those who favor a transformation of the South against those who oppose it
column9: and you will find Northerners and Southerners on both sides of that divide. The Peace Democrats
column10: for example
column11: “Copperheads” in the North
column12: are loath for the Lincoln administration
column13: Republicans
column14: to interpret the surrender as a mandate for the Republican party.  So the Copperheads embrace Lee's interpretation of the surrender:  the “overwhelming numbers” interpretation of Southern defeat
column15: Lee's notion that the Union victory was a victory of might over right. Southern Unionists
column16: African Americans obviously
column17: and some white southern Unionists
column18: too
column19: embrace Grant's view of the surrender:  the Union victory as a victory of right over wrong.  So we see fault lines
column20: but we have to be very careful when acknowledging divisions within each society.

column1: CWBR: Did the assassination of Lincoln magnify the meaning of Appomattox and make it much more important than it would have been had Lincoln lived?
EV: My emphasis
column2: in a sense
column3: in regard to the assassination
column4: is on continuity. I try to show the heated debate about the meaning of the surrender begins before Lincoln died. Its interpretive lines persist after his death. If we look at Civil War historiography
column5: we can see quite plainly that the assassination has utterly overshadowed the surrender. There has been an assumption in studying the assassination that Booth turns Northerners away from magnanimity and towards vengeance. I found something a little different. First of all
column6: Northerners interpret the assassination as a direct response to the surrender. They believe that Booth is trying
column7: through his deed
column8: to undo or undermine the Union victory. We do see many Northerners call for vengeance in the wake of the assassination
column9: but we see many others
column10: in a sort of call-and-response
column11: answer that cry for vengeance by upholding magnanimity and mercy--Lincoln's policy
column12: Grant's policy--on the grounds that the best way to honor Lincoln's death is to uphold this idea of mercy. In other words
column13: this notion that mercy was an emblem of the North's moral authority proves very potent and popular
column14: and I found that was true even among Radical Republicans
column15: many of whom thought the best fate for the likes of Jefferson Davis and Robert E. Lee was to have to live in the brave new world that the Union victory has created.

column1: CWBR: Why did Appomattox become a ""golden moment lost"" so quickly? Was there any real chance it was the golden moment many hoped it was?

EV: This “golden moment lost” phenomenon is really quite fascinating. Each of the three interpretations that I just outlined--the notion of the surrender as a vindication; the emphasis on the part of Southerners like Lee on restoration; and then the variation on vindication
column2: the emphasis of African Americans on liberation--each of these interpretive modes came to incorporate an argument about the lost promise of Appomattox. For Lee and his followers
column3: as I have suggested
column4: Radical Republicans betray the true meaning of the surrender by imposing a regime that contravenes the promise that southerners won’t be “disturbed.” For Grant and his followers
column5: it is Andrew Johnson who is the arch betrayer
column6: as he seems to capitulate to Lee's idea that the peace must bring the restoration of power to elite southerners. In the eyes of African Americans
column7: whites on both sides--both those who oppose and reject black citizenship but also those who give up the fight for it--let this moment of promise
column8: of Appomattox
column9: fade unfulfilled. I am trying to make two arguments about this. First of all I am asserting that there is never a moment of unity in this story. There is never a moment of shared reconciliation. There is never a moment when Southerners in unison mourn their lost cause and northerners in unison rejoice. There is never a moment in which Confederates are prepared to concede that their ideology has been discredited. In essence
column10: Northerners who embrace Grant's terms said to the South
column11: ""We don’t want to punish you any further
column12: we want you to change."" Southerners
column13: Confederates
column14: turned back and argued that the demand for change was a form of punishment. Northerners said “here is your chance to atone
column15: ” and Confederates responded that they had nothing to atone for. I don’t see much evidence of a true golden moment there. The battle lines were drawn very quickly. The terms became politicized very quickly. On the other hand
column16: I am trying to account for why the golden moment interpretation
column17: despite the fact that it was kind of wishful thinking
column18: why it had such power and resilience.  I observe that it tapped a strain of American exceptionalism:  that even as they grappled over the surrender terms
column19: Northerners and Southerners could
column20: and did
column21: congratulate themselves for ending their Civil War in a more civil way than any other nation had ever done before. I also try to account in other ways for the resilience of this golden moment idea. I stress
column22: for example
column23: as I have stressed in our talk here today
column24: that African Americans have had their own reasons for upholding the surrender as a golden moment. They believed that they had
column25: at the moment of the surrender
column26: won something
column27: and earned something
column28: and proven something that should never be taken away. So all of the various stakeholders had their own reasons for being intensely invested in the idea of the golden moment--and for charging their political rivals was having betrayed it.

column1: CWBR: Professor Varon
column2: I appreciate you taking the time to sit and discuss your most recent work
column3: Appomattox: Victory
column4: Defeat
column5:
and Freedom at the End of the Civil War.

" Frawley
column6: Michael Winter 2014 2014-02-01 Interview Oxford University Press "" "Click here for the audio version of the interview"

column1:
5737 978-1-4696-1076-4 $39.95 CWBR Author Interview:
Nature's Civil War: Common Soldiers and the Environment in 1862 Virginia Meier
column2: Kathryn Shively			"<h3>Interview with Kathryn Shively Meier
column3: Assistant Professor of History at Virginia Commonwealth University

column1: Interviewed by Michael Frawley
Click here for the review
Civil War Book Review (CWBR): Today the Civil War Book Review is proud to speak with Kathryn Shively Meier
column2: an Assistant professor of History at Virginia Commonwealth University
column3: and discuss her recent book Nature's Civil War: Common Soldiers and the Environment in 1862 Virginia. Thank you for joining us today.

column1: Kathryn Shively Meier (KM): Thank you for having me.
CWBR: What first brought you to this topic?
KM: In reading Civil War common soldier accounts
column2: their letters
column3: diaries
column4: memoirs
column5: I quickly noticed that soldiers discussed nature all the time giving
column6: what seemed like
column7: daily accounts of weather
column8: climate
column9: flora
column10: and fauna. But scholars have never really analyzed why
column11: and I began to wonder if there was more to it than simply bored farmers just sitting around looking at their environment. So when I started investigating it a little more closely
column12: I realized that soldiers believed that environment was responsible for some of the deadly diseases that they were facing. For instance
column13: they believed miasma
column14: bad water
column15: seasonal shifts
column16: the southern climate were causing things like diarrhea and dysentery
column17: and those two were the top killers of the war
column18: as well as some others like malaria and typhoid. And further
column19: a variety of mental unfortunates
column20: like melancholy
column21: home sickness
column22: loneliness. The ending of the Civil War
column23: of all of the mortalities
column24: 2/3 of them would be from disease and yet most scholarly medical histories have been focusing on battle wounds. Also
column25: they had mainly been focused on the top down
column26: like medical personnel
column27: rather than the soldiers themselves. So ultimately
column28: I decided I wanted to focus on mental and physical health through the eyes of the soldiers in this war.

column1: CWBR: What were the challenges you faced in doing your research?
KM: Actually one of the problems was a good problem
column2: which was an overabundance of sources
column3: because as anyone who has read Civil War soldiers’ accounts knows nearly every soldier in this environment and health. So it was the opposite of the needle-in-a-haystack type of research. Which is why it ultimately shows to do a case study. But sort of a problem that I had
column4: and this was one of bigger problems
column5: was in charting mental health because official records really only recorded the most severe mental illness. So things like insanity
column6: suicide
column7: and what was contemporarily called nostalgia
column8: which was a potential deadly case of home sickness. So in order to gain a nuance understanding of soldier's mental landscapes and how they were influenced by the environment
column9: I had to take a more in-depth approach rather than a broad approach. My core study ended up being just a couple hundred individual soldiers because I had to literally map out their daily moves over a course of a year
column10: which I did in an Excel spreadsheet
column11: and I charted each time a man mentioned being melancholy or happy or even when he did not mention it but you could discern the mood shifts in his writing
column12: and I had to figure out why that was happening. Was it linked to weather? Or health? To losing his friends to disease? etc. Ultimately I knew that morale shifts had serious consequences for Army operations because you could see that a soldier who had very low morale starts to unravel
column13: deserts
column14: disobeys orders
column15: drink
column16: and just performs poorly in his job. So I did the same technique then for physical illnesses as well. Even though there are official records
column17: which are much better on the U.S. side than the Confederate side
column18: for physical health
column19: those records are really spotty because the way soldiers reported to sick call in the morning. Looking at their daily physical landscapes as well
column20: I saw how sick they really were. It was very rare to find a soldier that wasn’t suffering from diarrhea nearly every day. The picture that emerged for me was an army that was really struggling to stay well enough to just be minimally adequate to the grueling task of soldiering every day.

column1: CWBR: So
column2: what was the state of medical care and knowledge before the war and did this play an important role in how soldiers dealt with their environment during the war?

column1: KM: The state of medical care before the war is best described as chaotic. The Civil War occurred a decade before the discovery of germ theory and about two decades before the discovery of insect-borne illness. Medical profession was not very much influx before the war
column2: as traditional surgeons were still clinging to humoral theory
column3: the idea that the body was made up of fluids in need of balancing and they do so by what we call heroic interventions
column4: these dramatic interventions to balance these fluids. Bleeding
column5: purging
column6: high doses of often mercury based medicine. Some of this was beginning to fall out of favor
column7: but this was still the mainstream of medicine. But for people who become soldiers
column8: they have fairly little experience with professional doctors before the war
column9: and very little experience with hospitals. The preferred being treated at home by family members
column10: usually women. They tended to believe that disease was caused by observable things they could see and feel
column11: so environmental factors. For instance
column12: there was a widely held fear that the South was a more harmful disease environment
column13: and if you lived there you would have to undergo a process of seasoning in order to adjust. So the soldiers who went to war in 1861 and 1862 were products of an antebellum culture that was on one hand suspicious of professional medical care
column14: and on the other hand emphasized self-reliance and environmental explanations of disease. One of the interesting things
column15: at the beginning of the war there were a whole lot of Confederate posturing at how maybe the Yankees would come down South and all die in the southern swamps. Under the circumstances of Army life where you have 50
column16: 000 to over 100
column17: 000 men living together in mobile cities without infrastructures. Well the truth was they all got sick. Virginia was changed by war to become hospital disease environment for everyone. There were dead bodies everywhere
column18: polluted water sources
column19: landscapes ripped up from combat and mobilization. A lot of their pre-held beliefs were tested. Many had assumed that hearty country boys would spare them in the harsh environment of war. Early on
column20: it was city men who spared best because they had already been exposed to crowd diseases when they were young like scarlet fever. So
column21: a lot of conceptions were tested when they went to war.

column1: CWBR: The campaigns you cover in your work are very different
column2: how did each area present environmental challenges to soldiers and how did they deal with these challenges?

column1: KM: So I chose the 1862 Virginia Peninsula and Shenandoah Valley Campaign because they were concurrent and overlapped. Also
column2: because contemporaries viewed these two locations as very different environments. They viewed the peninsula as deadly because of its swamps
column3: and they viewed the valley as hostile because it was mountainous and famous for its beautiful hot springs. The areas were challenging to soldiers in slightly different ways. The valley had more extreme weather shifts
column4: particularly in the spring season. The campaign there required a very quick and grueling case of marching
column5: particularly for the Confederates under Stonewall Jackson. The peninsula alternately took place in swampy areas. It was really bad water
column6: and the pace of the campaign was much slower. Soldiers on both sides were stagnant. The peninsula was more taxing to health in the summer because of the swarms of mosquitoes that spread malaria. The soldiers thought that malaria was being caused by swamp miasma. Even though the campaigns were different and the areas were different
column7: the soldiers protected their mental and physical health in virtually identical ways and diverse locations. Using what I term in the book as self-care. These are techniques to combat environmental causes of disease and mental illness. So things like boiling water
column8: bathing frequently
column9: foraging for fruits and vegetables
column10: eradicating insects
column11: constructing protective shelters
column12: etc. These techniques helped them stay physically healthier but also boosted their morale. The main variation of locations when it came to self-care actually had to do with the pace of the campaign rather than the environment itself. For instance
column13: if you are camping in one area for a while
column14: a soldier could rig a better tent construction to keep it dry and drain his camp of moisture by laying down sand
column15: and that would keep away mosquitoes. However
column16: if you were in an area for a long time that would mean your water source would get fouled from having thousands of soldiers defecating
column17: washing
column18: and touching all in one place. So that is an advantage to a fast pace campaign
column19: so that you avoid the buildup of filth
column20: if you will.

column1: CWBR: How good was the medical care apparatus of each army and how did soldiers react to the care officialdom tried to impose on them?
KM: The state of medical care in 1862 was not so good. However
column2: on both sides it was starting to improve. When the war broke out
column3: soldiers were forced into this official system that was really different from what they had known in the antebellum era. For instance
column4: army surgeons often labeled them lingerers because the men were so sick so often that it seems implausible essentially to surgeons. When soldiers were treated
column5: they despised the medicine they received
column6: these heroic interventions
column7: because they felt these medicines actually made them sicker. Then they were terrified to go to the hospitals because they were unfamiliar with hospitals in general and didn’t want to be treated by strangers. The least of what they had seen in the ranks were the majority of the regiments commanding them to come back home because of how the volunteers in the civil war were raised. So the consequence of this was that soldiers often avoided the official care offered by the medical department
column8: or they supplemented it on their own by addressing what they believed to be the cause of these diseases
column9: environment. They developed their own unofficial networks of care with comrades
column10: civilians around the war front
column11: and the ones back home to provide nursing
column12: comfortable beds to recover in
column13: and also to receive supplies and advice about how to care for their health.

column1: CWBR: Seasoning is something that almost all military histories talk of
column2: but
column3: in your view
column4: what is seasoning and how did the environment play a role?

column1: KM: The traditional military view of seasoning is that citizen soldiers have to undergo a shift being a civilian to learning how to endure combat. Scholars like Earl Hess are fantastic on that type of seasoning. Then there is also another type of seasoning that is recognized by scholars like Joseph Blatter
column2: which is a phase when newer recruits first join an army and somewhere around 50% of them become sick with crowd diseases. That is important because America was so rural at the time. Joining the Army was like moving to the city
column3: but with closer quarters and no infrastructures. In addition to those two phases
column4: I see another
column5: and that is after the initial influx of crowd diseases taxes
column6: soldiers succumb to a phase of environmental seasoning
column7: which would tax physical and mental health during the daily grind of soldiering. This is the phase where they learn to endure days
column8: weeks
column9: months outside with very little shelter
column10: very little food
column11: marching 10-20 miles a day before you found pass and these are little guys
column12: like 135 pounds on average. This was an active process of becoming seasoned to the hardships. Some soldiers practiced self-care and became mentally and physically tough
column13: while others really floundered becoming despondent and often very ill and dying.

column1: CWBR: Again
column2: straggling is something important to commanders and military historians
column3: could you explain though why it was important to soldiers' self-care?

column1: KM: Commonly in the Civil War
column2: straggling is conflated with desertion
column3: which preserves a command bias from the time of the war. I think it is very important to draw distinction between temporary abandonment to one unit with the intent to return versus a permanent abandonment. There were many reasons to straggle
column4: but I looked at a reason for the practice that wasn’t covered by the literature before and that is the men often straggled to practice self-care. When they became ill or despondent or the environmental burden of soldiering was too much to bare
column5: they would often slip out of the ranks to seek shelter and recover maybe for just a night or two or sometimes for a little bit longer. In some cases they would actually seek out civilians to care for them; give them a bed to sleep in
column6: give them food. Other cases of straggling for self-care was when rations were really poor.  For instance
column7: they were not being issued fruits and vegetables. Sometimes soldiers would straggle for forage. This helped to prevent scabies. In other cases
column8: if they were not being ordered to bathe frequently enough
column9: which happened on Stonewall Jackson's Valley Campaign
column10: they straggled to find clean water to bathe and keep clean and to drink. From the soldier perspective
column11: straggling could be just the key to staying healthy enough to continue on. But
column12: of course
column13: from the command perspective
column14: generals didn’t really consider that there were benefits to straggling. To them it meant and absence of available men to his campaign. It meant that the discipline in their army was poor. There is this kind of divide between the soldiers and generals here when it came to viewing straggling. Straggling became so pervasive over the course of 1862 that the medical departments were still so weak that command on both sides became to really crack down on the practice as the year went on
column15: and impose torturous penalties. To give a few examples: Stonewall Jackson had four men court marshaled and executed as deserters
column16: who claim they had only been straggling to serve the example because straggling was so bad in his army. Then
column17: I say the most effective punishment in serving straggling was probably just restricting pay. By the end of the years
column18: straggling had somewhat evaded.

column1: CWBR: How did what soldiers and the army learned during these two campaigns effect medical care and reactions to the environment in the rest of the war?

KM: Soldiers continue to practice self-care throughout the war. Discipline did improve straggling and it was evaded. Both sides learned that their medical systems were inadequate to the task of caring for these massive armies
column2: and went about improving hospitals
column3: supplies
column4: rations
column5: etc. The U.S. really had an advantage with the intervention with the U.S. Sanitary Commission who had been investigating soldier camps and making recommendations for improved sanitation and environmental management. As well as providing supplies and nurses since the beginning of the war. In the Army of Potomac
column6: the Union Army looked at a new medical director
column7: Jonathan Letterman
column8: who came in and addressed problems like ambulance evacuation to considerable affects starting in July of 1962. In the end
column9: the Civil War had a much better track record than the Mexican-American War in terms of mortality due to disease. In the Mexican-American War
column10: 80% of mortalities had been from disease and in this war
column11: only 66% by war's end. However
column12: I would argue that it remains very much due to credit of the soldiers themselves and the individual decisions they made caring for one another
column13: and adapt to the environment of war. They were able to mentally and physically preserve here.

column1: CWBR: Professor Meier
column2: I appreciate you taking the time to sit and discuss your most recent work
column3:
Nature's Civil War: Common Soldiers and the Environment in 1862 Virginia.

" Frawley
column4: Michael Spring 2014 2014-05-01 Interview University of North Carolina Press "" ""

column1:
5801 978-1-4696-1085-6 $34.95 CWBR Author Interview:
Washington Brotherhood: Politics
column2: Social Life
column3: and the Coming of the Civil War		Shelden
column4: Rachel			"<h3>Interview with Rachel Shelden
column5: Assistant Professor of History at the University of Oklahoma

column1: Interviewed by Zach Isenhower
Click here for the review
Civil War Book Review (CWBR): Today the Civil War Book Review is proud to speak with Rachel Shelden
column2: Assistant Professor of History at the University of Oklahoma
column3: and discuss her recent book <i>Washington Brotherhood: Politics
column4: Social Life
column5: and the Coming of the Civil War. Thank you for joining us today.

column1: Rachel Shelden (RS): Thanks so much for having me.
CWBR: For starters
column2: I'd like to know what first brought you to the topic?

column1: RS: Well it's a great question. I started this project as my dissertation at the University of Virginia
column2: and I had been interested in Washington politics for quite some time.  I had worked for the Library Congress before going to graduate school
column3: and I was very interested in the way that people interacted in Washington
column4: and the difference in the culture of Washington from the inside and Washington from the outside (having not grown up in Washington
column5: I'm originally from Chicago).  So
column6: that was something that really struck me while I was living there
column7: and I was working on a history of the House of Representatives
column8: and I noticed that this was something that was very big in the nineteenth century
column9: this sort of culture of Washington
column10: and this was something that I wanted to pursue long-term.  So although I actually came to the topic a little bit later in graduate school
column11: it was something that was bubbling in my mind for a long time.

column1: CWBR: You say that this was a problem that was very big in the nineteenth century--I'm sure some people would say that it's a problem that hasn't gone away--so what were some of the challenges then
column2: of exposing the nature of that disconnect
column3: and sort of the true culture of Washington when you're talking about people who have a very vested interest in projecting a certain kind of image and a certain kind of rhetoric and representation
column4: when perhaps there's something else beneath the surface.

column1: RS: I think that's something we've struggled with for a very long time. As historians
column2: we have a lot of faith in the documents that we work with
column3: and we worked with the Congressional Globe
column4: which is the official record of the U.S. Congress in the nineteenth century--for most of the nineteenth century.  We had great faith in the Congressional Globe to be able to tell us what was going on in Washington and the ways that politicians engaged in thinking about the major political issues of the period.  And there were no real indicators as to why the Congressional Globe wouldn't have given us a straightforward answer to the ways that people thought and the way they behaved.  But I discovered more and more as I was reading about the politicians and reading their letters and reading—particularly their letters back home to their families—that they didn't have much trust in the Congressional Globe to tell them what was really going on because they didn't pay much attention to the speeches in Washington.  So the more that I sort of peeled back the layers of the Congressional Globe
column5: the more I could tell that it wasn't actually representative of what politicians thought in terms of getting policy forward in the process of politicking in the nineteenth century.  So
column6: I think it's a challenge because
column7: as we all know
column8: as all historians deal with
column9: our sources can only take us so far.  They are only a small portion of what exists out there in terms of what was actually going on.  I had to dig deep to find references
column10: usually not long stories
column11: to the kind of politicking that happened outside the halls of the capital
column12: at places like boarding houses and dinners and parties
column13: and meetings of various associations in Washington.  That was a challenge
column14: but I could tell that something was really not quite right there.

column1: CWBR: So
column2: really then
column3: most of the political discussions that mattered the most in reality
column4: you would say
column5: were the ones that took place outside of the halls of Congress?

column1: RS: That mattered to policy making. I would never say that the Congressional Globe was non-important in terms of understanding what was going in the rest of the country
column2: because in a lot of ways
column3: the Congressional Globe was very much representative of what constituents wanted to hear.  That’s who these people were talking to when they were speaking in the halls of Congress.  They wanted their constituents back in Massachusetts and South Carolina and Kentucky and Louisiana to actually hear what they wanted to hear.  It was not
column4: however
column5: representative of what was going on in terms of the actual politicking in Washington.

column1: CWBR: One thing that interests me about that point is this very conscious importance of rhetoric. Especially as we approach the Civil War and rhetoric
column2: especially secessionist rhetoric
column3: becomes even more virulent
column4: even more fiery
column5: it's interesting then that perhaps a lot of those speakers didn't fully believe what they were saying
column6: or is that an overstatement?

column1: RS: I think it's a little bit of an overstatement. This all goes back
column2: as many of these things do
column3: to David Potter
column4: and David Potter's famed article “The Historian's Use of Nationalism and Vice-Versa
column5: ” where he talks about these conflicting loyalties that a person might have.  Loyalty to state
column6: loyalty to family
column7: loyalty to nation
column8: and I think it was possible for a lot of these men to say things about their views on slavery in particular
column9: but also be friendly with people who disagreed with them.  In part because of the personal experience of living in Washington.  It was very hard
column10: if you wanted to have any kind of political role in the city at this time
column11: to avoid interacting with people who are going to have different opinions from you
column12: and that was an acknowledged part of being there.  So you see
column13: for example
column14: slaveholders talking about how most Northerners are antislavery
column15: and not liking those views
column16: but being willing to work with it because they have this understanding that they have those views and those are the views of their constituents.  So I would never say
column17: for example
column18: that they don't really believe what they're saying.  They may say it a little bit more strongly
column19: or in particularly fiery rhetoric to try to get their constituents fired up about the issue
column20: but I would say that much of what happened was really in the context of ""We are politicians
column21: that's what we do
column22: and we all have a sense of what we want
column23: which was to keep the Union together--most of the people wanted to keep the Union together--and to have a successful Federal government.  It didn't always work
column24: but there was certainly a level of respect that existed among the politicians that didn't necessarily extend to the constituents.

column1: CWBR: That issue of respect sort of leads to another question
column2: because it seems like the centerpiece of most narratives of Washington politics right before the Civil War was
column3: of course
column4: Preston Brooks caning Charles Sumner.  It's sort of the image that's been seared into every textbook.  And
column5: a lot of scholars have established the importance of honor and personal politics.  But it seems like part of what you're saying is that this respect and sense of honor
column6: in more cases
column7: helped keep these people together and working together
column8: rather than driving wedges between them. So would you call instances of people like Preston Brooks more of the exception than the rule?

column1: RS: I wouldn't say that it was an exception in the sense that there was an incredible amount of violence in the nineteenth century
column2: and especially in Washington
column3: which was a pretty violent but also just a pretty dirty and disgusting city
column4: which allowed for that kind of thing to happen.  This is part of what I tried to show in that chapter in particular and in my book
column5: that if you understand the caning of Charles Sumner in the context of the violence that existed in Washington
column6: it's not unusual.  What made it unusual is that it got the kind of press that it did
column7: and it became such an incredible tool for people in the North and the South
column8: in thinking about the problems of
column9: say
column10: a slave power
column11: or of an oppressive North.  So
column12: it's usual in the sense that there was quite a bit of violence.  It's unusual in the terms of political tools outside of Washington
column13: but the people in Washington understood it as an example of violence
column14: of things getting out of hand
column15: and one that didn't necessarily mean that we were about to crumble into Civil War.

column1: CWBR: For the politicians that may have witnessed this
column2: or heard about it
column3: it was sort of disconnected from what the nation saw.  In a sense
column4: the nation saw this as a much more important event than perhaps the people there at the scene did?

column1: RS: Exactly
column2: it was a big event when it happened
column3: and people were upset
column4: but it went away after a couple days.  People sort of said
column5: ""Ok
column6: now we're going to get back to the business of making policy
column7: and that involves talking to my Southern neighbors or my Northern neighbors
column8: and I can't avoid that
column9: nor should I.""  So it certainly was something that really energized people who weren't in Washington
column10: but in Washington
column11: it wasn't such a big deal.

column1: CWBR: One that you've mentioned several times that also sticks out to me is this sense of place
column2: and you mentioned that because of the nature of Washington
column3: that these people couldn't really avoid each other
column4: even if they had wanted to.  I was hoping you could talk about the role of proximity
column5: and how that affected politics
column6: and also what were some of the places that politicians interacted outside of Congress?

column1: RS: I'm happy to. I think one of the most fascinating aspects of Washington in this period is that there are sort of two Washingtons. There's the permanent Washington. There's the Washington that has the people that you would see in any city--in New York
column2: in Charleston
column3: etc.--where you're going to have workers
column4: women
column5: African Americans.  That absolutely existed in Washington
column6: but there was also this more temporary part of Washington that really only existed between the Capital building and the White House on Pennsylvania Avenue
column7: which is not a very large area.  In that area
column8: you had mostly male politicians living in boarding houses
column9: also some hotels.  They spent almost all of their time together.  They were either in the Capital or they were at home
column10: or they were at dinners or gambling houses--maybe some brothels also--in that area.  So they actually spent most of their time together
column11: and what this produced was something of a fraternity.  You might think about it as a giant male bonding session
column12: where you have these men who spend all their time together
column13: not so much with women
column14: and where they're really engaging in conversation in places outside the Capital.  That includes things like dinners.  Lots of people held dinners for their friends.  This would happen
column15: some
column16: with the permanent politicians.  William Corcoran
column17: who was a famous socialite in the period
column18: would host regular political dinners
column19: and he lived right by the White House so you would see
column20: basically
column21: a revolving door of politicians coming to eat with him
column22: but also just people sitting down to have dinner at the end of the day.  There were various boarding houses.  You also had people going to church together.  You had people meeting at Masonic groups
column23: and also other smaller groups that they put together.  One really famous example of this was Abraham Lincoln
column24: who was in a group called the Young Indian Club
column25: which was sort of a political debating group that consisted of himself
column26: one other Northerner
column27: and five Southerners including future Confederate Vice President Alexander Stephens
column28: which made for some really interesting commentary on Lincoln's behalf.  But the two of them became quite friendly in this group and talked politics and this had a real influence
column30: on Lincoln's thinking on politics in Washington
column31: and particularly the secession crisis.  Thinking about what was possible
column32: the kinds of compromises that could happen
column33: and the way in which you could have a conversation with someone from the South
column34: and not have it lead to Civil War.  So there was a lot discussion that happened outside of the Capital building in these more informal circumstances
column35: but with the same group of people.

column1: CWBR: Would you say that Lincoln's experience in Washington was initially what made him optimistic that war could be avoided?
RS: I do think so. I think he was affected by his time in Washington in a variety of ways
column2: and I point this out in a couple of places in the book.  One of things that was really important to him in terms of his experience in Washington and being in this Young Indian Club was to expose him to John Crittenden
column3: who was very famous politician from Kentucky
column4: someone that he admired very much.  Crittenden was life-long politician
column5: had spent many years in Washington
column6: and Crittenden himself became quite friendly with Stephen Douglas
column7: Lincoln's main rival in Illinois in the 1858 Senate campaign
column8: and Douglas is very happy to get Crittenden's endorsement in 1858
column9: and this had a very big impact on Lincoln's experiences in thinking about who should be in his cabinet once he's elected in 1860.  I believe he never forgave John Crittenden for his behavior in supporting Stephen Douglas.  But it also gave him a sense of this Washington club
column10: and what was possible in Washington.  I think he really underestimated how much secession was going to be a grassroots movement that did not have any kind of real push in Washington.  It was much more a rejection of Washington politicians
column11: and so he misread the South.  He had a misunderstanding of what was actually going to happen when he made his original decision to not speak out
column12: to not say anything
column13: to not support the attempts in Congress to try to come up with a solution--the Crittenden Compromise--again
column14: his anger at Crittenden is something that I think we really underestimate.  In spite of that
column15: Lincoln was smart man
column16: he figured things out
column17: and a lot of historians have shown his thinking in March and April to be quite different
column18: but early on in the process
column19: I think he had a great misunderstanding of what was going to happen.

column1: CWBR: Do you think that this club should be viewed more in the light of having been able
column2: for a long time and with some notable instances of compromise
column3: that they were able for so long to smooth over differences and prevent war from breaking out
column4: or is this more a story of these guys in this ""Washington bubble"" disconnected from what the issues of the war and secession were going to be
column5: really ultimately being unable to prevent something that they didn't really understand?

column1: RS: That's an excellent question. I think what I've tried to do and the historians who read this will recognize this
column2: is sort of turn the old revisionist theory on its head.  So the old revisionist theory being that a blundering generation of politicians pushed toward war because they had a misunderstanding of how serious these things were
column3: and they were particularly fiery
column4: and they ended up pushing us into war; it's their fault.  My point here is to show
column5: to a large degree
column6: that they didn't really have control.  They were not the ones that could have made decisions about this
column7: and they did live in a bubble that made them really unable to understand a lot of what was going on at home.  Jefferson Davis being the best example of this.  He's quite sad when secession comes
column8: and he's sad
column9: in part I think because he didn't realize how serious it was.  In large part because he was so sad that the Union was falling apart
column10: but also because he didn't understand how this could happen so quickly; he was very surprised by it. I would say that my point is much more that they didn't have the tools to fix this problem. The movement toward secession was really a rejection of them
column11: and a rejection of their way of handling politics.  You read the letters during the secession crisis
column12: and so much of what they say is ""these corrupt officials in Washington
column13: they've failed us
column14: over and over and over again
column15: so we need to take matters into our own hands.""  So I think the secession crisis is much more about that
column16: it's not so much about the blundering politicians.  Of course they contribute
column17: because they make all these fiery speeches
column18: but they didn't really have it in their power to fix the situation.

column1: CWBR: Professor Shelden
column2: I appreciate you taking the time to sit and discuss your most recent work
column3: <i>Washington Brotherhood: Politics
column4: Social Life
column5: and the Coming of the Civil War.

column1: RS: Thank you so much
column2:
I enjoyed talking with you.

" Isenhower
column3: Zach Summer 2014 2014-08-01 Interview University of North Carolina Press "" ""

column1:
5864 9781594161919 $35.00 CWBR Author Interview:
To Raise Up a Nation: John Brown
column2: Frederick Douglass
column3: and the Making of a Free Country		King
column4: William S.			"<h3>Interview with William S. King
column5: independent scholar

column1: Interviewed by Zach Isenhower
Click here for the review
Civil War Book Review (CWBR): Today the Civil War Book Review is proud to speak with William S. King
column2: an independent scholar making his debut in the Civil War Era
column3: and discuss his book
column4: <i>To Raise Up A Nation: John Brown
column5: Fredrick Douglass
column6: and The Making of A Free Country. Thank you for joining us today.

column1: William S. King (King): Well I'm glad to be here.
CWBR: So just to get us started
column2: describe to me what brought you to this subject
column3: not only recovering John Brown as a key player
column4: but then linking him to Fredrick Douglass and using these two lives to sort of tell this very large story of the era?

column1: King: Yes
