column2: well my links with John Brown go back to my earliest childhood.  I lived in that area of Kansas in the early 1950's with my parents and have active memories through the years
column3: of the battlefields there
column4: of John Brown's presence. More than that I would say in the development toward my journey to writing something like this was the impact of the Civil Rights Movement in the United States. In all of its phases
column5: and I feel that I have been very shaped and profoundly affected by it in all of its phases. I think to really to really put a point on it one of the impetuses of me developing toward was the killings that developed
column6: of course Medgar Evers
column7: Martin Luther King himself and Malcom X
column8: and many others that sacrificed their lives in a very American way in the sense that they were targeted individuals
column9: because they became outspoken and became effective. In this struggle that we've had in America we've had with race relations
column10: but my initial contact which moved me into this book was reading Du Bois’ John Brown and there one has a point meeting in the stone quarry outside Chambersburg between Fredrick Douglass and John Brown. Essentially all we know about it come from Douglass's narration of it in his Life and Times
column11: and of course he talked about it in a few other venues as well. At the end of his account Brown puts his arm around Douglass after two days of discussion
column12: and it was a comprehensive discussion
column13: when he says
column14: ""Come with me Douglass I will defend you with my life. When I strike the bees will begin to swarm and I shall want you to help me hive them."" But Douglass as we know refused to go and broke off with John Brown at that point
column15: and the rest transpired. I wanted to write that story and that led me to the other biographies of John Brown and Fredrick Douglass
column16: and his own writings (Life and Times)
column17: the works of Benjamin Quarrels
column18: and Phil Foner. That story gets repeated but is never elaborated on
column19: causing my reading to keep branching out. I was living in New York City at the time and I had the great fortune of getting laid off—this was back in the 1970s—and took myself to the New York library picking books I had noticed in my reading
column20: which were interesting and out of print coming from the nineteenth century volumes. I began reading in
column21: crucially
column22: in some people that had known Brown and had written biographies of him notably Richard Hinton
column23: Franklin Sanborn
column24: and James Redpath. I began
column25: not having been able to write anything yet
column26: but just gathering notes and experience
column27: which grew out. I had been familiar with the story the Civil War
column28: several years prior to this I had read the entire series by Bruce Catton on the Civil War.  That's basically what it was and I struggled with this writing for a number of years and kept reading. That is where it began its development
column29: from that specific incident in the stone quarry outside Chambersburg.

column1: CWBR: It sounds like part of what drew you to the story of Brown was this (and the link that would obviously connect him to much later figures you mentioned Dr. King and Medgar Evers)
column2: is this notion of sacrifice and then is that sort of the link that then led you to branch out and explore the myriad instances of sacrifice--many of them nameless—by these people that are soldiers and commanders?

column1: King: I think that’s really the crux of it
column2: although I don’t overtly state that
column3: but I think that's what moved me through this.  And it's a process of revelation too
column4: because there is so much that's obscure about this aspect of antebellum period because there's such contradictory views on John Brown and the understanding of what he did is very ill thought-out in most
column5: if not all regards. The relationship of Douglass and Brown
column6: which is crucial to understand this whole era
column7: has not been a source to study for everybody.  They leave it at the brief statements that Douglass makes
column8: and Brown didn't make any
column9: then leave it at that. But there's a whole area that can be open up to this portal
column10: as it were.

column1: CWBR: Do you think that part of how Brown has been misunderstood is basically then what sort of prevents people from exploring the relationship between Brown and Douglass? You mention early in the book that Brown has sort of become this caricature; he's sort of eternally the depiction in the Tragic Prelude that hangs in the Kansas state house
column2: of this larger than life kind of crazy man. How does that prevent us from exploring his relationship with Douglass?

column1: King: Well in the matters that pertain to the Civil War his story by in large has not really had a comprehensive grasp of the nature in the meaning of American slavery. The fact that it is often a peripheral discussion in the matters of the civil war
column2: even a great work like Bruce Catton's volumes. I recall him saying in his book The Coming Fury
column3: which was on the precursor to the Civil War
column4: the 1850's
column5: he really devotes one line to state of the slaves and their stake in the issue saying
column6: ""the mute and luckless negro."" That's his phrase and he really doesn't develop a view of slavery or of the agencies blacks really had
column7: both enslaved and free
column8: in bringing on that war and in its resolution. I find that many historians
column9: and my latest experience was with David Blight
column10: a professor at Yale University who is a magnificent scholar on the Civil War as you know
column11: I just happened to take myself to the internet and watched his twenty-two part lecture series of an hour each on the Civil War. He devotes a whole chapter to John Brown
column12: but is appallingly miserable in his discussion of Brown as a historical figure. Partly that is because they haven't felt that they really had to think through what he did and they’re deriving all their information from sources that really had a negative view about him and haven't penetrated for several reasons the meaning of Harpers Ferry. In one of them they sort of cap the whole thing on this notion that he was trying to raise a slave insurrection there of significant proportions
column13: which I show in the book was not the case at all
column14: and certainly it would have defeated all efforts he was trying to accomplish there if he had been able to do that
column15: which is just fantastical. I just find that they haven't thought it through
column16: which is a great failing of scholarship because there is plenty of material available. Notably
column17: in Brown's on words
column18: if you really study them if you get away from this notions of him being a mono-maniac who was mad and was a bloodthirsty
column19: cold blooded killer
column20: which he wasn't. You have to see what he was grappling with and the difficulties presented. One of the things I was able to bring out was that he was definitely trying to foreshorten what he saw to be the terrible war that did come. He saw that
column21: and it wasn’t a fantastical
column22: God-driven apparition
column23: he really understood his time
column24: and the potentials that war would unleash. Although there is magnificent work done
column25: I don’t think scholars have really gotten to the root of that war.

column1: CWBR: So
column2: you have
column3: as I understand as your saying
column4: when you're trying to decide how to evaluate Brown
column5: and of course evaluating Brown sort of a matter of deciding which of his words to weigh his actions against. It seems that a lot of historians have weighed his state of mind against his words where he says
column6: oh I would like to seize the armory and start and insurrection. So they have decided that weighed against those goals
column7: Brown must have been a failure and basically
column8: as I understand
column9: what you're saying is historians should take more seriously when he writes about the moral impetus slavery and how very seriously he took that? Since for him the political issue couldn’t be divorced from the moral issue
column10: so then the evaluation of what he's doing shouldn't be either?

column1: King: Right
column2: but I think they still miss the point in terms of what he was trying to accomplish at Harpers Ferry. It was not a slave insurrection in the terms it's been conceived in most commentary. His son
column3: who's mentioned in the book
column4: had an interesting remark saying that all writers had failed to appreciate that his father was trying to bring about the split in the Union. That was his point of striking at Harpers Ferry. It was not an irrational
column5: ill thought-out thing. He was trying to topple the very foundation of the political structure of the Union which at that time had a huge slavery component
column6: and was undermining the foundations of the republic as he saw. He was kicking the legs out from under the stool.

column1: CWBR: That is very interesting about the perspective that you bring because John Brown is not completely alone in this of course. One thing I found very interesting about the book is that you're always keeping track of the more familiar Civil War narrative
column2: but as the same time this is a story that is often told from the perspective of so-called extremists. You're highlighting the grassroots narratives that are essentially the opposite of those examined by our last guest
column3: Rachel Sheldon
column4: who wrote about this sort of “Washington bubble
column5: ” the fact that a lot of these politicians in Washington
column6: they do conceive of these things as completely political issues with political solutions and they're really surprised by secssion and by the ferocity of the war. In many ways the war is a rejection of them and we're seeing that here too. We're seeing fire-eaters seceding against Lincoln's initial expectations and we see Wendell Phillips echoing John Brown by welcoming secession
column7: because it's going to eventually seal abolition. It’s an intriguing juxtaposition
column8: the sort of a larger narrative that I think a lot of readers will find very familiar
column9: and then this sort of grassroots undercurrent. Would it be fair to say you think the grassroots as not only dragging the nation to the conflict
column10: which I think a lot of historians would agree with
column11: but that consistently the grassroots has to keep dragging laggard military planning and politics throughout the war?

column1: King: Yes
column2: I agree 100% on that
column3: though their defeat is what compelled them to go in the direction the grassroots were pulling them. They weren't able to resolve this war in fact they were on the verge a number of times and people like to point this out that there could have been a Southern victory. It wasn't impossible
column4: or there could have been a victory that was achieved with an independence of sorts
column5: of course things would have continued after that
column6: that wouldn't resolved anything at all. It did come to a revolutionary peak. It was a complete transformation that fact that they accepted these regiments of black soldiers after the Emancipation Proclamation. It's not at all that they had a significant impact on the battlefield. They had an impact and at times an important one
column7: but the underlying fact was the whole direction and the meaning of a confederacy was undermined by that fact
column8: of these black men in arms who have been enslaved in the south. That utterly defeated slavery. It couldn't go on. They had then to throw in the towel even though they continued to fight on
column9: because it was a possibility even as late as Appomattox that there could have been a political compromise. That compromise didn't go away with defeat of the confederacy it reemerged as you note in a Reconstruction and the defeat of Reconstruction.

column1: CWBR: I actually would like to hear you talk about that a little bit more because so much of the second half of the book does show what you were just talking about
column2: how important it is that there are black Americans taking agency in their own emancipation
column3: and it doesn't come down to whether they win or lose individual engagements in which they're deployed
column4: it's the fact that they're there. But then the war does conclude with this disappointment of reconstruction.

column1: King: Well actually I mentioned David Blight earlier
column2: he had suggested the question of when did reconstruction end? He ends with the interesting idea that it never ended
column3: in other words that struggle within our history has continued down to today. It has a very different flavor and balance of forces and dynamic in each succeeding decade
column4: but it's continued to roll on
column5: never with complete resolution
column6: never yet with complete quality and acceptance of the black nation within the United States. We continue to see--I don't need to bring up examples--but Ferguson would seem coincidental
column7: but I don’t think it can be considered coincidental.

column1: CWBR: Do you think that kind of falling short
column2: or perhaps the fact that it never really does resolve in a positive fashion
column3: would lead you to say that [lack of resolution] has something to do with the fact that as powerful as this grassroots impetus can be
column4: it's also very tough to turn into a cohesive structure? Or would you say that really the problem is not that the grassroots impetus for freedom wasn't strong enough
column5: but that there's this continuing and ongoing grassroots kind of counter-revolution in American history that's always trying to push back?

column1: King: In history I would say it continually shows itself in new forms
column2: but also it needs new forms of defeat. There's no promised land and no resolution of struggle in human existence. We should hope
column3: we may be faced with it
column4: but that's extinction I think
column5: a society without history. History is the narration of the struggles. People who study this aren't always aware of it of course or some are
column6: but it is continually re-presented. The Civil War era is a classic case of that. People are stirred by images of combat and in who was there or what canteens they carried or armaments and all of that. I find that I had to pay attention to the strategic and tactical points of these battles. In the writing of it I wrote in terms of what I thought was essential in terms of its strategic importance. I brought to the foreground what had not been present in most histories of the Civil War which was the black presence in it
column7: and that black agency
column8: which was important to the resolution it had in that period. I quote Douglass on one of his magnificent speeches late in the war when they had a convention of blacks to consider he said
column9: ""Come let us reason together. You may not have such an opportunity in 100 years
column10: and that exactly what it took before there was that upsurge that we saw in the 50's and 60's (historians know the incidents and conditions).  Of course there were people and events prior to that
column11: but that grassroots movement come up again in a magnificent way. This is the essential American story
column12: that struggle.  I don’t believe it’s resolved in any one period. The struggle adjourned from the battlefields to other venues
column13: to the social venue and to the courts
column14: and the mass movements. We did neglect poor Fredrick Douglass and John Brown in this discussion
column15: that I think is the key which is why I subtitled the book <i>John Brown
column16: Frederick Douglass and The Making of a Free Country. That was a crucial relationship in our American narrative
column17: and it has been neglected. Of course there’s been recent scholarship The [James Oakes] book
column18: The Radical and The Republic. I based myself largely on Douglass's own writings in his journalism and his speeches which merits a lot more attention than it usually gets. I let him speak in a full sense on many occasions there are actual words and writings. It's interesting to think too that Douglass
column19: his house burnt down
column20: he lost all of his volumes of the North Star
column21: Frederick Douglass’ paper
column22: all of these papers and correspondence
column23: and he remarks in Life and Times if he said or did anything important it was in the period covered in the papers he lost in that fire which was 1845 through 1860. Yet most people study him after the civil war as a figure in that period.

column1: CWBR: Also the period where he knew John Brown.
King: Yes and that was going to be my next statement. All of his work on John brown
column2: so scholars haven't had the benefit of going directly to those papers. I was mentioning Phillip Foner's volumes the Life and Writings of Fredrick Douglass
column3: which is a 5 volume series. I don't know how many people read those
column4: but I've broke the backs of several of them
column5: bent the pages right out the book in find that it is a marvelous history of the period
column6: in the most comprehensive sense. It's not incidental or undeserving of study
column7: and I’m sure many scholars have gone to it
column8: but I don't think it's been quite appreciated to the extent that merits even yet. Brown and Douglass
column9: the meaning of their relationship the depth and contact I try to bring out in the book but the skeleton is based on Douglass's on writings.

column1: CWBR: Thank you Mr. King
column2: for taking your time to discuss your most recent work <i>To Raise Up a Nation: John Brown
column3: Fredrick Douglass
column4:
and The Making of A Free Country.

column1:
5928 9781469617770 $35.00 CWBR Author Interview:
Through the Heart of Dixie: Sherman's March and American Memory Rubin
column2: Anne Sarah			"<h3>Interview with Anne Sarah Rubin
column3: Associate Professor of History at the University of Maryland
column4: Baltimore County

column1: Interviewed by Zach Isenhower
Click here for the review
Civil War Book Review (CWBR): Today the Civil War Book Review is excited to speak with Anne Sarah Rubin
column2: associate professor of history at the University of Maryland Baltimore County. Professor Rubin previously authored
column3: <i>A Shattered Nation: The Rise and Fall of the Confederacy
column4: 1861-1868. Today we get to discuss her most recent book
column5: Through the Heart of Dixie: Sherman's March and American Memory. Professor Rubin
column6: thank you for joining us today.

column1: Anne Sarah Rubin (ASR): Thank you very much for having me.
CWBR: So just to start we always like to hear
column2: what lead you to this project?

column1: ASR: I decided to write about Sherman's march and the place of Sherman's march in American culture a long time actually before I started the book. It was a kind of confluences of things that happened during graduate school
column2: things that I read and things that I saw. I had read Charles Royster's The Destructive War
column3: which is a fascinating dual biography of Sherman and Stonewall Jackson and it looks in the way of how Americans became more comfortable with this kind of destruction and devastation. All around that same time was the first time I saw the Ross McElwee movie Sherman's March where he
column4: in the early 1980's goes down South and he was planning to write a documentary about the legacy of Sherman's March. He wound up having all these romantic problems
column5: so what the movie really becomes is him trying to figure out why he can't have a girlfriend and Sherman's March is a metaphor. I thought that was really interesting and unusual. Also
column6: right around that time I saw references in a documentary then read James Reston's book Sherman’s March in Vietnam
column7: where Reston tries to make a connection between Sherman's march and the destructiveness and devastation that Americans wreaked in Vietnam. Somehow it all kind of came together. There was something special about Sherman's march that made it unlike other Civil War campaigns and that gave it a sort of greater cultural power than other campaigns and events had
column8: so that's why I decided to start exploring it.

column1: CWBR: It's interesting that what draws you in is the cultural power of the march and we see that even in the name
column2: because it's “Sherman's March to the Sea” but we really don't have a good name for it. It seems like we ought to at least add “Sherman's March to the Sea
column3: and Back
column4: ” right?

column1: ASR: Right
column2: exactly and what happens
column3: what I think is really interesting and what I was not very aware of in the beginning was how important the Carolinas campaign actually is. First of all
column4: Sherman thought that Carolinas campaign was more important and I think at one point he refers to the march to the sea to a mere change of base. It's the Carolinas campaign that is in fact even more devastating and destruction than the Georgia portion of the march. There's a real since of anger and vengeance in South Carolina in the part of the men and Sherman is very disingenuous about this in his memoir he writes
column5: “Well somehow the men got the idea that South Carolina was the cause of all their troubles and the cause of this war. They wanted to be harder on South Carolina and I felt like I couldn’t restrain them less they sort of loose their fighting edge and their vigor.”  He lets them loose on South Carolina and there is much more destruction of personal property of houses as opposed to outbuildings. I'm not minimizing what happens in Georgia only saying that it's actually worse than South Carolina and yet it's much less well known. Then in North Carolina the men are supposed to put the gloves back on
column6: because of Unionism in North Carolina because of the unionist population there. They don't quite do it to the degree I think that Sherman would have wanted them to do. That's why the book in its entirety is about Sherman's march and I felt really strongly about how it had to be more than just the Georgia piece.

column1: CWBR: Why is it you think that Georgia--and it seems like it happened fairly quickly by the early twentieth century—Georgia and Atlanta specifically kind of manages to claim the effects of that march almost all to itself and it seems like especially the South Carolina story is sort of lost outside of South Carolina. Why do you think that happened so quickly?

ASR: It is really a curious thing and I think it happened for a couple of reasons. I think there is sort of narrative tidiness to the Georgia piece of it that it's the march to the sea. It's got this kind of inherent drama or destination
column2: you're going to the sea. I think that's why
column3: for example
column4: it holds more cultural power
column5: meaning
column6: and people remember its violence more than the Shenandoah Valley Campaign or something like that in terms of how it blocks everything out. Also
column7: a lot of it actually is the impact of Gone with the Wind
column8: so that's a little later than what you're saying. It's the 1930's
column9: 1936 is the novel and the movie is 1939. Gone with the Wind just exerts so much influence and defined Sherman's march for generations of Americans. One of the things that's pretty important to understand about Gone with the Wind is that Margaret Mitchell had grown up hearing stories about Sherman's march. It had happened to her grandparents and she also did a lot of research. She's very very careful in the book to be as scrupulously accurate as she can about all the military maneuvers. She writes in a letter at one point saying
column10: ""I don't want anybody coming to me and saying that I got it wrong."" True confession time
column11: I had seen Gone With the Wind for the first time in the 8th grade history class
column12: and I always like to add unironically.  I actually grew up in the North too
column13: this was right outside New York City. Then I had read the book
column14: which I was about thirteen at the time and it was the longest book I had ever read
column15: I was so enamored by the romance and all the reasons Gone with the Wind is a great novel and movie. Then when I became a historian and a southern historian then I started to realize how much was problematic about Gone with the Wind--the way it treats race and reconstruction. I moved away from it for a while but when I started looking at it again for this book
column16: I sat down and reread the novel. For the first night I thought I'd just skim it and wound up literally staying up until two in the morning reading it. I was sort of sucked back into it again. Now I see that Gone with the Wind is this really powerful document. If you want an illustration of what white southerners thought about the Civil War and reconstruction in the 1920's and 30's read Gone with the Wind. It's straight out the Dunning School. For all of those reasons I think Gone with the Wind has a huge impact.

column1: CWBR: Do you think the timing of Gone with the Wind is also sort of critical? It emerges right about the same time that a lot of these actual Union veterans of the march
column2: the “bummers
column3: ” a lot of them are in their later years or gone. Do you think that the timing was right for
column4: even in the North
column5: a narrative that suggested the cause may have been just
column6: but even [northerners] can admit or believe that Sherman was perhaps a little bit too much?

column1: ASR: I think that's interesting. I haven't really thought about that but you're exactly right. You know it comes out
column2: the movie
column3: right around the 75th anniversary of the march. There's a huge fanfare about it. They do this three day premiere with people dressed up in costumes and hoop skirts. In one of these crazy you-can't-make-it-up historical coincidences
column4: Martin Luther King as a child actually sings in a choir that performs at the Gone with the Wind premiere. What are the chances? So anyway I do think there is a lot of that
column5: that there's not ever a good kind of northern counter-narrative of Sherman’s march. Even the northern novels don't really--Yeah that's right there's not really a northern defense of the march in that period. Veterans themselves in the 1870's
column7: and 90's they talk about the march in very heroic terms that they see it as winning the war and they minimize the degree of destruction
column8: but you don't really see that coming out afterwards. The condemnations of Gone with the Wind are not about the way it portrays Sherman it's about the way it portrays African Americans and the way it portrays Reconstruction
column9: as the carnival of corruption. So you're right that's a great insight. I should have put that in the book.

column1: CWBR: Going off of your point there about Reconstruction it does seem that this march is really heavily mythologized very quickly and even though it has a tidy narrative as you say you also write that it sort of is missing the central cast of characters and missing the epic battles that the other mythologized events in the Civil War like Pickett's Charge
column2: and there are a number of reasons why it occupies such a huge space. I was hoping you could expand on that a little bit.

column1: ASR: There's very few actual battles along Sherman's march and from the Union side in particular they take very few casualties over the course of the march. Very few people died. That's one of the reasons that Union soldiers remember the march fondly. It doesn't have the kind of heroic grandeur such as Pickett's Charge or Cold Harbor or anything like that. It is the military movement that is about civilians
column2: I think in a way that fewer or any other campaigns are described that way. Historians know about all of these campaigns against civilians and places on the border or as I mention the Shenandoah Valley
column3: but the general public doesn't. So what happens is that Sherman's march becomes the scapegoat for all the ills visited on civilians
column4: and all the devastation wrought on the South. Then I think there's a little bit of conflation too of any destruction and devastation is going be blamed on Sherman. These legends
column5: Oh Sherman burned my family’s house in Alabama
column6: well no
column7: because he wasn't there. I've had people come up to me giving talks and someone how came up to me recently saying ""Oh we have a chair with scorch marks on the back and the scorch marks are from Sherman
column8: and it could be from the march because this person mentioned where the chair had been and that in fact was in South Carolina on the route of the march so that could be true. But I think there's a lot of that kind of legend that grows up around it.

column1: CWBR: Well even in just the way the march is described I thought it was interesting when it comes down to the tactics. In the [popular] narrative
column2: it always comes down in a swath
column3: but it wasn’t actually in a swath right?

column1: ASR: The phrase that I always use is
column2: we think of it as this 50-mile wide lawn mower stripe but it's not. It's more like a 50-mile row of stitches in that there are a lot of places that aren't touched on Sherman's march. One of the things I explore in the book are that there are all these different stories and legends that grow up
column3: about the reasons why this house was spared or that house was spared. It occurred to that the reason there are so many stories about homes being spared for different reasons was in fact so many homes were spared. You can't make this argument that Sherman's march cut this 50-mile wide swath and at the same time have tourism brochures and what-not praising all the antebellum homes that are still standing. It becomes this interesting way for stories about the march to come up that [people say] “this house was spared because we put up Masonic apron on the door or that house was spared because there were pretty girls there
column4: or we saved the family silver by hiding it somewhere clever
column5: or the jewelry got stuck in the baby’s diaper and that's why we still have the jewelry.” These ways of outwitting the Yankees become really prevalent
column6: common stories.

column1: CWBR: It seems that compares to a lot of other Civil War memory--of course women have played a huge role in shaping a lot of those memories with the Daughters of the Confederacy and what-not--but it seems women play an even more essential role when it comes to Sherman's march because they're actually the actors
column2: right?

column1: ASR: In most cases women were the ones that confronted the Sherman soldiers when they came onto their farms or plantations. Partly this was because most able-bodied men were away
column2: and those able-bodied men who weren't away often hid when they knew Sherman was coming. They figured the women would be largely protected by their gender. One of the big misconceptions we have today about Sherman's march is that we talk about it in the context of “total war
column3: ” whatever “total war” means
column4: and to us it means a war on civilians that involves the death of civilians. It's total war in the WWII or the Vietnam or Gulf War sense where there's actual killing of civilians
column5: and that just doesn't happen along Sherman's march. They're not hauling civilians out and shooting them. They're not using sexual violence as a weapon the way that we've seen in ethnic cleansing and things like that. I don't want to minimize the impact the march had on civilians and it was terrifying for them
column6: but it was a war against civilian property not against civilian persons.

column1: CWBR: Then why do you think that narrative seems to be so entrenched? It seems pretty evident that even if one could broadly define Sherman's war against property as still some kind of form of terror tactics
column2: he's not the first even in the Civil War to do that.

column1: ASR: I think it's the triumph actually of a lot of the Lost Cause in ascribing this Sherman and it's the triumph of something like Gone With the Wind where that's the narrative that's put forward. Sherman I think
column2: people always ask if Sherman was a war criminal and the answer to that I would say is no. I think Sherman is someone who knew very well the laws of war and I would say that he knew where the line was and he pushed right up against that line
column3: but didn’t step over the line of what was permissible under the laws of war at the time. The only cases were where I think he might have are where in retaliation for Confederate actions he
column4: in one case a Union soldier steps on a minefield in Georgia and has his legs blown off and Sherman calls up a bunch of prisoners of war and has them walk across the minefield. They actually survived all that. Then there are some cases in South Carolina and North Carolina where some groups of Union foragers were killed and in retaliation Sherman ordered some Confederate prisoners killed. That I think is more morally problematic than the kind of destruction and destroying of supplies that the march engaged in.

column1: CWBR: It’s sort of ironic that one of the most morally problematic events of the whole march is actually afflicted on freed slaves when that is sort of Sherman's other legacy is that he visited great destruction on white southerners but also an agent of emancipation.
ASR: Yeah
column2: I think that's one of the great contradictions of Sherman in Sherman's march. That's the other thing
column3: when people talk about the destruction and devastation of Sherman's march they're really talking about how it affected southern whites when in fact it's African Americans who in many ways bear sort of the equal brunt of the destruction. If all of the food in an area is taken or ruined that's starving African Americans as well as whites. Sherman was no friend to African Americans really he did not believe
column4: for example
column5: in African American troops. He did not have African Americans units marching with him and one of his subordinate commanders
column6: in this event that you allude to at Ebenezer Creek in Georgia
column7: where it's a big cypress swamp and the Union soldiers are crossing over pontoon bridges and they're being followed by hundreds if not thousands African Americans
column8: the subordinate commander actually named Jefferson Davis--no relation to the Confederate president--orders the pontoon bridges pulled up and leaves these African Americans with Confederate cavalry closing in on them. Their choice is try to swim across
column9: which many try and many drown
column10: or to be captured and sent back into slavery
column11: which is what happens to them. Sherman is ok with what happens he doesn't condemn Davis for this
column12: but when the news reaches Washington the Secretary of War Stanton comes down and is chastising Sherman for this and saying you [Sherman] go to do something for African Americans. So they meet first with about twenty African American ministers in Savannah and say
column13: ""Well what do you want
column14: what do you want to come out of the war?""  And they say
column15: ""We want land.""  Sherman offers a suggestion so outlandish that [Stanton] will back off--this is Special Order 15—that they take all of this land that has been abandoned by whites who fled all along the coast of Georgia and South Carolina
column16: altogether about 400
column17: 000 acres
column18: and divide it up into plots for African American families to settle on.  From Sherman's perspective
column19: that solves two problems.  It gets Stanton off his back
column20: and it means that these thousands of African American who've been following him will be resettled on this land and not continue to follow.  And it happens that this plan is briefly put into effect
column21: but I think the true test of it is that when Andrew Johnson
column22: after the war
column23: essentially voids it by returning all of this land to its original owners
column24: Sherman doesn't say a word.  He's moved on
column25: he doesn’t care.  He is simultaneously this great liberator
column26: and his army is a great army of liberation
column27: but they're not willing motivators. They're not ideologically motivated.

column1: CWBR: Sherman has quite a long career in fiction after the war and after he died
column2: but it seems like that is kind of a theme--whether in emancipation
column3: or in fiction
column4: or in Lost Cause histories--of Sherman being this agent that causes things to happen
column5: but he's not actually there.  He's always sort of there
column6: but off-frame.  I thought that was sort of an interesting contrast
column7: in your section on depictions in art and fiction
column8: with somebody like Lee
column9: who is like a King Arthur figure in a lot of depictions
column10: always on his horse leading and a presence.  I wonder if that is indicative of how people imagine Sherman as an early practitioner of total war--do people more naturally imagine Sherman as hunched over a table of maps and troops strength readouts
column11: sort of callously directing the logistics rather than galloping across a battlefield?

column1: ASR: I don't know if I ever thought of that--I think your portrayal of him hunched over a map is more generous than what I think are stereotypical portrayals
column2: which is sort of Sherman
column3: wild-eyed
column4: holding a torch
column5: where Sherman is personally burning things everywhere he goes.  Portrayals of Sherman are interesting.  There are not a lot of portrayals of Sherman's march
column6: certainly--The Mort Künstler
column7: Don Troiani
column8: those paintings that people love--are definitely more of a glorification of the war in Virginia.  Sherman
column9: though
column10: does have such a long postwar career too.  He's General-in-Chief of the Army for about another 15-20 years.  One thing I was struck by was that when he died in 1891
column11: there was this great outpouring of grief
column12: a national outpouring of grief
column13: with the black-bordered newspaper columns and the big funeral and all of that.  So he was a big national figure
column14: and doesn't have nearly the number of statues that Lee has
column15: but he does have a few big statues.  Specifically
column16: the one in New York City at 59th Street
column17: at the entrance to Central Park
column18: there's also a large one in Washington D.C. So I don't know that he's that slighted. Although I will say that I grew up seeing that statue all the time and had no idea that it was Sherman until I started working on this book.

column1: CWBR: Of course that could just be a function of being around a landmark
column2: monuments all the time
column3: you may not think to really look at it until you move away from it.  But to backtrack a bit
column4: I wanted to hear about the ""bummers.""  You were sort of surprised by their postwar sentiments
column5: right?

column1: ASR: Yeah
column2: because again
column3: when you come of age in the post-Vietnam world
column4: where so much of the writing about soldiers is in the vein of memoirs talking about post-traumatic stress
column5: and soldiers who were asked to do terrible things
column6: asked to make war on civilians
column7: and they feel guilty about that and they feel traumatized by all that.  You just don't find that with Sherman's ""bummers
column8: with the marchers.  The big caveat to that
column9: of course
column10: is that I can only know what they wrote down.  So certainly
column11: the veterans who are gung-ho veterans
column12: who belong to these veterans organizations and who go around and make speeches and all of that
column13: are only one subset.  They don't speak for all veterans
column14: but the dominant story that they tell is one of tremendous pride in their service
column15: tremendous pride in the march. They believed that they ended the war. I think they're not wrong about that. The analogy that I draw is that they're sort of like the airmen on the Enola Gay
column16: who believed that what they did was necessary
column17: was right
column18: and brought the war to a close.  So they're not troubled by it
column19: they're remarkably untroubled by it
column20: I found.  To them this was the great moment of their lives
column21: the great experience of many of their lives.

column1: CWBR: This march just keeps inspiring other people to try to experience it for themselves too. This experience thing [of Sherman's march]
column2: I don't know that it's stronger than with other events
column3: because certainly people visit battlefields all the time
column4: but retracing this entire march is a larger undertaking than visiting a battlefield park for a day.  It inspires this peculiar form of travel writing from just after the war through present day
column5: people travelling through the South
column6: coming to wildly different conclusions over time by visiting the same locales
column7: and you end up deciding to follow in their footsteps
column8: so what was that like?

column1: ASR: I felt like I couldn't really write about Sherman's march
column2: because so much of what I write has to do with these specific places
column3: that I didn't feel like I could do it without visiting them myself.  I didn't retrace the entire march but I did about two-thirds to three-quarters of it.  I did all of Georgia in 2008
column4: then I did the North Carolina from the Bennett place—from the surrender--to Columbia and then further south of Columbia.  I actually did that in reverse
column5: because I was driving down from Maryland.  I found it really interesting.  I thought that I would see a lot more memorialization.  And I just didn't find as much as I thought I would.  Even the roadside markers seemed more about troop movements
column6: and not really the impact of the march.  I found that surprising.  There was also such a contrast in the way that Atlanta sort takes their Sherman experience of being burned right before Sherman leaves on the march
column7: and they kind of run with it.  Atlanta put the Phoenix on their city seal
column8: and in a lot of way the march is kind of the best thing that ever happened to Atlanta
column9: whereas I was really struck in Columbia by how much angrier Columbia seemed.  Columbia seemed to still retain this sense of grievance from Sherman.  I’m actually looking forward to a big symposium there on the anniversary of Sherman’s burning the city.  I was glad I got to go
column10: and it will be interesting to go back. One of the fun side-effects of this book coming out is that I got to back to a few places. Even just seeing the names on the road signs again.

column1: CWBR: Given how much more room you saw in the memorializations you mentioned
column2: for added complexity that you show in the book here
column3: moving the memory beyond just troop movements
column4: do think that the memory of the march is as fluid as it was in the past? Do you think we'll start to see a little of this complexity and contradiction work its way into the popular memory?

column1: ASR: That's hard to say
column2: I'd like to think that complexity and fluidity moves in.  Certainly the Civil War Sesquicentennial in general has been a much more rich and diverse and complicated view of the war and what happened during the war
column3: compared to the centennial.  I'm by nature an optimist
column4: so I'll say yes
column5: I think our understating will become more complicated and more subtle
column6: rather than fixed. So we’ll close on an up note.

column1: CWBR: Well Professor Rubin
column2: I appreciate taking the time to sit and discuss with us your latest work
column3: Through the Heart of Dixie: Sherman's March and American Memory.

column1: ASR: Thank you so much
column2:
it was a pleasure.

column1:
5986 9780817318482 $34.95 CWBR Author Interview:
The Rebel Yell: A Cultural History Warren
column2: Craig A.			"<h3>Interview with Craig A. Warren
column3: Associate Professor of English and Prodessional Writing at Penn State Erie
column4: The Behrend College

column1: Interviewed by Zach Isenhower
Click here for the review
Civil War Book Review (CWBR): Today the Civil War Book Review is happy to speak with Craig A. Warren
column2: Associate Professor of English and Professional Writing at Penn State Erie
column3: the Behrend College. Professor Warren previously authored Scars to Prove It: The Civil War Soldier and American Fiction
column4: and today we get to discuss his most recent book
column5: The Rebel Yell: A Cultural History. Professor Warren
column6: thank you for joining us today.

column1: Craig A. Warren: Thanks for having me
column2: I appreciate it.

column1: CWBR: We always start out by asking because it's always an interesting question
column2: especially in this case with this subject that hasn't been in historiography for quite some time
column3: what was it that drew you to this project?

column1: Warren: I became really interested in the rebel yell in the summer of 2008. At that time my first book had just gone to press. To a large extent that book is about the memoirs of Civil War veterans and southern women on the home front. I came away from that project tremendously impressed by the ability of everyday Americans to put on the page some of the abstractions of war. Things such as freedom
column2: democracy
column3: and human dignity. I also became aware of where these writers struggled to represent certain phenomena in print and to communicate it to the reader. One of those areas
column4: interestingly enough
column5: was the legendary battle cry of Confederate soldiers
column6: the rebel yell
column7: and I saw writers struggling to represent it on the page. Some were trying to spell it out with vowels
column8: consonants
column9: and exclamation marks etc. That didn't satisfactorily convey this ferocious battle cry to the reader. Others adopted different strategies by using metaphor
column10: saying the rebel yell sounded like the squealing brakes of a runaway train
column11: or it sounded like the howling of wolves
column12: and even a hurricane. This was not satisfying either since these three things don't necessarily sound alike. Also a frame of reference we are familiar with doesn't seem to connect with a Civil War battlefield. Then some just gave up altogether
column13: which my favorite was the Union veteran and writer Ambrose Bierce who simply said the rebel yell was
column14: “the ugliest sound that any mortal have ever heard.” I saw these different attempts to describe the rebel yell
column15: all of which failed to a large extent. As a literary critic I was interested in the limitations of language to describe a sonic phenomenon
column16: but as a cultural historian I quickly became interested in the rebel yell for other reasons as well. The more I looked into it the more I realized it had this really rich and vibrant career after the Civil War
column17: all through Reconstruction and the Gilded Age and the early twentieth century. I think that's a history that most people still today are completely unaware of. That really got me interested to dig and understand the yell better
column18: and to understand its evolving meaning and purposes for subsequent generations of Americans.

column1: CWBR: I do want to come back to the sonic aspect and the limitations of the language
column2: but before we get into all the details maybe it would be helpful to have a quick overview of the career the yell had that you mentioned. You found that it started from unclear but probably varied origins
column3: to become what we are familiar with historically as a particular battle cry
column4: but it changes a lot even after that.

column1: Warren: That's right. As with any human language or expression the rebel has
column2: as you say
column3: murky origins. Everything evolves from a complicated matrix and linguists do their best to patch together where human languages come from and how they evolve and change. It seems that the Antebellum South was absolutely awash with different kinds of high pitched yelling. Some was related to animal husbandry calling to animals
column4: shepherding animals. Some had to do with rural life
column5: communicating with neighbors and family members over long distances. There were also hunting cries used by every class strata in the Antebellum South. Then there were Native American war cries which could be heard through the 1830's and in some frontier communities in the south. Over a period of time it seems that all these different sounds and styles of noisemaking change how southern communities
column6: in a broad sense
column7: approached standard cheering. Unlike in northern populations and communities where cheering typically took the form of noisemaking in unison in a standard way like 'Hoorah
column8: hoorah
column9: ' it seemed that in the South
column10: both in town and in rural communities
column11: cheering took the sound of free-form screeching
column12: overlapping noises usually at a high pitch
column13: lacking words or word sounds. When the Civil War began
column14: it seems to me that this style of cheering just came naturally to most folks in the South
column15: and was translated from a civilian life to the battlefield
column16: the camp
column17: and the march. It's sort of a mistake to think the rebel yell was exclusively a phenomenon to the battlefield. Southern troops used it in lots of different ways and in different contexts. In any case it became a battle cry and as you were saying after the war
column18: it did change. For a long time was seen as a
column19: I would say
column20: kind of defiant statement of white southerners that they were still here and living through Federal occupation
column21: but they were not foregoing their traditions. It was used in some cases of racial violence against freedmen. It was used in scenes of insurrection. The Crescent City White League
column22: a white paramilitary organization was using the rebel yell while battling troops in blue in New Orleans. It was used in political contexts whenever different political parties would get their candidates together. The rebel yell was often sounded by old Confederate veterans now in support of new political measures. This goes on through the Spanish American War
column23: and I don't know how much you want me to get into its career as a battle cry in 1898
column24: but it's a major sociopolitical barometer of intersectional hostility in some cases
column25: but also reconciliation as well. It's not until the twentieth century that we see the rebel yell eclipsed by the Confederate battle flag as a major symbol of white southern identity.

column1: CWBR: One thing that struck me
column2: going back to the origins of the yell
column3: was this odd obsession
column4: given how familiar most southerners would have been with all the different possibilities for its origins—whether it be Indian battle cries or hunting calls
column5: anything like that—with figuring out a single source
column6: and I was curious about that.

column1: Warren: Yeah
column2: I think its human nature. We like to be detectives to try and find out the one single place where a particular expression began or where particular human behavior started. Really I think that's fool’s gold
column3: there’s not going to be
column4: when it comes to human language
column5: one single beginning for virtually anything. I think that what happened with that obsession during the decades following the Civil War
column6: with the origin of rebel yell
column7: was that a lot of people began to understand the rebel yell existed somehow as the voice of the South.  That's how it was often characterized. That being the case
column8: anyone who had a particular political or cultural agenda and wanted to represent true southern identity as belonging to a particular region
column9: people
column10: class
column11: or political party would adopt the rebel yell as their own and try to make the case for its origins falling in line with their personal interests. For instance
column12: if you wanted represent the South as this romantic
column13: agrarian
column14: cavalier society then you make the argument that
column15: “oh the rebel yell derived from the fox-hunting cries of plantation owners.” If you instead want to make the case of true southern identity is in that blue collar work ethic of yeoman farmers then you say
column16: “well the rebel yell derives from rabbit hunting calls that these farmers would voice after tending their fields during the daytime.” If you want to represent the South as a multi-racial society then you say
column17: “oh it derives from Native American battle cries” or you suggest even that the rebel yell—ironically enough—began with slave songs and celebrations and those were passed on to their white masters. I guess what I'm getting at is the rebel yell becomes a political or cultural chess piece. People interested in trying to define the South in a particular way are going to interoperate its origins accordingly.

column1: CWBR: In defining its origins it also
column2: it was interesting to me
column3: generates quite a bit more commentary than I had read anywhere else on how it was that northern soldiers supposedly cheered as well.

column1: Warren: That became something that for us today is kind of amusing
column2: to see northern and southern veterans crossing pens after the war describing the difference between northern battle cries and southern. Northern troops seem to yell in a European and British style which is a low register
column3: in unison
column4: give a 'hoorah
column5: hoorah.' They said this is the manly
column6: deep-breasted cheer of the northern soldier. They all did it in unison and that sits very well with the concept of Union and togetherness. The southern veterans though
column7: thought that was all clockwork and mechanical. They thought that kind of cheering was appropriate for northern factory workers who never saw sunlight and never got outside or had any individualism at all. They prized the rebel yell and said
column8: here’s a battle cry which each individual contributed his own preferred pitch and sequence of sounds to the collective whole
column9: and it's not a kind of cheering by rows
column10: but instead free-form screeching
column11: and all that overlapping sound creates a unified cacophony. The different sides found ways to talk about their style and mood of cheering as a way to describe their political approach to conflict and democracy. Are we representing a united front or are we each doing our own thing together? I think that's really interesting symbolically. There’s a lot to be said about how the rebel yell was different from the style of cheering in other sections of the U.S. and in Europe at the time. I think it does speak to the fact that the American South
column12: although it had lots of shared characteristics and origins with the North
column13: did have different cultural attitudes and origins owing to its region and to its people
column14: which white southerners were encountering in the generation leading up to this whole war.

column1: CWBR: It is interesting to me that these northern veterans and southern veterans
column2: as they’re sort of sparring in various written pieces
column3: are more or less in agreement on what makes a northern yell different from a southern yell
column4: it's just they disagree on whether this is a good or bad thing
column5: in their characteristics. Yet both interpretations lend themselves pretty readily to the growing Lost Cause ideology of the South being overcome by this tremendously more numerous
column6: more industrial force
column7: and really the ideology goes out of the equation.

column1: Warren: Right
column2: I think that what happens over time is that as the two sections move towards reconciliation there becomes this need for mutual respect. Northern veterans instead of saying
column3: “oh this high pitched rebel yell was effeminate
column4: or it was wild and incoherent
column5: and it represents everything that was wrong with secession
column6: ” began instead to praise the rebel yell as a unique American voice
column7: voiced by a worthy opponent who
column8: “though defeated in battle
column9: nonetheless had lots of virtues in term of honor and dedication and commitment to cause.” If it does get discussion
column10: the rebel yell gets incorporated into this drive towards reconciliation
column11: which was not shared by everyone by any means
column12: but in large contours there’s this movement towards reconciliation. It gets to the point where after a while
column13: you begin to see the rebel yell embraced by people in the north and northern readers and newspapers are writing to southerners asking if they can describe the rebel yell in print or help them to better understand it. It becomes almost a kind of shared American achievement and I noted earlier that it took part in the Spanish-American War. By 1898
column14: I would suggest the rebel yell became the de facto battle cry of the U.S. military. It was used on San Juan Hill and then the Philippines and elsewhere
column15: taught to Northern troops and even African American troops by Southerners. After the war former Northern officers coming back to Washington D.C. in 1898 were serenaded by the rebel yell at the nation’s capital
column16: which must have been really disorienting for them considering their previous experience with it
column17: but it had become a national battle cry. I think you are right to say that it is an evolving experience and its meaning for the nation
column18: and not just for the South
column19: changes over time.

column1: CWBR: That Spanish-American war moment was particularly striking
column2: because it really does look for a moment that the rebel yell is going to become a newly fully incorporated American military tradition and it's going to be that shared American achievement you mentioned. All signs point to increased popularity
column3: then what? Two or three years later it retreats
column4: what happened?

column1: Warren: I think there was no longer the urgency on the part of white Southerners to prove their loyalty to the larger United States. That is what a lot of rhetoric was about during the Spanish-American War. People are saying
column2: “oh look how the South is now sending its officers and men to support the United States and now they're wearing the blue uniforms as well and so forth.” After the Spanish-American War I think that Southern loyalty has been proven
column3: so there's not this urgency in the part of the South to share the rebel yell with the North
column4: so I think that's one of the reasons why there’s this retreat of its use. I also think that by the turn of the century
column5: and I say this in the book
column6: the rebel yell is no longer a military phenomenon. By then it’s been used and practiced by subsequent generations of civilians
column7: people whose fathers and grandfathers had been Civil War soldiers and had taught that to them. We start seeing it also used in political spheres
column8: the term rebel yell becomes an expression that's used to denote certain political perspectives. It's just not strictly a military phenomenon anymore and I talk about its growing demilitarization after 1898. So for me the Spanish-American War represents its zenith as a shared national battle cry and after the rebel yell
column9: both screeching and name brand of the rebel yell
column10: moves increasingly to the civilian sector.

column1: CWBR: Was it the civilian sector then that was most responsible for the fact that
column2: as we get past the Spanish-American War
column3: you start to describe these multiple personalities for the rebel yell
column4: so that there's still a Southern defiant yell that especially comes out in as a result of the Civil Rights movement
column5: but then there’s also what you called a “cartoon yell?”

column1: Warren: Yeah
column2: you know it's true. Once it's no longer seen as this terrifying ferocious battle cry
column3: as it was described immediately after the war (veterans were writing about it in those terms)
column4: people begin to see it as an expression of life and vitality. People talk about the rebel yell as what Walt Whitman would call a “barbaric yawp
column5: ” declaring oneself’s place in the universe. It becomes something that screamed out at sporting events and race tracks. It becomes a fun-loving expression. Certainly during the Civil Rights movement the mid-twentieth century
column6: segregationists started using the rebel yell in a throwback way as during the Civil War itself
column7: but at the same time there's what I call the cartoon rebel yell was firmly placed as the sort of teenage hijinks yell
column8: screeching out while driving 90 miles per hour down a country lane. It has multiple personas all at once
column9: which is one of the reasons why I thought it was such an interesting phenomenon.

column1: CWBR: We also cannot talk about its change without discussing the context of what might be replacing it. So especially when we are getting into the Civil Rights era
column2: and the visual aspect is so important there
column3: you write that that’s true as well for how the yell is regarded
column4: right?

column1: Warren: The rebel yell
column2: we have to remember
column3: emerged from the nineteenth century. It's invisible
column4: intangible
column5: just really much more at home in a culture that was oriented toward sound. There are critics that have done a great job about talking about how sound was so important to nineteenth century America. That's one reason why today we have a hard time understanding why people would go and listen to three-hour-long oratory
column6: but that was something that was part of their culture
column7: perhaps especially in the South. As we get in the twentieth century
column8: especially after World War II
column9: we are now in a culture of images
column10: with the advent of televisions and motion pictures. Increasingly people are looking for visual symbols culturally and politically. What happens
column11: to my mind
column12: is that the rebel yell is no longer as much at home in that kind of society. So the use of the yell as the dominant symbol of white southern identity is eclipsed by that Confederate battle flag
column13: which had largely gone dormant from about 1865 to 1948 or so
column14: when the Dixiecrats adopted it and it started beginning to be used for other purposes. John Coski's excellent book The Confederate Battle Flag charts this evolution about how the battle flag was largely used just in ceremonial ways through Reconstruction in the Gilded Age
column15: but really came into its own as a controversial and important symbol around 1950. That was helpful for me because I began to see how in his description of the career of the battle flag
column16: how it was following many of the same contours we had seen the career of the rebel yell established. I began to ask what the difference here is. Well one major difference is that the flag is visible and it’s more dignified to be suited for a governor's office or for a state capital than the rebel yell
column17: which is more of a ragged
column18: raw expression of self. The rebel yell is better suited for a street fight than for a governor's office. I think that's one reason why we see the battle flag eclipsing the yell as a major symbol right around 1948-50.

column1: CWBR: It's not too long after that
column2: that it seems to me like the yell experiences an effort to re-imbue it with a bit of the original ferocity and gravitas that it originally had. You mentioned there’s another personality
column3: the “lost yell.”

column1: Warren: It's true
column2: it wasn't that there was a clear passing from the yell towards the flag. There was an overlap for a while
column3: the same places the segregationists are waving the Confederate battle flag such as from University of Mississippi in 1962 when James Meredith was enrolling. At the same time that those flags are being waved
column4: protestors were also shouting the rebel yell. There is this throwback
column5: but at the same time there is this new movement to which I refer to as the concept of the “myth of the lost yell
column6: ” which suggests that the rebel yell has been lost to history. That began with a handful of Confederate veterans at the end of the nineteenth century who didn't like how the rebel yell was being used by civilians. They thought it was being treated irreverently
column7: and used as a party trick.   They wanted it to be treated as a dignified anthem for a particular time and place
column8: the Confederacy of 1861-65. They wanted to cordon it off from its irreverent use and said
column9: “Oh it's been lost forever and you can never hear it after Appomattox.” Lots of other veterans
column10: though
column11: were demonstrating the rebel yell quite willingly at banquets. The argument about the lost yell never got a lot of traction until most veterans passed away. Then people like Shelby Foote
column12: who had a particular cultural agenda
column13: began pushing again the concept of the lost yell. Over time people began to embrace the idea that “we may have a facsimile of the rebel yell today but we really don’t know exactly how it sounded but the true rebel yell has been lost
column14: ” so you see this movement as well. I think what Shelby Foote and others were trying to do was to distance the rebel yell from what they would see as its abuses in the mid-twentieth century. They didn't like the KKK using the Confederate battle flag during the Civil Rights Movement
column15: or the segregations using the rebel yell
column16: which made them think that it was spoiling what these nineteenth century artifacts had been used for initially
column17: and they should not dishonor them in that way. They suggested that these things are actually dead and gone forever. They said that the rebel yell
column18: like Southern oratory had been lost. I suggest in my book that it’s a myth and that there's never been a time since 1865 when we haven't had Confederate veterans willingly give up the rebel yell
column19: or that we haven't had any recordings
column20: audio and visual
column21: of Confederate veterans giving the rebel yell. The idea that it was lost to history is really part of a particular agenda
column22: but it's not a reality.

column1: CWBR: Well the recordings that you mention became this really fascinating part of the book where you did quite a bit of sleuthing to dig a little bit into various efforts that have now been made with the miracle of digital technology and what not
column2: to have now a “found yell.”

column1: Warren: Exactly
column2: I think when Shelby Foote went on Dick Cavett in the 1970's and talked with Ken Burns in that famous PBS documentary The Civil War in 1990
column3: we didn't have the World Wide Web yet
column4: on which we could share recordings with the entire world
column5: so it was easier than to make the case that the rebel yell has been lost and we don’t have any recordings of it. Now that kind of thing can be shared. There was an effort on the part of the Museum of the Confederacy a few years back to try and uncover what they were putting forward as the true yell. They were following the tradition that there had only been one way to give a rebel yell
column6: that everyone who gave the yell did it in the exact same way. There's no historical record to back that up
column7: but they latched on to that idea. They found a recording the United Daughters of the Confederacy had and then another one across the country thinking they were two separate recordings that lined up and uncovered the true yell. What I do is go through a lot of UDC catalogs and find different radio stations who played recordings of the yell over the last several decades and try to show that actually the Museum of Confederacy found the same recording twice. It wasn't a one true yell that was offered by different guys and units
column8: but actually the same recording. I hope that what I have done in looking at that and trying to figure out exactly what's been recorded and when or who by
column9: is that there was no true way of giving the rebel yell. Every soldier has his own preferred way of doing it
column10: and I would suggest every soldier gave a slightly different rebel yell from one occasion to the next. So the found yell was really that realization
column11: that there was no one way to do it and the fact that we now have the World Wide Web and technology is better to share those kinds of things. We can look at what the Library of Congress has
column12: to look at their audio and visual recordings of Confederate veterans giving an individual yell or collective yells. This is available now at the Smithsonian website actually. I like to think now we can get past a lot of the myths that have grown around the rebel yell and better understand its real evolution for what it means for our country.

column1: CWBR: So what do you see as the importance of the historical debate over the yell as its going on into the twenty-first century
column2: trading its particular historical meaning in our culture for symbolizing a more general rebelliousness?

column1: Warren: One think I learned from this process is that often times passes for history is really an attempt by various commentators to shape the thinking of generations of Americans about American history or Southern history in this case. Really the job of the scholar is to look at different interpretations of the past or cultural artifacts and try to approach it in that sort of neutral objective way
column2: and see how these markers have been used to front a particular agenda
column3: and to understand how American culture develops overtime in accordance with these perspectives that are maybe politically motivated or culturally or socially motivated. In terms of what I've learned about the yell’s shift from one particular use on a battlefield for instance for being used for commercial purposes and everything else
column4: it's that a cultural icon really cannot be contained. Shelby Foote and others might want us to say that this artifact is lost forever and lost to history
column5: but cultural artifacts are not lost. They evolve over time
column6: they change over time. You see this when Billy Idol can use the rebel yell—this British rocker having it on a song or an album—or whenever the rebel yell is used now as a name for a clothing line or bourbon. You see how these things can be commercialized
column7: how symbols can change and be adopted for new purposes and new agendas. I think that's the truth in how we approach symbols as people
column8: and to understand that about our images and symbols is important
column9: because it makes us more aware of who we are and how we choose to represent ourselves to the world.

column1: CWBR: Professor Warren
column2: I won't ask you to offer your own rendition of the yell
column3: but I thank you for taking a moment to sit down with us today and discuss your new book The Rebel Yell: A Cultural History.

column1: Warren: Thank you very much for having me
column2:
it was a pleasure.
