Empty Sleeves: Amputation in the Civil War South Miller
column2: Brian Craig			"<h3>Interview with Brian Craig Miller
column3: Associate Professor of History at Emporia State University

column1: Interviewed by Zach Isenhower
Click here for the review
Civil War Book Review (CWBR): Today the Civil War Book Review is happy to speak with Brian Craig Miller
column2: Associate Professor of History at Emporia State University. Professor Miller previously authored John Bell Hood and the Fight for Civil War Memory
column3: and is Editor of the journal Civil War History. Today we get to discuss his most recent book
column4: Empty Sleeves: Amputation in the Civil War South. Professor Miller
column5: thank you for joining us today.

column1: Brian Craig Miller (BCM) : Thank you very much for having me.
CWBR: Ok so I always ask to start about what drew you to this project
column2: but I think in this case it’s a particularly important question
column3: given how potentially relevant these veterans’ challenges
column4: and their society’s reactions were
column5: as you mentioned toward the end of your book.

column1: BCM: Yeah
column2: it sort of came by accident in some ways.  In graduate school we were discussing new ways of thinking about Reconstruction
column3: and at that time I was starting to think about John Bell Hood as a potential thesis and dissertation topic
column4: and since he was a double amputee
column5: I thought wouldn’t that be a really interesting way at getting at his particular life?  In the midst of writing about Hood and his amputation and what that meant
column6: ultimately
column7: to his manhood and how it affected him in the postwar period
column8: I started getting these letters in the mail that I mention in the epilogue
column9: from these various veterans organizations
column10: that showed amputees from Iraq and Afghanistan who had acquired prosthetic limbs and were looking for a financial donation to help them buy some sort of craft kit.  It was usually around the holidays so they could assemble a model kit and then paint it to give them something to do with their functioning limb
column11: which I thought was really fascinating
column12: in terms of the way that these photographs were taken
column13: of these particular veterans
column14: that were sent with the mailing to acquire funds.  To me
column15: it became one of those things were the past of the Civil War and the present day crisis
column16: that I think a lot of men and women who are returning from war are facing now
column17: particularly with some issues with gaining the health care that they need quickly
column18: and just simply being recognized.  That they have extensive challenges both with issues of mobility as well as chronic pain they may be facing
column19: as well as just simple recognition for their military service.  So I think in many ways
column20: the present day conflict
column21: and the reverberations and aftermath of that conflict
column22: bled into this particular project to think about
column23: what does it actually mean in the Civil War era
column24: to return home missing an arm or a leg
column25: and how does Southern society
column26: that has just been defeated in war
column27: incorporate the damaged individual into the fold of society?  I think that sort of matches where the Civil War historiography is going right now.  I think the current trends of the issues veterans are facing in Iraq and Afghanistan are starting to appear in the Civil War era
column28: with the work done recently by Brian Matthew Jordan
column30: or I think you will see work here shortly from Diane Miller Sommerville
column32: who are all talking about the challenges that veterans are facing
column33: and I think that will continue on in the near future.

column1: CWBR: A very interesting thing about this project is how it’s challenging in two different directions
column2: because there is
column3: as you mentioned
column4: there’s real parallels with the challenges veterans face today and certainly
column5: challenges that veterans from both sides of the Civil War faced
column6: but then there are a lot of particularities to what Southern veterans experienced.  I was wondering if you could explain why
column7: specifically
column8: you choose to look at Southern veterans?

column1: BCM: The reason for the Southern veteran
column2: if you will
column3: being the center of this project is because in some ways I thought it would be more challenging to do the Southern side of the story
column4: which certainly is not something that we traditionally see in Civil War scholarship.  A lot of times when volumes are produced on veterans
column5: in particular
column6: I would say that a vast majority of the source material and the stories within those books are mostly focused on Northern veterans
column7: and for good reason.  The paper trail is much greater
column8: the United States medical records are more extensive and easily accessible
column9: so I wanted to focus on the South and especially in its connection to manhood.  We think of how Southerners defined their manhood before the American Civil War
column10: with honor
column11: or this internalization that men actually had to go through to realize they were a man
column12: and how they outwardly showed that through how they physically appeared
column13: how they interacted with the public
column14: how they controlled their drinking or their horses and so forth.  And also their ability to master or control their wives
column15: their slaves
column16: their children
column17: and their own personal behaviors.  The Civil War in many ways alters a lot of those particular facets of defining manhood.  For example
column18: honor is shattered in many ways because Southern men are going off to war to fight to prove their manhood and they’re returning as military failures.  Their concept of mastery has been completely overturned because of emancipation and women taking a much more prominent role in literally running many Southern households while their men were away fighting the war itself.  So it seems that in some ways when men are returning home
column19: and society was once again looking to them as men
column20: it seems that the male physique
column21: which had been so important in the prewar era
column22: would in some ways naturally rise back to the top again.  However
column23: because now the male physique has been battered in many ways
column24: not just through amputation but because of physical scarring or emotional scarring that has made these men more dependent on their wives
column25: on their children
column26: on their society in general to care for them
column27: which certainly would have been a mark of feminization in the prewar period.  What I was struck with
column28: was I found some isolated cases of amputees in the South before the American Civil War
column30: many of them amputees from the Mexican-American War or from the Texas independence conflict
column31: and what I found is that Southern society didn’t necessarily embrace them.  Even though they would be considered military heroes
column32: they were still viewed in a negative light because their physical being
column33: if you will—their body—had been battered
column34: broken or damaged in some way
column35: which was seen as a marker of feminization
column36: or certainly not pristine manhood.  That sense seems to carry its way through the Civil War and into the postwar period
column37: creating what historian LeaAnn Whites calls
column39: a “crisis in manhood.”  I think it’s a crisis that was deeper and more profound than historians have been willing to acknowledge
column40: particularly because of this newfound dependent place in which Southern men find themselves
column43: coming back to a society that isn’t necessarily thrilled that their military prospects turned out so poorly.

column1: CWBR: It’s that return of damaged physiques that seems to offer the starkest contrast between Southern and Northern veterans. The Union guys can expect limb replacement programs from the government
column2: they have Federal pensions
column3: and of course they won
column4: so there’s this outpouring of public gratitude for having won.  For Confederate veterans there are already steeper obstacles because of the shattered economy in the South
column5: but then there are all these notions of Southern male honor
column6: the pall of defeat
column7: and these hinder the support that these guys can expect.  Since we’re already on that topic
column8: could you talk about the ways in which those notions of honor hindered the support that they could expect?

column1: BCM: Yeah
column2: it seems in particular that because these men would not get any Federal benefits at all
column3: that they would have to be reliant on benevolent societies
column4: local communities
column5: or state governments to step up and take action.  The benevolent societies were completely overwhelmed.  I think they had great intentions early on
column6: particularly the local groups that were gathering supplies or raising funds to buy prosthetic limbs
column7: but they simply could not handle hundreds of men who needed their assistance
column8: particularly when they were working based on donations.  The eye then focused on state governments
column9: where you only see seven Southern states start prosthetic limb programs—North Carolina
column10: Mississippi
column11: etc.
column12: some of these deeper South states—start a limb program
column13: starting with legs
column14: then eventually arms.  But the programs are mixed.  They take some time
column15: and require that the amputee themselves travel to usually the state capital or another other major city in that state to acquire the limb.  It would require some measurements and you’d have to wait for the limb to be constructed and then fitted.  Some men found them very useful
column16: others did not
column17: they found them painful.  States started to revise some of those programs by offering men a choice between a limb or a cash payment.  I discovered that as those programs advanced a few years
column18: that men wanted the cash payment. It was more important for them to have seventy-five or one hundred dollars up front rather than a prosthetic limb that may increase mobility or may hide the fact that they received a catastrophic injury during the war
column19: but it seems that their dire straits of poverty required them to take the cash payment.

column1: Those programs fizzled out and you started to see other programs like land grant programs. Louisiana and Texas particularly gave large tracts of land to amputees. In west Texas and more rural areas of Louisiana
column2: but those programs weren’t as successful as the state governments hoped them to be
column3: because many of these amputated men didn’t know what to do with such large parcels of land unless they had family members who could help them farm these plots of land.  So ultimately it comes down to the pension programs.  Because of Unionist governments
column4: because of Constitutional questions within state governments themselves
column5: you have legislators
column6: particularly in Texas
column7: wondering if they should actually
column8: if Confederate veterans should be seen as wards of the state
column9: if this dependency that they’re going to have on a government handout payment in the form of four times a year—is that appropriate
column10: is that an honorable endeavor to take place?  The governor of Florida actually questioned if this is a manly enterprise.  If Southern veterans were true men [the governor reasoned]
column11: then they shouldn’t have to rely on state governments in order to survive.  So the pension programs are very slow coming.  By the 1880s
column12: some of the states started to buy into these programs
column13: and they started to pop up from time to time all the way through Kentucky
column14: which was one of the last to start its program
column15: in the nineteen-teens
column16: which was almost fifty years after the conflict itself.  Many of these veterans have started fade away
column17: and haven’t even survived to the point where they could actually collect a pension.  That I think was most striking to me.  The Lost Cause
column18: in many ways
column19: has allowed us to think that these veterans returned home
column20: were completely embraced by Southern communities
column21: the women took care of them
column22: they lifted them up
column23: they constructed monuments in their honor
column24: they praised them
column25: and cared for them.  But the reality is that these men came home
column26: they had no financial prospects
column27: they ended up begging on the streets in some cases
column28: or trying to find odd work here and there
column29: but the doors were closed to them.  In fact
column30: one veteran famously noted the sign that appears when he looks for work everywhere
column31: “no maimed veteran need apply.” These men were not being recognized by society as men
column32: let alone men who could be productive in a postwar Southern economy.

column1: CWBR: Talking about how overwhelmed these benevolent societies were
column2: about how this question eventually had to go to the states and to politicians because there’s just no other institution that’s capable of supporting them.  In a general sense
column3: I’m curious about numbers
column4: and if there are numbers available
column5: for Southern veterans.  Looking at some of the tables in the book
column6: the number of amputees seems a little lower than one might expect
column7: especially once you divide them up among the states.  But at the same time
column8: this controversial subset of veterans becomes a symbol for veterans
column9: especially aged veterans
column10: writ large.  So I was wondering first about the numbers
column11: and second how they became such a powerful symbol.

column1: BCM: The numbers are a tricky prospect for anyone working on Southern medical history. A lot of the records for medical hospitals and medical care were not standardized until several months into the war itself
column2: so you didn’t have appropriate record keeping.  A lot of it was just doctors writing things down in ledger books
column3: which of course were scattered all over the South.  Then as the Confederate government starts to centralize these medical records
column4: and a lot of them were destroyed when the Confederate capital of Richmond was evacuated in 1865.  So we don’t have an exact count of how many Confederate amputees there were.  I think most medical historians have estimated it’s probably close to the Union figure
column5: which was around 29
column7: but it’s really difficult to pinpoint that exact number.  The pension files themselves may be useful in counting that number
column8: but in some states they’re still medically sealed
column9: because they contain medical information so historians are not actually able to go and look at that information.  This is actually applicable in the state of Texas
column10: for instance.  The medical portion of pension files in Texas is not available for historians because it contains sensitive medical details
column11: so again
column12: so that would maybe be one way of counting these amputees
column13: but we’re certainly not able to do so in a physical sense.  I can tell you that what medical there is does show that the number of amputees did decline during the course of the Civil War
column14: which I think may surprise many readers with general Civil War knowledge
column15: which sees this as a continued medical crisis throughout the war
column16: but it seems that by 1864
column17: Southern surgeons and hospitals have become very regulated
column18: with very strict cleanliness policies
column19: and doctors themselves had access by that time not just to practice but to medical journals and surgical manuals which had been updated.  These went step-by-step on when and when not you should amputate
column20: and it became so standardized in practice that surgeons
column21: particularly by the last year of the war
column22: were able to treat thousands of gunshot wounds
column23: but weren’t necessarily amputating at the same rate that they had done at Manassas or Shiloh
column24: in the early part of the war
column25: where you saw surgeons completely overwhelmed
column26: without extensive experience
column27: and they were cutting off limbs left and right.

column1: I think in some ways we can see the amputee
column2: particularly because he became such a prominent physical being in many Southern communities
column3: to be elevated to a different stature amongst other Southern veterans.  But it struck me again
column4: particularly with these benevolent groups
column5: that the amputees themselves aren’t always easily recognized in Southern society. You could have instances in some Southern communities where veterans and amputees begging on the streets were told that they were no longer allowed to do this.  They would be rounded up—particularly in the city New Orleans—and they would be rounded up and dumped into the Shakespeare Alms House.  So the city actually went back and revised that statute to say that actual Confederate veterans could remain begging on the streets
column6: but what happens is some men are able to acquire Confederate uniforms by buying them or stealing them
column7: and get through that loophole and beg for money as an amputee that would not have been caused by a war-related injury.

column1: I thought that the United Confederate Veterans
column2: which becomes the largest Confederate veteran organization by the 1890s
column3: would be a great place for amputees in order to be positioned and heralded
column4: but what I found was that not a lot of amputated men were joining this organization
column5: let alone being recognized by the organization.  The UCV does have in their mantra that benevolence is part of who they are
column6: and they want donations to be solicited so they can help take care of aging veterans and infirm veterans
column7: particularly in veterans’ homes across the South
column8: but once state governments started to get involved and take over those veterans’ homes
column9: it seems a lot of the financial resources the UCV would have put into taking care of veterans now goes to other endeavors
column10: particularly textbook writing.  The UCV becomes very
column11: very concentrated on making sure that the narrative of the war is written from a Southern point of view
column12: and that Southern point-of-view textbooks are being used in classrooms across the South
column13: rather than in lifting up and caring for these amputated men.  Maybe it’s because amputated veterans aren’t interested in joining a veterans’ organization
column14: or they simply don’t have the financial resources to pay dues or to travel due to mobility issues
column15: to go to camp meetings
column16: or even to the national reunions that the UCV is holding from place-to-place. Or they simply don’t want to return to locations where that injury actually took place. A lot of times UCV reunions are taking place at or near battlefields where veterans can go and see where the action took place and maybe that’s something they’re simply not interested in reliving.

column1: CWBR: Yeah I thought it was telling in the section you had on allocations of funds from Mississippi and
column2: at the same time that some $2
column4: 700 was allocated for amputees
column5: there was some $20
column6: 000 allocated for the defense of Jefferson Davis.  There seems to have been quite a mismatch between the rhetoric of supporting veterans
column7: compared to when it actually came time to pay for such things.

column1: BCM: The thing that’s fascinating about that Mississippi number with historians is that it grows. I’ve actually seen some popular Civil War books
column2: looking at the darker crisis of the Civil War
column3: which are now taking that number and saying that Mississippi spent fifty percent of its state budget.  It was twenty percent
column4: then it was forty percent
column5: now it’s fifty percent.  That’s simply just not true.  Mississippi actually spent about what everybody else did
column6: which was a small portion of their budget
column7: partially because there were such large hurdles for these men to actually go through and apply—because they had to be counted
column8: they had to be verified.  In order to get you prosthetic limb
column9: you had to prove that you were an honorable man
column10: that you didn’t desert from the war
column11: that you honorably left the war
column12: that you surrendered or were discharged in an appropriate way
column13: and you had to get medical guys to step forward
column14: your physicians
column15: surgeons had to say that this guy’s amputation took place during the Civil War.  So it became a very large burden of proof on these men just to actually fill out the paperwork and then swear and affidavit before a judge to actually get the prosthetic limb to begin with.  So Mississippi’s budget figure
column16: I hope
column17: will actually return back to normal here.  It continues to be one of the great myths of the Civil War
column18: that Mississippi had to spend all this money on prosthetic limbs when the reality was very similar to what the few other state who even created the programs actually spent.

column1: CWBR: There’s one group I want to make sure we talk about
column2: because the whole time these guys are doing all of this
column3: trying to get their paperwork filled out and
column4: of course
column5: they don’t make a whole lot of headway until almost the turn of the century
column6: and in the interim in many cases they’re basically dependent on women at home.  You mentioned the disruption of prewar gender expectations.  Some of it seems to have come down just to numbers
column7: with some twenty percent of the marriageable male population no longer available.  So women have to make adjustments
column8: but they make a whole range of adjustments. Would you say that overall Southern women formed a crucial bridge to the more formalized institutional support for veterans after they returned?

column1: BCM: Absolutely
column2: I would definitely agree with that.  We think for these amputees themselves
column3: the very first person that they’re going to interact with once they wake up from their amputation is probably a female nurse who has been assigned to give them medical care
column4: change their dressings
column5: and watch over them for a few weeks while they recover
column6: before their return back to battle or the front lines or sent back home.  In some ways these nurses serve as the psychological gatekeepers for preparing these men for some of the challenges that they may face.  As these amputees are recovering
column7: they take a lot of time to think about what an injury means to them in the future.  They begin worrying
column8: in particular
column9: about how their fiancées
column10: or potential spouses back home
column11: or their current spouse
column12: are going to react to this injury.  It seems time and time again that the nurses themselves are telling these men
column13: “everything is going to be ok
column14: show your fiancée
column15: your wife
column16: your empty sleeve
column17: show them your wound.  They will embrace you
column18: they will love you all the more.”  In some cases as these men are recovering in the hospital
column19: they’re getting mail
column20: so we have nurses having to break the news that their fiancée or spouse has actually sustained a major injury
column21: one that will alter their ability to maybe be a breadwinner for the household itself.

column1: The Lost Cause has this thing that every single Southern woman rose to the challenge and accepted these men. I actually found it to be a mixed bag early on. You have some women who were very enthusiastic
column2: very excited about taking care of amputated men.  There are others who are not so interested
column3: particularly those who want a fully able-bodied man
column4: because that is how they see their ability to care
column5: to survive in the future.  Other women simply become physically repulsed by the sight of men who have been physically altered by the war.  I don’t think we can blame those particular women because they are part of a culture and a society in the mid-nineteenth century that was in many ways Barnham’s world
column6: where those were physically altered or handicapped became sideshow attractions.  They were individuals who were gawked at or stared at or ridiculed by the general public
column7: so it shouldn’t surprise us as historians that these men now
column8: who are veterans
column9: happened to be viewed in the same way by some of their potential spouses.

column1: It seems that as time passes and these men come home
column2: that for the most part they are embraced by women who have no choice other than to sort of help pick up the pieces. They heed
column3: in some ways
column4: Jefferson Davis’ call near the end of the war to help build up the amputee as the “new aristocracy
column5: ” mostly out of sheer desperation to readjust to society.  If you fell in love with a man when he went off to war
column6: you certainly understood the risks and when he returned missing an arm or leg
column7: for the most part women
column8: again
column9: accepted that man in that new position.  We see cases of women who were very vigilant in caring for their amputated spouses
column10: others who took them out every morning and tied them to the plow so they could actually do the fieldwork for the day.  Others found this prospect to be slightly exciting and beneficial for their own relationships
column11: because they felt that their husbands or fiancées would not leave them.  “Who else could love an amputated man better than myself
column12: ” these women would start to argue.  In fact
column13: some relished this newfound dependency that their husbands would now have on them
column14: in many ways
column15: as they had been dependent on their husbands prior to the Civil War.  It’s from those efforts in particular that we see women in that familial role of lifting these men back up or at least providing them medical care.  They become the stand-ins for the state governments that are slow to react
column16: or the lack of healthcare system that’s readily available for these veterans as they return home and adjust to their newfound disabilities.

column1: CWBR: Of course there’s one more group that undergoes a massive transformation over the course of the war
column2: and that’s the surgeons.  It was really striking to me that you have these soldiers and also the untrained nurses
column3: maybe from rural Arkansas or Mississippi or Louisiana or wherever
column4: and they think so little of the surgeons that they feel that their own opinions on whether amputation is necessary or not hold more weight
column5: even as the surgeons themselves are very carefully developing and documenting and standardizing best practices.  Although it does seem like there were certainly cases where the worst perceptions of wartime medicine were accurate
column6: that actually instances of really saw-happy surgeons
column7: and utter disregard for cleanliness
column8: and incompetent post-operation care
column9: those don’t really represent the typical standard of Civil War medicine.  So how is that our impression still today
column10: has become so skewed?  Because of all of these groups that undergo real transformations
column11: surgeons’ reputations don’t seem to come out of the other end of the war much better than they went in.

column1: BCM: I think there are a few reasons for that. First of all
column2: popular culture has done some damage to Civil War surgeons.  Think of any major Civil War film
column3: going all the way back to Gone with the Wind
column4: where the surgeon is sort of viewed in this negative light.  He’s more Sweeney Todd than a skilled individual
column5: hacking away at the bodies
column6: calling for the next patient/victim
column7: hacking off the limb
column8: tossing it
column9: and then just screaming “next!” as they wipe the saw or knife on their blood-spattered apron.  That
column10: I think
column11: also parallels with some of the very negative impressions early on in the war.  If you look at any sort of general narrative history of the American Civil War
column12: these big one-volume narratives that have been written
column13: usually when you get to the section on medicine
column14: or the medical crisis
column15: a lot of the quotes pertaining to doctors
column16: both Union and Confederacy
column17: usually are lifted from 1861-1862.  We can’t blame those diary writers and letter writers because that is the horror that they’re seeing for the very first time.  They don’t have much of a frame of reference.  We’re talking about men and women who probably have never seen an operation before.  They certainly had not experienced any sort of major medical surgery in their life or been into a location where that had taken place
column18: so when they walk by a battlefield hospital or they’re serving as a nurse in a battlefield hospital
column19: they’re going to hear people screaming
column20: they’re going to hear cries
column21: they’re going to see limbs being cut off.  The only thing they can think of is to use the term “butcher.”  Now we think of the term butcher as back in those days as requiring some skill.  Even today
column22: when you go to Whole Foods or Kroger and you go talk to your butcher behind the counter
column23: you’re going to have him cut a piece of meat in a very skilled manner so it looks great
column24: and so butchers themselves back then were doing very skilled work
column25: but observers had no other frame of reference
column26: so that was the term.  It comes up again and again and again
column27: particularly in ’61 and ’62
column28: and these accounts were written about these surgeons or the hospital experience in general.  It has been cast

column1: In some ways I think surgeons rightfully earned that label
column2: but only early in the war
column3: because they were so overwhelmed
column4: they were understaffed.  You’re talking about hundred of gunshot wounds
column5: thousands when you’re looking at the aftermath of Shiloh
column6: with a limited number of medical personnel
column7: a limited amount of time
column8: and in many cases they simply did not know what to do with that many wounded.  Once that storm calms a bit in the early part of the war
column9: we start to see more standardization of practices
column10: more medical literature readily available
column11: and there it seems the medical practice really makes profound steps forward.  We have cases of surgeons who are clearly understanding germ theory well before we have given them credit for in the historical community.  Doctors are employing cleanliness standards in battlefield hospitals or in recovery units.  Nurses themselves are starting to understand the necessity for cleanliness and regularly changing dressings or following protocol where floors have to be scrubbed and cleaned in a certain way after a certain amount of time has passed.  In some ways when we negatively castigate these surgeons or hospital workers
column12: we’re actually shredding their credibility
column13: their honor
column14: where they had taken up very honorable profession and did their best. While we have a lot of source material negatively blaming these surgeons in 1861-62
column15: I was able to find quite a bit of praise-worthy material
column16: particularly of patients who ran into their surgeon later in life
column17: and thanked them for saving their life.  Those are the stories that don’t necessarily get into those grand narratives of the Civil War
column18: and they certainly don’t make it into the Hollywood
column19: pop culture views of the medical practice.

column1: CWBR: So by the time we turn the clock again and get back up to the turn of the [twentieth] century
column2: and women caregivers have been stand-ins for quite some time.  There have been the benevolent societies and we’re starting to get some incipient state programs.  But the foundation of support is really still too small
column3: especially as these veterans get older.  By contrast
column4: Northern veterans
column5: by the 1890s
column6: support for Northern veterans I think accounted for something in the neighborhood of forty percent of spending.  At the same time
column7: Southern states are still debating whether individual support is undignified and maybe they should all go into these underfunded veterans’ homes.  So while there is some emerging systematic support
column8: it’s coming after a lot of the veterans have died
column9: and it’s really kind of
column10: as you mentioned earlier
column11: a very mixed actual result for the veterans.  What do you think was the legacy of their efforts
column12: and the efforts of the women and of the benevolent societies
column13: who championed on the veterans’ behalf?

column1: BCM: I would say it’s a very mixed legacy. Unfortunately
column2: I think this is a mixed legacy after every major American conflict.  I don’t think that the Civil War stands alone here.  If we look at recent events
column3: you know
column4: a few years ago with the issues at Walter Reed Medical Center or with the backlog of paperwork that veterans are having to wait to see a doctor at the V.A.  This seems to be a sad
column5: persistent theme in American history
column6: that after every major conflict
column7: we sort of turn the page in the textbook
column8: I like to say.  The war ends
column9: we turn the page
column10: and we move on to the next chapter in history
column11: not really taking the time to understand the complexity of what these veterans
column12: and those who were directly connected to them
column13: have to deal with on a daily basis.  The benevolent organizations themselves
column14: in the South
column15: try their best
column16: are overwhelmed
column17: then sort of turn their attention elsewhere
column18: such that caring for the wounded may not have been in their minds the larger legacy
column19: as opposed to decorating graves and constructing monuments and writing textbooks.  That telling the story of the war becomes more a pertinent issue for these benevolent groups than taking care of the human beings who survived the war itself.  The state governments drag their feet.  Some of them take a long time to actually get to a place where they put up a financial commitment for these veterans
column20: by which time many have passed away or are no longer interested in seeking out financial support.  A lot of them will just write in that they are in a place where they simply need help
column21: and when the government was unable to do so
column22: we’re left as historians to wonder what happens to them
column23: if that’s the only paper trail that they leave behind.

column1: I think that the story of the veterans themselves becomes a problematic one in the sense that we don’t have enough material
column2: if you will
column3: to sort of glean what their experiences were really like
column4: other than these sort of grand narratives that the benevolent organizations like the Daughters of the Confederacy
column5: or the Ladies Memorial Association
column6: or the United Confederate Veterans wrote.  They wrote very grandiose things about these men
column7: and they wrote very grandiose things about the nurses who cared for them
column8: but that rhetoric doesn’t necessarily seem to match when you go to pension files and prosthetic limb applications that show injured men in such dire straits that they are begging state legislators
column9: they are begging governors.  You look at some of the governors’ files related to some of the prosthetic limb programs or pension programs
column10: and there’s usually a folder full of letters written by the veterans saying
column11: “I need help.  I don’t need help next week or next month
column12: I need help immediately because there’s nowhere for me to go
column13: ” and I think tragically that continues to be a legacy of American military conflicts where we have veterans today who are still begging for help
column14: who are having to live under bridges or are homeless
column15: who don’t have the medical care that they need.  That sad mixed legacy I think for Confederate veterans
column16: and even Union veterans as some historians have pointed out
column17: even continues today.

column1: CWBR: Well
column2: an excellent look behind the grand narratives that certainly do need more complication.  Professor Miller
column3: I appreciate you taking the time to discuss your most recent work
column4: Empty Sleeves: Amputation in the Civil War South.

column1:
BCM: Thank you very much.

column1:
6113 9780807159187 $47.50 CWBR Author Interview:
The British Gentry
column2: the Southern Planter
column3: and the Northern Family Farmer: Agriculture and Sectional Antagonism in North America		Huston
column4: James L.			"<h3>Interview with James L. Huston
column5: Regents Professor of History at Oklahoma State University

column1: Interviewed by Zach Isenhower
Click here for the review
Civil War Book Review (CWBR): Today the Civil War Book Review is happy to speak with James L. Huston
column2: Regents Professor of History at Oklahoma State University.  Professor Huston previously authored
column3: among several books
column4: <i>Calculating the Value of the Union: Slavery
column5: Property Rights
column6: and the Coming of the Civil War
column7: as well as Stephen A. Douglas and the Dilemma of Democratic Equality. Today we get to talk about his most recent book
column8: <i>The British Gentry
column9: the Southern Planter
column10: and the Northern Family Farmer: Agriculture and Sectional Antagonism in North America. Professor Huston
column11: thank you for joining us today.

column1: James L. Huston (JH): My pleasure
column2: and thank you for the invitation.

column1: CWBR: So I'll get right into it because there's quite a bit going on in this book. You're taking on a lot of long established narratives: an industrialized North growing apart from an Agrarian South; capitalist development in the North growing antagonistic to the outmoded southern economic model; a matter of free labor versus slavery; but you argue that all of these are incomplete explanations at best for sectional antagonism. So instead
column2: the source of sectional antagonism lies in agriculture?

column1: JH: That is the thesis of the book and it is there because of landholding patterns. Small farms in the North and large estates in the South
column2: and that particular antagonism is
column3: I think very evident in Europe
column4: and the transference to North America demonstrates how the large landholders and the small landholders have a continuous battle going on.  Now just as an aside—the industrialized North growing apart from agrarian South—let me just add to that by saying
column5: it is growing apart in certain ways of mechanization and perhaps some social relations and what have you.  But even John C. Calhoun recognized by 1848 or 1849 that the Northern industry was complimentary to Southern agriculture.  They weren't in competition.  That's part of the problem with that model.  Where is the competition between the two?  They actually kind of work together.  As for the matter of labor relations
column6: I have long argued that slavery was a threat to all kinds whatever kind of free labor was going on in the North.  It's just that it seems to me that so much of the literature has focused on wage labor in cities and has not looked at the way that wage labor was operating in the countryside.  At any event
column7: from the way I set it up
column8: and looked at the landholding patterns
column9: there is a moment of explicit collision and that is 1854 with the Kansas-Nebraska Act.

column1: CWBR: So it's not necessarily that there is no tension in the economic systems or in the labor but that
column2: that tension doesn't originate with the labor
column3: it doesn't originate with the economic systems
column4: it all comes down to the landholding patterns?

column1: JH: Yes I would argue that. The landholding patterns actually spin off different ideological formulations
column2: different understandings of the way you work with other people
column3: a different—actually a sense of mastery.  The large landholder is going to have a sense of mastery over others
column4: whereas in the small farm environment
column5: you have to master yourself in order to make the family farm operate.  When you get a collision
column6: the collision is going to be that the large operators are going to have this sense of mastery over others and it's going to get picked up. That's how I look at it.

column1: CWBR: So towards the beginning of the book
column2: it's not unusual for books talking about sectional antagonism to go well back into the Antebellum period
column3: but you go back a little further you take readers clear back as far as 1066
column4: on a another continent.  When you were starting out did you have an idea that this research was going to take you that far back
column5: or was that somewhat surprising?

column1: JH: It was a total surprise. I expected to go to 1840 and stay in the United States. But the question arose who were yeoman? What was involved? All I had was the background notion that most of us gain going to grad school. And so I got out Wallace Notestein
column2: New American Nation series
column3: out in 1960
column4: The English People on the Eve of Colonization
column5: and there it had a section on yeoman but also on farm labor
column6: which was originally in The English People on the Eve of Colonization wage labor
column7: and that just struck a bell right there so I just pursued it.  I kept trying to find yeoman in England and I ultimately came to the opinion that they were sort of a mystical beast.  I have to say 1066 to about 1450 was just a mess in terms of manors and land distribution patterns and the type of land tenure systems they had.  But probably about 1500-1550 it develops into the large estates
column8: tenant farms
column9: and massive agricultural labors
column10: and that's the contrast either I had forgotten about or I was ignorant of
column11: but that's the contrast that then plays a major role in my understanding of how agriculture in North America develops. You know I have to say it was a lot of fun. I really enjoyed getting out of the United States and going into agricultural development in parts of Europe and particularly in Great Britain. But yeah it was a total surprise. I didn’t expect to be doing this at all.

column1: CWBR: I was also surprised by how significant
column2: in Northern agriculture
column3: the early experiments by the Puritans were to this whole thing.  I expected ok
column4: a book on agriculture
column5: it's going to be looking very heavily at plantations and slavery and the sort of the expected set of elements
column6: but with going to Europe and then looking at that transference to North America it seems that you sort of revived a little bit of the centrality to that Puritan experiment in the overall narrative.

column1: JH: Which also was a bit of a surprise
column2: but I had to figure out why the estate system of English agriculture did not grow in the northern states
column3: and northern colonies.  I ultimately came to conclusion that they just couldn't transfer a good
column4: cheap labor source.  The tenant labor for example on the Van Rensselaer Estates and the patroons on the Hudson River could not generate the income necessary to live like a true English high gentry aristocrat.  Thus if you wanted to make money you went to the city.  That meant that the people who were willing to put in the work on a small farm were going to be able to get a farm
column5: which is very different from what happened in England.  I had to work somehow to explain that really gross deviation
column6: where in the Southern states because of an early discovery of tobacco
column7: later on rice and then cotton
column8: they found sort of a monopoly crop that could sustain large landholdings if they got a cheap source of labor
column9: and that was slavery.

column1: CWBR: When with the lack of cheap labor in the North I found it very interesting that yes
column2: in order to achieve a certain standard of living Northerners may have been drawn to the cities
column3: but their savings rates really seemed to upset assertions that later
column4: free labor is all about basically forcing labor into the lowest possible wages
column5: sort of imposing top-down capitalism on Northern farmers. Because not only are these Northern farmers—they seem far more agrarian than their Southern counterparts— but also they don't really even seem that poor.

column1: JH: I did the best I could with the numbers I could get from [Jeremy] Atack and [Fred] Bateman
column2: To Their Own Soil
column3: which gives income in the various states
column4: approximately the average
column5: and working that out on a family basis.  I put it between about $800-$1000 a year
column6: that's income of course.  That's not profit
column7: that's income.  So I guess on average some of these farmers are probably saving maybe $100 maybe $150-$200 a year.  Those are a little bit guesses.  I have to say that some questions of just important numbers that you would want to have
column8: not really existing in the literature.  So I took some leaps of faith
column9: just to get it out as to what kind of income would indicate what kind of standard living.  The way it sort of shook out is the northern farmer
column10: the average northern farmer
column11: is probably would be what we call a lower-middle class position.  Maybe to a middle class position
column12: in income.  Soon as you hit the word “class” you're getting into a whole other realm of behaviors and manual labor versus mental labor versus leisure and things like that.  But just in terms of income
column13: they are considerably above subsistence
column14: they're nowhere near luxury. Does that answer your question?

column1: CWBR: Yes
column2: yes.  And then to push a little further
column3: despite the fact that much is made of the larger cities being in the North
column4: how is it that these smaller farms
column5: very small farms compared to the Southern plantations
column6: were the backbone of those larger Northern cities?

column1: JH: First off the question of Northern cities the first thing I would probably say is that Northern cities develop because of trans-Atlantic trade. It's the Boston merchants
column2: the New York merchants are involved in the cotton trade
column3: the rice trade with the West Indies
column4: with China. They're making money that's outside the sphere of agriculture except to the point of local farms near the cities
column5: there you're going to get an exchange.  When you get closer into the two decades prior to the Civil War than you get the railroads and the great grain trade and the Great Lakes and the canal trade.  Then it's a question of rural areas supplying the urban areas with food which becomes
column6: actually
column7: a great economic locomotive for decades
column8: if not a century.  Why the cities grow though is not necessarily connected to Northern farms.  People gravitate to cities
column9: some of which because they don't like farm work—Horace Greeley being a good example
column10: actually a whole bunch of Republican leaders—

column1: CWBR: Abe Lincoln as well right?
JH: Well it's a lot of work and you know not everybody wants to put in that much effort just to get a competence. So why Northern cities kept growing
column2: you're not going to find a lot of answers out of rural America.  Rural America
column3: rural Northern society rather
column4: produces small towns because a small farmer cannot keep a small farm going without artisan/craftsmen help.  You have to have blacksmiths
column5: carpenters
column6: shoemakers (bootmakers in particular).  You have to have carriage makers.  There’s a host of craft disciplines that small farmers need.  I ran into a number of times these family farmers were trying to repair their wagons or their carriages or whatever
column7: and all they did was hurt themselves.  So the small family farms needed to be serviced and that's where you get the small towns.  As it becomes more commercial then these small towns start to need some credit facilities and merchants who are making long distant travels
column8: gives rise to the regional city
column9: and as commerce further develops
column10: they get attached then to the core cities: New York
column11: Boston
column12: Philadelphia later on Cleveland
column13: Chicago probably.  To contract this quickly
column14: I don't know why the great cities grew great.  My real answer probably would be
column15: and it’s not in the book
column16: its immigration. European immigrants are the ones who flood to the cities.

column1: CWBR: But what this does suggest is that those small towns are really important to that network and that's major point of divergence from the plantation complex.
JH: Oh yes
column2: that's right.  Actually the point I make about the plantation is the comparison between a free society
column3: as it turns out northern agricultural society
column4: and the plantation is the difference between the town setting in the north and the slave community.  Because the slave community on the large plantations is actually the reflection of the artisanal needs of the agricultural community in the south.  That's where you have the slave artisans and the difference in housing
column5: standard living
column6: and everything else is reflected in the difference between the small northern town and the slave community.

column1: CWBR: And the effect that the plantations have on populations in the South
column2: I thought was particularly fascinating that yes
column3: the plantations are engines to some extent for westward migration
column4: but not because these plantations are simply using up soil and then moving westward. It's because they're engrossing their landholding and pushing people westward.

column1: JH: I think yes they are pushing some people out. It's a long term process
column2: it was a long term process in England
column3: and I think the parallel works.  The problem is the sons and the daughters of small farmers.  Where they going to get the land to have their small farm?  The northern farms of the states that compose the Union in 1850
column4: was about 880
column5: 000 I think.  It's going to grow in the same states to over about 2.1 million in 1900-1910.  They're still multiplying small farms up there
column6: but in the southern states where you have the plantations of thousands and thousands of acres
column7: you're not going to have the spare land for extra small farms
column8: and I think that’s the crisis the yeoman were facing in the South. The plantation was undercutting the yeoman's society in the South.

column1: CWBR: I also want to talk about the plantation's ability to exert that kind of influence as it seems to me essentially a very capitalist enterprise. I mean this requires capital to make one large and then it sort of seems to create an advantage that just keeps regenerating
column2: they have the capital to invest in more land
column3: to invest in more technology...

column1: JH: The plantations were making large amounts of money. They were investing that money either in land acquisition or in more slaves. You know
column2: compared to the English example
column3: the English had to use a lot of manures and a lot of fertilizer in order to continue to be productive and to be successful in terms of money income.  Southern planters used
column4: as far as I can tell
column5: quite a bit of fertilizer.  The difference is though
column6: if necessity arose
column7: they can move West.  I mean they weren't cut off.  If they were cut off I think they would have made the switch to invest it in manures
column8: fertilizing
column9: something to maintain their operations.  I don't think that westward expansion was a life-or-death kind of situation for them.  Now I have to say that the financial statements of the plantation where they're investing their money in everything
column10: I'm not altogether—I don't have a balance sheet for them.  I don't know very many who actually do now that I think about it.  They were generating a large amount of income
column11: and the great planters were living close to the style of the gentry who were making about—they had 1000 acres or 10
column12: 000 acres which was considered high gentry in England.

column1: CWBR: There was some evidence that you found in Virginia that I thought was really interesting about just how adaptable the plantation system may have actually been even if it's a small study.
JH: OK first point
column2: the plantation turns out to be adaptable because it's big.  That's a point I got to that everybody emphasizes the number of slaves
column3: I emphasized the number of acres and slaves. With a large landholding you can do some more systematic
column4: efficient exercises than you can on a small farm.  Now the second part on wheat is I had read Irwin's article
column5: I think in the Journal of Economic History
column6: I'm not sure where
column7: on slavery and wheat growing in the Shenandoah
column8: on the Piedmont.  I thought that's good you know it's interesting
column9: economic questions
column10: economy of scale
column11: and how did the wheat farmers (slave owners) make slavery pay in wheat farming.  I had no idea it was very extensive.  I was invited by Gary Gallagher to give a talk to a small group in Charlottesville some years back and
column12: I think it was Edward Ayers
column13: hit me with slave plantations producing enormous amounts of wheat. Well I just sort of tucked that one away. Then when I went to the University of Virginia library and then to the Virginia Historical Society
column14: and I finally looked at some of these collections of wheat growers
column15: and northern farmers [were producing]
column16: what 50 bushels
column17: 100 bushels
column18: and these guys [southern planters] were producing 5
column22: and in one of the magazines of southern agriculture somebody was producing 10
column23: 000 bushels of wheat. That's enormous! That’s an enourmous output. That puts them right up there with some of the good sized English estates and by the way
column24: the English Estates were growing wheat and they were doing it with cheap labor.  There's no reason why I personally think the slave plantation could not have been adapted to other kinds of crop
column25: and the reason is because on a large plantation you can get specialization of labor.  Certain people do certain things all the time
column26: be the plowmen
column27: be the ditchers
column28: and have some carpenters
column30: transportation workers.  You make occupations that are very specialized and you get a certain economic efficiency from that.  Then there is the economies of scale from what [Robert] Fogel and [Stanley] Engerman call mass productions in the fields. That’s a point of some controversy
column31: but compared to a family farmer who has to do everything on his own
column32: has to stop doing some things to do something else
column33: has got a multiple number of jobs
column34: the comparison is pretty obvious.  The northern family farmer is a jack of all trades.  You’ve got to do everything.  He and either a couple sons or a hired hand to help him
column35: they're doing everything.  And you don't get any division of labor
column36: you don't get any repetitive motion activity in the fields like you do in slavery.  I think that was probably transferrable.  The old explanation is that
column38: a four month crop whereas cotton is what
column40: that it's the length of the growing season necessary which made slavery work for cotton but not for wheat.  I think that given the size of the plantation
column43: and from what I can tell from the account books
column44: the large planters were very rational people.  They kept a tight control on what was going on their plantation.  I don't see why they could not have gone into these other activities if cotton prices started to falter
column45: if they had to make a switch to something else to keep their plantations going
column46: or to move into other areas

column1: CWBR: Well let’s talk about that
column2: because despite how divergent these are—the system that creates self-mastery versus a system that's predicated on mastery of others—they coexist for a very long time
column3: and its territorial expansion that actually brings them into competition
column4: and then that's when you argue that one to has to come out on top.  I was wondering how does it work
column5: that you called the plantation complex
column6: basically that they're warring on small farmers?

column1: JH: I'm going to refine your statement a little bit
column2: which is whether the plantation complex had to expand economically or not is one question.  The political leaders thought it did.  Maybe for economic reasons
column3: maybe for political reasons in order to keep the Senate equal between the free and slave states. It is the political decision to repeal the Missouri Compromise. That is the kicker
column4: because those were the areas reserved for the sons and daughters of northern family farmers.  That's how they're [rural northerners] looking at this.  It’s their patrimony.  It belongs to them.  If you want a blundering generation
column5: I would say that's it.  The logic of my argument forces me to concede that if they would have drawn the 36 degree 30 minute line through to the Pacific Ocean
column6: that they might have avoided a sectional split.  Because the migration tends to go in a directly west pattern and not a north-south pattern
column7: and it was likely that if the southerners kept beneath that line and northerners kept above it
column8: then the two systems were not going to get entangled.  But as soon as the political leadership of the South declared we have to repeal that line for what
column9: reasons of honor
column10: reasons of constitutional equality
column11: for possible expansion
column12: whatever.  That's what ignites the northern agricultural districts.  By the way my last table
column13: where I chart out how the agricultural congressional districts are voting from 1842 to 1860
column14: I added that in the last two weeks of writing this book.  I had made the division
column15: I had listed all these congressional districts
column16: and I said well nobody can make of this
column17: I can't make sense of this.  So then I collapsed it to see the pattern and actually I went back and added 1842-1851
column18: and the northern farming congressional districts were voting democrat continuously
column19: even through the Wilmot Proviso California controversy—

column1: CWBR: They're actually the strongest voting block at one point aren't they?
JH: Yes by a substantial majority
column2: and then you hit 1854 and it's just the death knell of the Democrats in the northern agricultural congressional districts.  That was the point at which I said ok
column3: there’s an economic basis to this political realignment.  It was not necessarily a signal that a war is forthcoming
column4: it was not necessarily a signal that maybe expansion into Mexico would be opposed.  That's conjecture
column5: but it is a statement
column6: “a plantation will not go about 36 degrees 30 minutes.”  That will not be permitted
column7: and then southern political leaders read it as well
column8: “this is a war on our institution
column9: ” the Republican Party that grows out of it.  So some of it I would say
column10: there is some misreading going on.  Southerners are hypercritical
column11: hypersensitive to anything that suggests that slavery will not be considered an equivalent economic interest in the Union
column12: whereas most northerners distinctly have the realization that the plantation creates a different type of society
column13: one that is hostile to the small farm. And they're not going to allow it to go above 36 degrees 30 minutes.

column1: CWBR: We often like to interpret the Civil War as a catalyst for tremendous change
column2: but when we start talking about the landholding patterns rather than the labor on them specifically
column3: it seems to call a little bit [of that change] into question. Did the war really change this fundamental agricultural antagonism?

column1: JH: As far as northern agriculture is concerned
column2: at least by the numbers
column3: it continues on a trajectory of small farms
column4: at least in the states that constituted the Union in 1860
column5: the northern states.  When we get to the southern states
column6: the plantation system is gone
column7: but actually the landholding system—the people who owned the land continued to own the land.  That's the part
column8: Johnathan Wiener in 1978
column9: Social Origins of the New South
column10: I remember insisted that in Mississippi and Alabama the landholding pattern remained the same.  I think David Wright says the same
column11: but what’s the index here
column12: what are the actual numbers?  Sharecropping
column13: when it comes about
column14: makes the comparison between northern and southern agriculture really difficult.  Southern agriculture obviously undergoes a major transformation
column15: in terms of the labor supply and what happens to African Americans.  The North just preserves it's family farm
column16: rural village setting
column17: right up virtually into the 1950s.  Actually in a way
column18: I guess I edited this out
column19: but farms now have grown big and they're now containing thousands of [formerly independent] farms.  Even the old family farm is being incorporated so they can escape estate taxes and things like that.  But at the same time we’re seeing
column20: in almost every state
column21: the small towns disappearing
column22: drying up and dying.  I would say the reason for that is because the size of the farm has changed.  When the family farm was 100 acres
column23: 160 acres
column24: you got the small rural villages and towns
column25: but when your farms are thousands of acres
column26: it squeezes those towns out of existence.  That's what's happened in western Oklahoma
column27: western Kansas
column28: western Nebraska
column29: actually western New York is facing the same thing. And I would say the major part of it is the difference in the size of farms.

column1: CWBR: Well Professor Huston
column2: there’s a lot more I wish we had time to talk about
column3: certainly.  I appreciate you taking he time to discuss with us your most recent work
column4: carefully researched
column5: and a great read.  The book is the <i>British Gentry
column6: the Southern Planter
column7: and the Northern Family Farmer: Agriculture and Sectional Antagonism in North America.

column1: JH: Thank you.
