column1:
6173 9780674286085 $22.95 CWBR Author Interview:
The Long Emancipation: The Demise of Slavery in the United States Berlin
column2: Ira			"<h3>Interview with Ira Berlin
column3: Distinguished University Professor of History at the University of Maryland

column1: Interviewed by Zach Isenhower
Click here for the review
Civil War Book Review (CWBR): Today the Civil War Book Review is happy to speak with Ira Berlin
column2: Distinguished Professor of History at the University of Maryland.  Professor Berlin previously authored
column3: Slaves Without Masters: The Free Negro in the Antebellum South; Generations of Captivity: A History of Slaves in the United States; as well as Many Thousands Gone: The First Two Centuries of Slavery in Mainland North America. Today we get to talk about his most recent book
column4: The Long Emancipation: The Demise of slavery in the United States. Professor Berlin
column5: thank you for chatting with us today.

column1: Ira Berlin (IB): I'm delighted to be joining you.
CWBR: Readers familiar with your previous works will find this book a natural fit
column2: but I still want to start out by asking what drew you to this project
column3: and how you decided to approach it?

column1: IB: Several things specifically drew me to this project
column2: like most history it's about arguments and I found myself in arguments.  First most unfortunately for me
column3: with Steven Spielberg who of course had millions of viewers of what I found is a really wonderful movie
column4: in the technical sense
column5: that his movie
column6: Lincoln
column7: where he focuses on one event and sees this as critical to emancipation and while this made great theatre I felt it made very bad history.  So that started me off. And then I read an essay by a Portuguese scholar
column8: Joao Marques
column9: who made the case that the prime cause of abolition could be found not in the quarters of slaves
column10: but in the drawing rooms of white Europeans and Anglo-Americans.  And that I found even more appalling since it was a historians take on things.  And Marques’ essay was surrounded by commentary by other historians
column11: many of whom I had great respect for
column12: who seemed to go along with Marques. So eventually I felt I had to answer this and I had the opportunity to do that in the Nathan I. Huggins lectures at Harvard.  That I felt was kind of an interesting exercise because I wrote what I had to say
column13: and then I had to kind of deflate it into bite-size lectures since apparently nobody can sit still for more than a half an hour or so.  Then I was told that Harvard wanted to pump it up to a book
column14: so what I deflated had to be pumped up as well. So what you have in The Long Emancipation is something which has a long tale.

column1: CWBR: I'm interested in your take on the recent historiography or maybe it's presence in the wider public because it is very clear that though there might be good scholarship out there
column2: it doesn't really seem to compete with voices like Lincoln
column3: which you mentioned. So part of what your addressing here is—would it be safe to call—that these things like Lincoln create a “great man” history of emancipation
column4: and why is that type of approach problematic when we're talking about slavery and emancipation?

column1: IB: I think it's always problematic. These two genres of the cinema and the book are just so radically different. The cinema focuses on a moment
column2: and it brings to bear on that moment enormous visibility by great actors
column3: people who if they were reading the telephone book would make us pay attention.  But if we take a look at the text that they have and take a look at the screen play I'm always amazed by how few words are actually involved.  On the other hand our work is the work of words and there are lots of words and words give us a way of telling not a moment but a longer story.   Much more detail to talk about nuance
column4: to talk about contradictions and the like.  So I think there are probably always going to be some natural conflicts.  On this one of course
column5: as Spielberg rightly understood
column6: he was coming into a great buzzsaw of conflict that Americans have had for a long
column7: long time over the question of who freed the slaves.  A conflict which is larded with ideas about how history progresses
column8: larded by racial divisions and so on and so forth.

column1: CWBR: So slavery dies as a result of a process
column2: not an act.  But I was impressed with how
column3: while keeping sight of all these nuances that you mention
column4: the larger context never really escapes. And how do you manage to balance that? You made this project quite a bit smaller and then you had to make it larger again but it's still not a tremendously large book and you've managed to walk a line there that it seems that perhaps in film people have been unable to do.

column1: IB: I think it's also very difficult to do in writing history. It's always easier to write long than to write short. I tell that to my students when I assign a ten page paper and they're utterly appalled at the prospect of writing ten pages. I say if I was really going to punish you I'd assign a one page paper and demand that you stay within those bounds. I think the answer is to have some kind of more general framework that you're writing in. That enables you to define and to stay within those bounds. The question that seem to appeal to me in speaking both at the lectures and then writing the book
column2: was to say if we're going to conceive of emancipation as a near hundred-year event between the Revolution and the 13th Amendment
column3: than what are the defining markers
column4: the defining ideas which always shape emancipation during these years? I think once I defined those and went back and forth in my mind of were there three
column5: or were there five
column6: and so on? Once I defined those then in some ways the job became a lot simpler. It was how as you cut into this long history of emancipation—this near 100-year history—did you find black people in positions of leadership or centrality. Once you raise the question of emancipation the question of exactly what the status of the slave was going to be once freedom came and you go on down the list and look at each of those subjects at various critical points in the near hundred years.

column1: CWBR: When I was struck by how often in this sort of longer view there are these critical points where not only does the [theatrical]
column2: more popular focus on white abolitionist allies—really they're not there—but they couldn't be there because the moment wasn't right. And of course you note that white abolitionist allies helped
column3: they were important
column4: they certainly hastened slavery's end
column5: but they were often divided and struggled to maintain focus on slaves and equality. Why do you think they were so much more divided than the people of the center of all this?

column1: IB: I would put the question the other way
column2: why were black people so focused?  And I think the answer is
column3: for them this was always going to be a central question.  A question that could not be compromised.  For whites
column4: perhaps all but a few like Garrison who maybe understood better as a surrogate black man
column5: but for all but a few whites you can imagine a compromise
column6: you can imagine all of those compromises that are continually pushed forward from the gradual post-nati abolition to colonization
column7: to the endless other forms of gradualism which white abolitionists are willing to accept
column8: but are clearly just out of the question for black people. And of course they were right of everything that we know about gradualism is that it extends and extends and extends and certainly would have extended the emancipation period well into the twentieth Century given the power of the slave holding class and their ability to use the courts and to delay and the legislatures and delay in various ways.

column1: CWBR: Well that's what was interesting to me is that slavery's white defenders did not seem at all beset by the same level of disorganization that it's white detractors experienced.
IB: I think that's true.
CWBR: But then of course black communities both slave and free
column2: it's very remarkable how organized they were especially considering the barriers that they faced.  You mentioned shifting histories
column3: I think you called it
column4: and justifications for slavery. How do you think those fostered solidarity within these two opposing forces while the folks that we often focus on were sort of vacillating in the middle?

column1: IB: Well this is a long period played out over not simply a continent but the larger Atlantic world of people who are often living apart and barely connected by newspapers and other epistolary connections. Not really until the end of the period
column2: do we have telegraphs and other forms of communication which move information.  So it seems to me that it's only natural that these kinds of differences take a variety of regional forms within the anti-slavery community.  There's a Philadelphia community
column3: and a Boston community
column4: a Chicago community and people who are slugging it out still in various places in southern Illinois and along the various other borderlands. It seems to me that we're always going to have those kinds of differences and part of them can be accounted for the structure of information flow. But beyond that there are real differences that emerge once a proposal is put on the table and then the implications of that have to be sorted out.

column1: CWBR: I want to get into some of the details
column2: for one you mentioned
column3: regional variations and it was fascinating to read of the specific challenges that communities faced perhaps in the borderlands—that is free black communities—faced in the borderlands versus places in the North or even southern cities.  And it was surprising
column4: I think a lot of the assumptions readers might have
column5: such as that unilaterally things would be easier in the North did not always hold true. I was wondering if you could just talk about some of the variations that you did run into taking this longer view?

column1: IB: Of course a central variation if we're going to look at free blacks as a critical agent in the emancipatory process
column2: is North and South.  The simple fact is that if you lived in the South the chances of prosperity were perhaps greater than in the North
column3: where labor was valued and denied to black people
column4: whereas labor in the South was defined as negro work
column5: and you could actually make a considerable amount of money.  But you were deprived of all those kinds of rights of citizens and political rights whereas in the North
column6: largely impoverished black communities could petition
column7: could protest
column8: could march
column9: could publish newspapers and pamphlets and the like.  So you have this one fundamental difference
column10: and then of course you have differences that grow out within the North which grow out of very different kind of experiences. The New England one clearly one where free blacks have a much longer tradition of political and social rights. They have created a public sphere
column11: which is much more fragile in the middle states
column12: and of course in the western states or what was then called the old Northwest
column13: is more fragile still because slavery hangs on for so much longer
column14: well into the 1830s and ‘40s.  It's a viable institution despite the Northwest Ordinance
column15: kept alive through various surrogate forms.

column1: CWBR: And then of course it's not just the free black communities that are assaulting slavery and eroding slavery with their organizations outside of the slave system
column2: there's also the slaves themselves.  I think a lot of readers are probably familiar with some of the ways that slaves could resist slavery such as breaking tools or
column3: obviously
column4: escaping but what are some of the strategies over this long period of time that slaves used that historians have been slower to integrate into the narrative of slavery's slow demise?

column1: IB: I think the crucial one is
column2: the one which is central and which can't be emphasized enough
column3: is how these various forms of resistance played out within a northern public
column4: within a white northern public.  Some of these are simple fact that if there was no resistance then the assumption that slaveholders projected about slavery
column5: that slaves were happy
column6: than had to have certain relevance and certain truth. So that there was resistance
column7: the first thing
column8: contradicted that truth.  A second thing which I think is really crucial is that a substantial portion of the northern free black population carried the heritage of slavery into the North
column9: meaning that runaways
column10: the first generation of people who were free who say enter the North in the third decade of the nineteenth century
column11: who are going to have children who are a first generation of born free in the North.  And all of them carry the experience of slavery
column12: so the direct experience of slavery is there in the North and it has enormous power.  It's not simply these matters of running away or breaking tools or setting fire to the barn or pissing in the soup or however we want to define various kinds of resistance
column13: it's the active presence of slavery and hence the people who cannot forget the elemental violence of human rights that slavery does. What it takes away from people
column14: the physical marks it leaves on people and so on.  All of these can be mobilized as the Civil War comes closer
column15: whether it's in resistance to the fugitive slave law or whether it's the kinds of mobilization that will come with the creation of militias in that last decade before the war.

column1: CWBR: Well even once the war begins
column2: that was one of my favorite sections of how that process from the beginning of the war through 1863 or so became a microcosm for the longer process because it really wasn't just the act of enlisting black soldiers
column3: it was this slow realization that the northern white soldiers and their officers had because of sudden exposure to slavery and contact with former slaves right?

column1: IB: That's absolutely correct. Again once we've established these four events or four processes that we’ve seen played out during the American Revolution and then we’ve seen played out during the struggle for emancipation in the North and that we’ve seen played out in the various post-Garrisonian struggles
column2: we see that played out again in the years between 1861 and 1865. Which I think is what gives it a kind of validity at least in my own mind.

column1: CWBR: Another theme or dynamic rather that struck me was how time and time again we see in this book tremendous efforts that black communities and leaders had to maintain
column2: at great risk
column3: just to loosen the stranglehold of slavery.  And that always was a major contrast with the relative ease
column4: over most of this period
column5: with which slavery supporters could assault black rights or increase violence with really just the stroke of a pen with things like the Fugitive Slave Act.  And we often talk about slavery[‘s end] as being either ""from the bottom-up"" or ""top-down
column6: but this story to me really seemed to come out almost as a history of ""bottom-up"" vs. ""top down."" Would that be a fair characterization?

column1: IB: I would think that that would be a fair characterization. It strikes me that one of the things the anti-slavery movement is
column2: and makes it so relevant
column3: makes it such a powerful force it really is the model for movement for social liberation. Everything from Jeffersonian democracy to gay rights
column4: and often movements which seem to be in contradiction to each other like pro-choice and pro-life.  Again and again they adopt the ideals of the abolition movement
column5: the rhetoric of the abolition movement
column6: the modes of organization
column7: their tactics
column8: their strategies so that antislavery always seems to have great relevance for us as Americans and I think other social liberation movements around the world.

column1: CWBR: These major themes that you highlight---black agency in demanding freedom
column2: black agency in defining that freedom
column3: and the citizenship
column4: demanding equality and of course the violence that had to accompany all these processes.  These are far from finished playing out by 1865
column5: and I was just wondering how do you decide where
column6: if not this story
column7: where this book has to end? Were you tempted to press this narrative into Reconstruction beyond?

column1: IB: There’s always that temptation because so much of Reconstruction is a playing out of the slave experience in various ways. But emancipation
column2: the 13th Amendment
column3: the end of slavery is a sharp breaking point at least for me
column4: and I think for most slaves.  They understood these former slaves
column5: these freed people
column6: they understood of course that they were not free as they would like to be.  They understood that they did not have the rights of white people and they would not be given the rights of white people despite the Civil War amendments.  But they understood also that things had changed in a dramatic way.  They could live and sleep in the same house as their children and had responsibility for their parents
column7: they could no longer be driven as with an overseer
column8: they would
column9: by right
column10: work for wages and be able to keep those wages and invest them as they wished
column11: they could become property owners. All of these things were radically different than being a piece of property yourself. So I always think that emancipation is a place where we have to recalibrate and reload and rethink the experience of both the black and white in a slave society.

column1: CWBR: Another good reason to focus on the people actually experiencing this then.
IB: I would say
CWBR: Well Professor Berlin
column2: I appreciate you taking the time to discuss with us your most recent work
column3: The Long Emancipation: The Demise of Slavery in the United States.

column1:
IB: Thank you very much.

" Isenhower

column1:
6240 9780813060798 $84.95 CWBR Author Interview:
Unequal Freedoms: Ethnicity
column2: Race
column3: and White Supremacy in Civil War-Era Charleston		Strickland
column4: Jeff			"<h3>Interview with Jeff Strickland
column5: Associate Professor of History at Montclair State University

column1: Interviewed by Zach Isenhower
Click here for the review
Civil War Book Review (CWBR): Today the Civil War Book Review is pleased to speak with Jeff Strickland
column2: Associate Professor of History at Montclair State University.  Today we get to talk about his most recent book
column3: <i>Unequal Freedoms: Ethnicity
column4: Race
column5: and White Supremacy in Civil War-Era Charleston. Professor Strickland
column6: thank you for joining us today.

column1: Jeff Strickland (JS): Hi Zach
column2: it’s an honor to speak with you.

column1: CWBR: Obviously immigration gets a lot of attention in American history and obviously so does race
column2: but in Charleston you find an intersection of both that often gets overlooked. Why do you think that is?

column1: JS: Well I think that in part it has a lot to do with the way that historians treated Charleston
column2: and mainly that social history—following trends of the profession—has only received significant attention more recently.  That includes the role of immigrants
column3: for example in Charleston
column4: and African American history as well.  That doesn’t mean that historians aren’t treating it
column5: it is just that it still seems to take a back seat to political history in particular
column6: and then also I think to a certain extent economic history.  So the intersection I think nationally and perhaps even internationally is a more recent trend
column7: to look at immigrants and African Americans together.

column1: CWBR: Germans and Irish started arriving in the 1840s
column2: and that’s also just when racial divides in Southern society were really hardening
column3: so how was that relationship early on? Were they initially—immigrants that is—rather sympathetic towards the situations of African Americans?

column1: JS: I think that
column2: reflecting trends elsewhere for example in New Orleans
column3: the Irish and African Americans had more tensions than [between] any other immigrant group.  That trend is prevalent in Charleston
column4: however there are these exceptional relations between the Irish and African Americans.  But there is definitely more of a class tension between those two groups
column5: especially when it comes to free blacks
column6: but even to a certain extent slave laborers
column7: who were competing with Irish laborers for employment throughout the city.  Germans however
column8: were decidedly middle class and primarily shopkeepers.  So there wasn't that sense of economic competition that led to tensions.  Therefore
column9: it allowed for even more exceptional behavior
column10: social and economic.

column1: CWBR: That actually brings me to a side-note you made in the book. I was wondering if you could talk about the fact that
column2: just in terms of sources
column3: you found--I think as would be expected--a little bit better record of German immigrants and what they were doing because they are a little better off when they arrive
column4: as compared to Irish immigrants. But then a lot of the time you say that when you do find Irish immigrants
column5: they are doing some of the same things and adhering to some of the same patterns. I was wondering if you could talk about that a little bit?

column1: JS: Yes
column2: so for example German and Irish immigrants as slaveholders were underrepresented when compared to white southerners.  Then when you compared Germans and Irish
column3: then actually the Germans were even less represented.  So there are Irish slaveholders in the city
column4: even though the overwhelming majority of Irish immigrants are in fact working class.  And then when it comes to shopkeepers for example
column5: I found a few instances of
column6: for example
column7: selling liquor to the slaves.  So the few Irish shopkeepers that did exist
column8: some of them were getting into trouble for violating city laws concerning selling liquor to free blacks and to slaves.  Germans were doing that to a much greater extent
column9: but from a standpoint of basic business practices
column10: they were equal opportunity salesmen.

column1: CWBR: So what was it about urban slavery particularly that sort of created the opportunities for these unusual interactions?
JS: I think that when you think about the sheer numbers of individuals who are living in Charleston
column2: I'd say between 1850 and 1860 say 40
column4: 000 people
column5: you have a lot of people living in a relatively small space geographically.  So there were lots of different types of jobs that slaves and immigrants would work in and there were also lots of storekeepers in and around the city.  So I think that there are any number of possibilities for those sorts of relationships.  Also from a residential standpoint
column6: what you find is that Germans and Irish are going to live in the same buildings and sometimes in the same households.  And the same is true of free blacks
column7: and even in some cases of course when you have a slaveholder and their slaves
column8: they might live in the same spaces.  So I think that historians have long talked about this micro-segregation of a place like Charleston.  That white and African Americans lived very close to each other throughout the city
column9: yet it was often a class sort of situation where elites were living in the big houses and slaves in their quarters or in the case of free blacks
column10: in shanties or in alleyways.  The same was true of immigrants.  You had very successful immigrants who were living in homes that they'd built
column11: and in other cases Irish immigrants
column12: laborers for example
column13: also living in shanties.  There's the sense that throughout the city on a daily basis
column14: people are interacting from both races--white and black--and also immigrant groups as well.

column1: CWBR: At the same time though these interactions are defined by a social hierarchy. Where to immigrants end up fitting
column2: what role do they fulfill in that hierarchy?

column1: JS: One of the things that I talk about falls on social theory
column2: which is the idea of a middle-man minority.  This concept suggests that immigrants who are middle class and potentially sort of unable to reach that southern aristocracy
column3: will act as a buffer between those African Americans below them--both slave and free--and those elite white southerners above them
column4: many of them in fact slaveholders.  In doing that
column5: acting as a social buffer
column6: perhaps it actually relieves tension between those two groups that might otherwise be more intense.  You can't read a travel account or travel narrative from the nineteenth century in which a European visitor for example arrives in Charleston
column7: and they don't call it a cosmopolitan place.  They recognize there's something different about it.  The presence of these immigrants and slaves seems unique to them.  And of course you could go to New Orleans and find something very similar
column8: but the fact that this was happening in South Carolina
column9: and as we mentioned earlier
column10: it doesn't seem to have been treated all that much historically or by historians
column11: was very surprising to me when I embarked on the project.

column1: CWBR: The tensions you mention seem to have been at times pretty high. There was a real need by elite white southerners to impose some order and control on this and in a way it almost seemed like they turned to immigrants as a way of funding the police that they need to control the rest of the city
column2: including the slave population. Is that fair impression?

column1: JS: Yes
column2: what ends up happening is that nativist movements that are taking place throughout the country also show up in Charleston.  So white southerners recognize that immigrants--they indicate that immigrants are undermining the slavery system.  In so doing they begin to come down on [immigrants] very harshly
column3: in the form of arrests
column4: imprisonment
column5: and high fines.  Fines that would in many cases exceed annual earnings.  So that was one thing
column6: and then at the same time what you find are examples of Germans and free blacks
column7: and also slaves--in fact some Germans admit this later--that they were keeping slaves as concubines
column8: and even going as far as to suggest that they did so because white southern women didn't want anything to do with them.  This is something for a German to write about in the 1870s
column9: with no shame
column10: and to get published in a national German-American journal
column11: seems I think a bit odd.  So there's this sense that the Germans and the Irish were doing things that they shouldn't have been doing.  That the laws were very clear that they shouldn't sell liquor to slaves for example
column12: that they shouldn't trade with slaves
column13: and yet they continue to do it. And I think that has to do with those numbers that I mentioned earlier that it was a very difficult thing to in fact police. What you see in the 1850s is that the police force continues to grow in size. Policing becomes very aggressive as the stranglehold on slavery tightens throughout the 1850s.

column1: CWBR: In that context I found it sort of surprising that even before the Civil War a lot of immigrants
column2: while they're resisting the conventions of white supremacy
column3: and they're really taking some of the brunt of at least the financial aspect of this crackdown
column4: their politics seem very difficult to pin down.  They seem to support a lot of Republican policies before the war
column5: but they also support Stephen Douglas and the Kansas-Nebraska Act. What do you think was going on before the war?

column1: JS: I think that before the war there is this whole question of necessity and whether or not if you were in fact antislavery
column2: that you would even express it.  If there were--and I think that there were Germans who were unionists and did not agree with the institution of slavery--they weren't going to say it publicly for fear of being run out of town.  I also think that there was a sense even before one might arrive
column3: that you would have to abide by that.  Either express your support for the Democratic party and slavery
column4: or stay quiet
column5: but there was no room for an abolitionist German or Irish immigrant in the city.  There were examples of Germans and Irish immigrants assisting slaves in running away.  When they were captured they were dealt with pretty severely.  So I think that there's that going on.  In the wake of the war you begin to see trends toward the Republican party that exist elsewhere in the country.  So a shift to the Republican party in the late 1860s was very opportunistic for the Germans in Charleston.  They had difficulty breaking into the Democratic party in town.  So if they couldn't overtake it
column6: which is ultimately what they did
column7: they were going to go ahead and become involved in the Republican party.  I think that it's not all that surprising
column8: I guess
column9: given that they were in a slave society
column10: that wasn't going to tolerate any sort of opposition.

column1: CWBR: It seems like they stayed even more under the radar
column2: so to speak
column3: during the war
column4: when you have some of them volunteering for service.

column1: JS: Absolutely. I think that's one of the reasons that for a long time people sort of assumed the Germans were good Democrats before and after the war. But what you really begin to realize is that they volunteered for local service
column2: sure
column3: and of course some did actually fight outside of the [Confederate] Home Guard
column4: but those individuals who had property signed up for the Home Guard and stayed close.  Or just stayed out of the conflict altogether.  So there was without question support for the Confederacy
column5: and you're going to find that especially among folks who support white supremacy
column6: who support slavery
column7: but there were also individuals who wanted nothing to do with it and some of them left town
column8: going back to Germany
column9: and some of them went North to avoid it. I think to a lesser extent some Irish were doing the same sorts of things. And the Irish were trying to avoid conscription. I think that's also a sign that there's clearly dissension within the city.

column1: CWBR: As difficult as the war was
column2: it seems like Reconstruction really ends up being a catalyst for German and Irish immigrants
column3: if not breaking in socially yet
column4: really breaking in economically or moving upward I should say. At the same time their interests are very quickly reorienting away from any kind of common ground with black Charlestonians and towards the interests of white southerners. I was wondering if you could talk about the role that emancipation plays in this shift?

column1: JS: Absolutely
column2: what I found was that very quickly we being to see German and Irish politicians who were upwardly mobile were really drawn to the Republican party while at the same time in 1868
column3: for example
column4: we have sort of straight-out Democratic white supremacist ticket that [immigrants] were in many ways turned off by I think.  Although you'll see some names on the municipal ticket
column5: with that failure on the local
column6: state
column7: and national level in 1868
column8: Democrats recognize that they were going to have to enlist support from moderate Republicans.  So basically that's what ends up happening in Charleston.  Not only are they going to try to attract German and Irish immigrants over to the Democratic party
column9: they're also going to try to attract some moderate African Americans
column10: which they do a handful.  But what the Germans did in particular was when the nominating conventions were being held with each municipal election
column11: was that they were really well organized.  In many ways they shaped the formation of those tickets.  Whenever those traditional white supremacist Democrats tried to regain control
column12: the Germans would threaten to throw their support to the Republican party.  Many white southerners and white Charlestonians resented that fact. They weren't sure if the Germans really meant it or not
column13: and I do think that they did.  They were much more moderate
column14: and I think less white supremacist in 1868-1870 than perhaps they would become by 1876.

column1: CWBR: Of course at the same time African Americans are asserting their rights as much as possible. But all these economic barriers
column2: which sort of eased for immigrants after the war
column3: really crash down on African Americans.  They can't get credit
column4: and maybe can start business but most fail I think within the first couple of years. So a lot of their exercising of their rights ends up sort of being--these Fourth of July parades are emblematic of that. I was wondering if you could explain why these public demonstrations were so critical?

column1: JS: Alright so with emancipation African Americans and German and Irish immigrants as well gain access to public thoroughfares
column2: the public space that had previously largely denied them.  So African Americans on the Fourth of July are really turning out to express their emancipation
column3: to express their freedom.  At the same time white southerners have decided that they don't want to be part of those same celebrations
column4: that the Fourth of July
column5: that Independence Day represents
column6: in their view
column7: emancipation now.  So of course we had Emancipation Day as well
column8: but this is something that is taking place on the day that they formally would have shown up.  So basically the streets of downtown Charleston were decidedly the space of African Americans.  It was very unique and that trend lasted throughout Reconstruction and in some cases African Americans were showing up in large numbers even after Reconstruction.  I think that story
column9: when I think about that black Charlestonians today would be interested to know that the Fourth of July was their day
column10: and that white southerners and that white southerners really stayed away.

column1: CWBR: And then critically there's another festival in town. You'll probably have to correct my pronunciation
column2: but what was the Schuetzenfest for the German community?

column1: JS: The Schuetzenfest
column2: early on before the war
column3: was literally just a moment to bring the Germans together
column4: and the German rifle clubs
column5: and just have a weekend festival where they went out to the schuetzenplatz and had target competitions and had various games for children and for adults on the grounds
column6: and then later they would celebrate with a dance.  This was a very popular festival before the war
column7: but only really among the Germans.  In the late 1860s
column8: after the war has ended
column9: the Germans decide to start this festival again
column10: and indicative of their acceptance by white southerners
column11: by white Charlestonians
column12: they begin to invite white and black Charlestonians to this festival.  It very quickly increases in popularity.  I think one newspaper called it the Mardi Gras of Charleston by the 1870s.  So it was really a success
column13: and the presence of African Americans in that space I think was very important early on.  It said something about the Germans' moderation and their lack of acceptance of the sort of white supremacist platform.  But
column14: again reflecting trends elsewhere
column15: by the end of Reconstruction you begin to see that the Germans are putting up fences
column16: that they're not issuing tickets to a great extent to African Americans anymore
column17: and that some of the various events that take place--amusements so to speak--during the actual Schuetzenfest are inherently racist
column18: including blackface minstrelsy and other sorts of amusements.  That's what they called them
column19: ""amusements.""

column1: CWBR: Did white southerners sort of become involved with this [Schuetzenfest] out of a combination of rejecting Fourth of July celebrations and being attracted perhaps--being former Confederates
column2: former soldiers--to the martial aspect of parading and shooting
column3: or did they just very explicitly
column4: plainly see with this festival an opportunity to drive a wedge between German immigrant community and freed blacks?

column1: JS: Sure
column2: so one of the things that the Germans do is they need permission from the military to hold this particular parade that begins through the streets of Charleston
column3: and then makes its way to the schuetzenplatz grounds. That means that they're going to be marching through the streets with weapons. They receive permission because they argue that it's a cultural festival and they were doing it long before the war and it has nothing to do with the Confederacy. However white rifle clubs
column4: once they see that the Germans are doing this
column5: begin to incorporate and reorganize.  They really see this as an opportunity to get out there like they were before the war and to display their martial prowess.  So yes
column6: they very clearly recognize that they're not going to be able to do this on the Fourth of July
column7: but they can surely do it on the Schuetzenfest weekend. So I think it was a very explicit display of white supremacy
column8: in large part because you don't see African American rifle clubs in these parades. It's purely reserved for whites.

column1: CWBR: So by the end of Reconstruction
column3: the city's politics kind of seem to mirror the national controversy.  And this theme that we saw before the war seems to reemerge with Germans often supporting Republican policies but they're tending to vote the other way still
column4: and really the cost seems to fall on the African America community.  So do ethnic communities in the South
column5: when they look at the African American community
column6: do they see a potentially ruinous battle in trying to resist to any greater degree white supremacy in Charleston
column7: with Federal support eroding
column8: do they simply retreat out of self-preservation
column9: or is this a more profound new sense of self-identification more deeply with native-born white southerners?

column1: JS: I think that it could've gone a different way
column2: but it didn't.  So as they begin to very clearly recognize that their economic and social and to a certain extent political success will lie with white southerners
column3: that that association is much more beneficial to them than any sorts of alliances that they have historically had with the African American community
column4: they begin to really establish stronger ties with white southerners.  I think it's also a numbers game.  In many cases if you look at the age demographics of Germans and even the Irish immigrants
column5: by the mid-to-late 1870s you notice that first generation that the parents have begun to die off.  So this is largely a second generation ethnic American community of Germans and Irish
column6: who seem to be much more socialized to their southern identity than their parents were.  I guess from that standpoint it's not that surprising but I also think that the fact that they were so upwardly mobile
column7: that they do identify less with the plight of working class African Americans
column8: who have found restrictions to that same mobility basically impossible to crack through.  I shouldn't say impossible because of course there were handfuls of successful African Americans who were doing quite well
column9: but in large part you actually see in some cases African Americans are losing presence in certain skilled occupations
column10: that they had been doing for decades if not generations. By the 1870s you begin to see that they're being excluded from those same types of jobs. In a sense it's one of the sources that's very good for revealing this kind of information.

column1: CWBR: Well it's a fascinatingly complex dynamic
column2: I really enjoyed reading it.  Professor Strickland
column3: I appreciate you taking the time to chat with us about your most recent book
column4: <i>Unequal Freedoms: Ethnicity
column5: Race
column6: and White Supremacy in Civil War-Era Charleston.

column1: JS: Thank you very much
column2: Zach
column3:
it's been a pleasure.

column1:
6306 9780307592644 $30.00 CWBR Author Interview:
Custer's Trials: A Life on the Frontier of a New America Stiles
column2: T.J.			"<h3>Interview with T.J. Stiles
column3: author of Custer’s Trials: A Life on the Frontier of a New America

column1: Interviewed by Tom Barber
Click here for the review
Civil War Book Review (CWBR): The Civil War Book Review is pleased to speak with T.J. Stiles
column2: winner of multiple awards for biography and author of Jesse James: Last Rebel of the Civil War and The First Tycoon: The Epic Life of Cornelius Vanderbilt. Today we get to discuss his most recent work Custer's Trials: A Life on the Frontier of a New America. Mr. Stiles
column3: thank you for joining us today.

column1: T.J. Stiles: Thanks very much for interviewing me.
CWBR: You've worked on subjects from varied backgrounds and who played remarkably different roles in American history. What drew you to George Armstrong Custer
column2: who dies in a remote area at a young age
column3: and is today remembered mostly for how he died?

column1: Stiles: Well
column2: I approach my subjects from the perspective of a historian. I'm interested in the period and the questions and then that leads me to an interesting individual who I can really explore as a writer as well. And so
column3: Custer is someone who's ubiquitous in any exploration of the Civil War Era. He just keeps showing up everywhere. And so I was very aware of his life. And as I began to think how to explore this revolutionary period of the Civil War and Reconstruction
column4: and all of the attendant issues that come up with that period in a new way
column5: I wanted to think ""What have I not done? What are stories and aspects of this history that are interesting to me?"" And I thought about the western experience and I thought about the conventional Civil War in the East and I thought about the other aspects--literary
column6: cultural--of this period that I have not touched on in my first two books. Custer first drew because of the travelogue of his life. His travels across that astonishing nineteenth-century landscape. Traveling from New York to the Great Plains
column7: to dealing with pre-industrial nomadic peoples
column8: to visiting Wall Street and having business there. It is just an amazing journey across that panorama. And then
column9: as I began to look into what he was doing
column10: then it really came together for me as a book and what my particular take would be.

column1: CWBR: Custer's Trials is ostensibly about the life and times of Custer
column2: but as you have alluded to here
column3: the book works equally well as a story about the birth of a modern United States. When did you realize that Custer's life embodied this change and how did that realization shape your approach to writing about Custer and his contemporaries?

column1: Stiles: Well there are several things that began to put together a picture of Custer as a figure on a frontier in time
column2: as I put it in the book. We think of him as a figure on the geographical frontier
column3: which part of his life definitely embodied that. But also
column4: I eventually came to the conclusion that he was--what really defined his life
column5: more than a geographical frontier--was this chronological frontier. And one little nugget of that came from his serialized memoir
column6: which he wrote for a major magazine and which was published as a book
column7: about his first years in the West after the Civil War. And he described his march to the Battle of the Washita
column8: through a howling blizzard
column9: how he was leading the column through the snow with only a compass to guide. And he wrote that
column10: he could see the width of Broadway. He meant Broadway in New York. He didn't bother to identify it as the great street of New York. He assumed his audience would know. And that identification with the cosmopolitan center
column11: that allusion to an urban metropolitan landmark
column12: in a story about the wilderness of the Great Plains--about the Indian Wars--that was fascinating to me. That was something that just stuck in my mind from years ago when I first read that. And then as I began to look into his life
column13: and I began to look into the way he had a very diverse range of actives outside of service in the Army
column14: and even his service within the Army
column15: showed him struggling with excited by
column16: and sometimes rejecting all the many changes taking place in America at the time.

column1: CWBR: Even before the Civil War ended
column2: while praise for Custer was growing there was a growing contrast between him and Grant. Does this contrast reflect the thesis of your book
column3: which places Custer on this frontier in time?

column1: Stiles: I think the relationship between Custer and Grant is absolutely central to the book. One of the interesting things about Custer is that he had this very large and flamboyant
column2: colorful
column3: public life and yet because of the volume of material that has been preserved--the number of letters he wrote
column4: the way in which his wife wrote about their intimate life together---we have a very interior portrait of Custer and this is actually the most interior biography I've been able to write so far. In his relationship with Grant
column5: you see both the external and the interior aspects of Custer
column6: highlighted by the contrast with Grant. And the growing tension between Custer and the times is reflected in and exacerbated by his growing tension with Grant. Grant was equally American with Custer in many ways. They were both from Ohio
column7: they both were from struggling families
column8: they had very obscure backgrounds
column9: and yet
column10: Grant was understated. He was someone who despised flamboyance and the big show. He was extremely practical--someone who was very modest and direct in his methods and his manner. Custer
column11: of course
column12: was the flamboyant figure
column13: very consciously adopting an almost southern air of the cavalier. And that was significant. That isn't just something he should be scorned for. And yet
column14: it is something that is a little bit out of step with an America that was more organizational
column15: industrial
column16: and corporate
column17: and one that that was more technical as opposed to heroic and individualist in the way that Jacksonian America had been. And this then throughout the course of his relationship with Grant
column18: this difference in style
column19: in leadership
column20: difference in style in their public image
column21: the difference in their interest to having a public image
column22: which did not appeal to Grant as much as it did to Custer obviously. That becomes caught up with the way they address the times. Grant is somebody who came to embrace not only emancipation
column23: but civil rights. Whereas Custer increasingly made himself into a public figure opposing civil rights
column24: opposing black suffrage
column25: opposing the fourteenth amendment. There is a rise and fall in their how much they confronted each other personally
column26: but it really came to a head right before the 1876 Little Bighorn Campaign.

column1: CWBR: Grant is an interesting figure because he is our segue into other figures in Custer's life that you dwell on in the book. Custer is obviously influenced tremendously by the people closest to him or the people above him in terms of the military institution. So can you describe the dynamic between Custer
column2: his wife Libbie
column3: and Eliza Brown
column4: the African American teenager he hired during the Civil War?

column1: Stiles: Yeah
column2: this is something that is both fascinating in terms of simply the human narrative but also the way in which Custer came to confront
column3: in a very personal way
column4: the larger issues of the Civil War. Custer was someone who had a professional military education
column5: even though he famously graduated last in his class at West Point in 1861
column6: though first in demerits. He graduated--and many cadets did not make it all the way through. He had a professional military education
column7: probably the best in the world at that point. And yet he rose in the Civil War through personal connections
column8: through patronage
column9: the traditional method of advancing in the world
column10: and he combined ability and real merit with this working the chains of patronage. So 1863
column11: on the eve of the battle of Gettysburg
column12: his personal connections with General Alfred Pleasonton lifted him to the rank of Brigadier General
column13: gave him command of the Michigan Brigade of Cavalry
column14: he demonstrate his ability at the Battle of Gettysburg
column15: particularly the third day
column16: when he not only famously led charges
column17: but he also deployed his men well and making use of their Spencer rifles and the new technology that the Union is bringing to the War. Now this great moment
column18: this transformation in Custer's life
column19: when he became a Brigadier General of the US volunteers
column20: this led him to want to adopt the lifestyle of a general and the lifestyle he'd seen Pleasonton lead. So he went to a contraband camp in Virginia at the close of the Gettysburg campaign and he—a contraband camp of course as I know your listeners know was a camp for escaped slaves--and he found this young teenage from the piedmont region of Virginia
column21: who was really extraordinary. She obviously had a real presence
column22: as we know not only from Custer's response to her
column23: but from what his wife Libbie later wrote. And she went to work for him as his cook
column24: she took advantage of that position to really build authority and security for herself
column25: such as she had never known. She took all of the skills of dealing with white people from a position of total powerlessness and she applied those in the role of the general's cook
column26: and she really became his domestic manager. She traded information with visitors
column27: couriers and messengers from other commands. She served as the banker
column28: an interceder for Custer's men
column29: she began to build her own patronage network by distributing food out of the general's mess. So she is someone who really took advantage of that position
column30: built up the security for herself and then had a very interesting change in her life when February 1864 Custer then married Elizabeth Bacon
column31: or Libbie as she was known. A very well education
column34: who came to the front and found that another woman was running the household
column35: a young black woman. Now this was long before the Great Migration
column36: there are very few black people in the North
column37: and Libbie doesn't know how to navigate that relationship. She expects to have the domestic authority as the wife
column38: and especially as the wife of a general. And yet she finds herself consistently outmaneuvered by this young black woman. So there is a personal tension as well as mutual admiration and respect between the two women
column41: find the issues of race and slavery personified in this extremely intelligent and capable and resourceful black woman
column42: and she actually tries to educate the Custers in slavery. She brings them
column44: they go to Louisiana and to Texas. She brings them into slave quarters
column45: she introduces them to people who have been whipped
column46: and shows the scars on their backs and really helps to change Custer's views because he had quite frankly accepted slavery and opposed Lincoln's election in 1860. And yet this personal relationship
column48: bring him around on the issues of emancipation
column49: and that relationship between the three of them went on for six years until 1869.

column1: CWBR: Eliza Brown
column2: as a researcher
column3: how difficult was it and what sort of methods did you use to reconstruct her life
column4: to put it back together because it seems that a lot of the material you were able to draw on had to come from Custer or his wife
column5: so how did get to an authentic version of Eliza Brown?

column1: Stiles: This is a very interesting question. This is something I dealt with
column2: for example in my first book Jesse James
column3: for whom but not only for Jesse James but the lives of the slaves in his family and his family members was not well documented in letters and diaries and traditional sources. So it is a matter of correlation and interpretation and putting together small bits of information until it builds a convincing picture. In the case of Eliza Brown
column4: we also have the benefit of the many amateur researchers who looked into Custer's life. He's one of those figures who has attracted a great deal non-scholarly research and as my late mentor Richard Maxwell Brown said: ""These are grassroots historians.” They should not be scorned. They don't operate within the academic structure
column5: they are not interested in issues of historiography
column6: they can get very focused on the trees rather than the forest and yet a lot of them do great work. And so
column7: there has been research on Eliza Brown--the farm she came from
column8: who her slaveholders were
column9: where she ended up after she left the Custers. I was able to draw on those bits of information. Put together with what historians have written
column10: I think Brenda Stevenson is the author of Life in Black and White: A Look at Slave Life in Northern Virginia (Life in Black and White: Family and Community in the Slave South) and tries to understand what daily life was life
column11: what the relationships were like
column12: what the struggles were like for the enslaved
column13: in exactly the part of the country where Eliza Brown came from. So it's drawing on the historiography
column14: putting it together with bits of data
column15: and then getting into the more qualitative look at her life
column16: much of which comes through not only mentions in Custer's accounts
column17: in his letters
column18: and letters from Libbie Custer
column19: but also Libbie's memoirs is a very important source. Memoirs need to be treated with a grain of salt of course
column20: more than a grain of salt. What's fascinating about Libbie Custer's memoirs is that if you read it carefully with an attention to who Eliza Brown and her position in the world
column21: you can read it very differently than has been read in the past. Libbie Custer reflected in her memoirs this tension
column22: as well as the mutual respect and support
column23: that the two of them had. There's many moments throughout their memoirs which she highlights moments where she embarrassed Eliza Brown
column24: when she sort of showed her up
column25: her racism is quite frank. We understand the tension between the two women because Libbie Custer wrote about it. It's there in her own account and so that is convincing to me because I don't think it is particularly flattering to Libbie Custer. Sometimes you take the same bit of information and if you think about that information from the perspective of the person who is has traditionally not been in power to tell the story it looks very different.

column1: So to take one example
column2: when Custer was deployed to Louisiana immediately after the Grand Review of the armies and he took Eliza Brown
column3: took Libbie
column4: they stopped briefly in Michigan
column5: and Libbie's hometown Monroe
column6: then they traveled through Ohio to their way to New Orleans
column7: they stopped at a restaurant that had no separate facilities for black customers. And so
column8: the owner refused to serve Eliza Brown at all and Custer insisted that she be fed. And so he insisted
column9: in a great confrontation with the owner
column10: that she be seated with Custer and his staff. And Libbie
column11: and it was a very tense moment
column12: as we know from Libbie’s memoir
column13: and this has been traditionally has been seen as a great thing. Custer was insisting that his servant should be showed respect and served also. But for one thing it is the lack of segregated facilities that upset Custer. The fact that there were no facilities where her to be fed. He wasn't trying to desegregate the dining halls of Ohio; he was asserting his position in the world as a major general at that point of the US Volunteers. And he wasn't going to let some civilian say that his servant couldn't eat. And for Eliza Brown
column14: that moment is fraught with tension; she did not ask for that confrontation. She is aware of the dangers of confrontations over race; and she knows that if anyone is going to suffer from that confrontation
column15: it will be her. This is my interpretation brought in by imaginatively understanding--based on our knowledge of race relations of the Civil War and its immediate aftermath--what life was like for a black person who is powerless in that situation. Libbie wrote that she was embarrassed
column16: and I write about that in the page
column17: but I say from Eliza Brown's perspective it’s not embarrassment-- its fear
column18: its danger
column19: and a sense of powerlessness that's going to be in play. Now that's interpretation
column20: that's not fact. And yet
column21: highlighting this moment
column22: drawing it out
column23: putting my interpretations on the page
column24: draws attention to it and I hope gets the reader to think about these moments from the perspective from somebody whose normally been left in the margins
column25: or left out of the picture entirely.

column1: CWBR: What was it about the West as a context--because you talk a lot about context and how much it matters for these historical actors--what was so different about the American West versus Custer's lived experiences before the war and during the war?
Stiles: That's an interesting question because it brings out Custer's personal flaws and conundrums as well as the
column2: as you put it
column3: the contextual differences. Custer was someone who I think was driven by a great ambition; he desired greatness and he desired to be seen as great; and
column4: coming from a very obscure background
column5: he had an underside
column6: I detect
column7: an underside of insecurity
column8: which gave him great volatility. He rose to high rank in the U.S. Volunteers at a very age without much of an apprenticeship in lower levels of command; he was from a staff position to a command position very early in his life; and
column9: so he didn't have the seasoning
column10: the experience and the slow process of maturation within an organization
column11: within in a command. The Civil War though was a great crisis and we see in the Civil War that--and actually in later moments in the West also--that in combat is the one moment when we don't see signs of insecurity
column12: we don't see the volatility that marked other areas of his personal life. He was at ease; he was himself; and
column13: so combat despite the impression left by how he died
column14: combat was his great forte. He wasn't simply lucky
column15: even though he was; he wasn't simply heroic in leading charges
column16: though he was; he really knew how to husband his resources
column17: how to make use of the latest technology. He more often deployed his men in dismounted skirmish lines in the Civil War then he had them lead in mounted charges. He made great use of his rifled artillery and other resources available to him. And so
column18: we see Custer as a true professional in the Civil War and in moments that come afterward. The problem is
column19: the moment that combat stops
column20: Custer now has to play a different role; he has to play a different role within the Army itself
column21: in which his role goes from combat leadership to what can only be called management. He has learn how to deal with troops who are no longer driven by the great mission of the Civil War who are now going to be dealing quotidian complaints about food and discipline
column22: and other issues that come up in any command. He has to develop tact; he as to develop a way of keeping his troops contented to a certain degree without simply relying his heroic image
column23: and that's an area where he really flounders. And what happens is this is where we see the insecurity in Custer. Again and again he lashes out
column24: very different from the way that Grant as a commander operated. Grant really knew how to win his troops loyalty without relying on harsh discipline
column25: not that he didn't use it
column26: but that wasn't his primary hallmark as a commander.

column1: Custer on the other hand engaged in whippings
column2: head shavings--other humiliations--to try and force his men to knuckle under
column3: and it only built up more resentment. Now in the different phases in the West the first came actually in this period of 1865 into very early 1866 when he was deployed into Louisiana and then Texas. At that point he was commanding U.S. volunteers who had not been mustered out; and
column4: these are troops that wanted to go home. He was dealing with Texas which is an area that had never been significantly invaded by Union forces
column5: it had not been conquered; slavery had gotten stronger there
column6: and there we begin to see another aspect of Custer's post war difficulties
column7: which is a return to his conservative viewpoint
column8: and also his desire to be accepted by
column9: what we can only call
column10: his social superiors. So the planters of Texas who had done quite well during the war
column11: they cultivate Custer and he very readily accepts their invitations and their offers to socialize with them. And we see his Jacksonian Democratic
column12: conservative views on race and society really coming back to the fore after all of this lobbying by Eliza Brown about slavery. That's the political of this story and how it put him in conflict with the country becomes very important with his next deployment in the West in 1866 and 1867.

column1: CWBR: Could we also describe the difference between east and west at this time as one of---in the American West--especially in the 1870s--as a place that is simply less managed
column2: it's one that seems in your book
column3: at least
column4: seems to be a place that is racially ambiguous at times
column5: where people who are in the margins of society in the east are in power in the west
column6: does that play into the West's ability to confound not only Custer but his contemporaries too?

column1: Stiles: Well I think that's a major issue in general in the West. We have to remember of course there are many wests. The southwest in Texas you have the slave economy of the South
column2: which not only in Texas
column3: but also in the so-called Five Civilized tribes of the nations that had been ejected from the southeast on the Trail of Tears
column4: they have slavery
column5: they sided with the Confederacy. You have that southern slaveholding culture is very strong on the southern Great Plains
column6: and then you have other layers of the West
column7: which are brining into a mix and conflict and alliance
column8: a very complex mix of very different peoples in a vast landscape. So of course you have Latino-Americans--I wouldn't call them Mexican-Americans because the border crossed them--who have strongly influenced a lot of the culture in the West and especially in the southwest. You have many different Native Americans who are in conflict with each other. You have different economies that are taking place; you have of course the Sodbusters in Kansas and Nebraska
column9: but you also have the mining economy of the mountain states
column10: and you have the great transit that's taking place across the Great Plains
column11: which is a major issue
column12: and something the Army doesn’t really quite come to grips with because its driving the conflict of the High Plains nations. And then you have this hybrid hunting and trading economy that the Great Plains peoples have to varying degrees and the conflicts between the High Plains who are fully nomadic and the nations of the lower Great Plains
column13: lower in altitude to the east
column14: who combine horticulture with seasonal hunting
column15: and who are in a great conflict with the High Plains nations.

column1: It's a multilayered set of conflicts. You have a changing economy as the cattle drives start and you have the great cow-towns grow-up in Kansas
column2: and you have different sources of conflict. It's not simply whites come in and try to grab the land
column3: it's migration through the West is creating economic degradation which is making the bison based economy of the High Plains untenable
column4: so the Army keeps trying to assert the right of passage and the Great Plains people are stating quite frankly that's making their lives untenable and the Army doesn't really quite accept it--or to the degree that they understand it--they say you just have to live with it. So there are all of these different tensions that are taking place and Custer steps into this very complex landscape at a moment of personal crisis. I mean 1866 and 1867
column5: when Custer is deployed to Ft. Riley
column6: now his regular Army rank is that of Lieutenant Colonel
column7: he is effectively the field commander of the new 7th cavalry
column8: and yet he was in personal crisis because he had thrown him into Andrew Johnson's campaign again the Republicans and the 14th amendment. He went alongside Grant on the Swing Around the Circle
column9: but where Grant was disgusted by Johnson's politics
column10: and actually left the campaign early
column11: Custer spoke to the crowds alongside Johnson on the stump and helped organize a soldier's convention to support Andrew Johnson
column12: to oppose the 14th amendment
column13: the Republicans; he very much himself a conservative national political figure. And as a result
column14: he was scorned by a majority of--at least politically speaking--by a majority of people in the North. And he went from being a great hero to being a---someone who was intensely controversial.

column1: This is before he starts confronting the Indian Wars and so that important; he's under pressure
column2: he's under crisis. And his constant neediness
column3: this personal neediness of his
column4: for attention and approval and for sex
column5: quite frankly
column6: put him in crisis in his marriage. He had spent time in New York in 1866
column7: away from his wife
column8: he was flirting
column9: he was pursuing other women. And I believe
column10: from reading the bits of evidence that we have
column11: that he had as a result created a crisis in his marriage. So Custer confronts this very complex picture of the conflict  with the High Plains nations at a moment when he is personally preoccupied
column12: and it's a very different kind of warfare
column13: and of course that's something historians have stressed
column14: that the warfare on the Great Plains
column15: it’s not properly guerilla warfare--it’s a raiding warfare
column16: something that Alexander the Great had to deal with in Afghanistan
column17: something that settled populations have dealt with on their borders
column18: on their frontiers of nomadic people from time immemorial. And it's a very difficult kind of warfare for a conventional force to manage
column19: and Custer is trying to carry out orders that are not necessarily well thought out
column20: he's put in an impossible position at a time when he is least able to grapple with it personally. As a result
column21: he completely falls apart—in 1867 he was court marshalled
column22: quite rightly
column23: and convicted quite rightly
column24: and again it reflects this amazing confluence of personal disaster
column25: of political crisis in the nation
column26: and of these great crises that are taking place on the Great Plains as a result of the U.S.'s expansion into this space that has been dominated by other peoples for so long.

column1: CWBR: What were the expectations of plains Indians? Well the high plains Indians especially
column2: who were used to military conquest--their expectation was to win militarily and not necessarily acquiesce to the United States offers of land and settlement?

column1: Stiles: This is something we have to remember is that the United States had been a presence in the West
column2: the trans-Mississippi West since the time of Lewis and Clark
column3: and the U.S. had a sort of contractual relationship
column4: a relationship of alliance and partnership
column5: rather than domination. So
column6: for example
column7: the Lakotas in the northern plains they had actually
column8: at various points
column9: been allies with the United States as the U.S. dealt with other nations. They had been enemies and allies
column10: they had confronted I don't deal with much in the book
column11: but extremely important
column12: is the war on the northern plains that resulted from the so called Sioux uprising in Minnesota during the Civil War. General Alfred Sully led a column
column13: including a number confederate prisoners of war who were given the option of serving in the U.S. Amy in the West--What's the term? galvanized Confederates who'd been converted into Union soldier--and led this destructive column through the West; and
column14: yet what happened after that campaign is that it was followed by Red Cloud's War where there were some fights including the famous the so-called Fetterman Massacre
column15: and there were some Army victories
column16: some Indian victories
column17: and the U.S. government decided to ratify this Sioux on the northern plains. So rather than a story of constant displacement and constant defeat--you know we tend think of the U.S. of advancing west and defeating and displacing various Indian nations--a kind of march of defeat for the Indian nations--the Sioux had seen ups and downs
column18: they'd seen victories and defeats followed by the Fort Laramie Treaty
column19: which basically ratified their power on the northern plains. It granted them this huge reservation and then a larger area that was called ""unseated Sioux territory
column20: which included a big disputed zone in their wars with Crows and others to the West. And then they accepted these treaty goods and treaty rations that were given to them
column21: that the U.S. saw as a show of the U.S.'s superior position
column22: that they were ceding to U.S. authority and they have these agency posts in their territory and they come in and accept these rations. Whereas I think the Sioux were seeing this as a part of their ongoing contractual relationship with the U.S. If anything it was more resembling the tribute that they forced some of their militarily weaker neighbors over time. They certainly didn't see themselves as a defeated and subordinate people. And so this is very different from the High Plains people
column23: of the central plains
column24: who were confronting US power and suffering defeats much more directly.

column1: What leads to the great Sioux War of 1876 and '77
column2: is not necessarily a sense of grievance by the Sioux they were upset by many things
column3: particularly the invasion of miners into the Black Hills
column4: but the fact that they had a sense of power--1873
column5: for example
column6: was climax of their generations long war with the Pawnees. They wiped out the last major Pawnee buffalo hunting party on the Great Plains. So they are embroiled in a series of wars
column7: which they are winning at the time when they face the great confrontation with the U.S.; and that's very important to remember
column8: that they were not feeling weak
column9: they were feeling strong when Custer advanced to his death.
